DOC.HEAD: Teen-age Husband Kills Wife, Child and Himself
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Young marriages face tough odds, but Todd and Bonnie Longsine seemed off to a good start and headed away from some of the troubles of their adolescent years. The two teen-agers owned a three-bedroom mobile home, a car and a pickup truck and had a happy 14-month-old son, Josh, whose blond hair and blue eyes charmed their friends. But Longsine, 19, turned against his family this week, fatally shooting 18-year-old Bonnie, setting a fire that killed Josh and then ending his own life. Their bodies were found Thursday by a repairman making a service call to their trailer. No suicide note was found, leaving their neighbors in the Country Estates Mobile Home Park in Greenville, a town of 225 in northeastern Wisconsin, without explanations. ``From what I could tell from Todd and Bonnie, everything seemed to be fine,'' neighbor Kathy Nichols said. ``It seemed like he had it together. He was happy to be a father.'' The couple married in October 1988, a month or so before Josh was born, and bought their trailer home a year later. Todd graduated from Menasha High School in 1988, worked at a warehouse for a brief time and then enrolled in a trade school to learn metal welding. Bonnie was a waitress in nearby Appleton, hoping to move up to management. Their actions seemed to be cutting a path away from their rocky adolescence, when Todd had some skirmishes with the law and Bonnie dropped out of Menasha High before her junior year. But not everybody believed that all was well with the couple. Wendy Reiland, a friend of Mrs. Longsine's, said the young mother wanted out within months of the marriage, then changed her mind. The couple filed a joint divorce petition a year ago, then withdrew it last summer. A neighbor, Krista Vollmer, saw a ``for sale'' sign in the window of their trailer one day earlier this month. Officials at Fox Valley Technical College said Todd failed to register Jan. 19 for the spring semester. Outagamie County Sheriff Thomas Drootsan said the .22-caliber rifle that Longsine used was bought just this week. He shot Bonnie, set the fire outside Josh's bedroom that asphyxiated the toddler as he slept, and then shot himself, authorities said. The deaths went undetected until the repairman's call Thursday because the fire burned itself out. Sheriff's Capt. Gary Barrington said Friday that Longsine had a juvenile record, including an arrest for disorderly conduct, but had not been in major trouble. There were no reports of wife or child abuse during the marriage, authorities said. ``I wish we had a real good motive to lay on you, but right now we don't,'' Barrington said. Longsine's step-grandmother, Irene Stoeger, said she remembered her grandson's being in trouble while growing up. His mother ``reported him to the police department a lot,'' Ms. Stoeger said. ``Quite a few years ago, Todd went on a rampage. He got mad.'' Police in Menasha said they investigated Longsine to see if he was helping Bonnie hide when she ran away from home in spring 1988 at age 17. He was not charged with anything and she eventually came back home. Mrs. Longsine's mother, Barb Godeck, said Friday that the family had reservations about Longsine when the two married later that year. The couple had met at a dance, she said. ``There were probably a lot of things we weren't pleased about,'' she said. ``Sometimes you think you know someone and you really don't. ``Bonnie was a very loving person,'' her mother added. ``Anyone who knew her liked her. She had no enemies.'' Mrs. Longsine's boss at Marc's Big Boy restaurant, Dave Anderson, called her a hard worker. He said she seemed quieter, somewhat tense the last two weeks. ``We had ideas she was having marriage problems, but to what extent? Everybody goes through marriage problems,'' he said. ``As far as we knew, they were doing OK financially.''
