DOC.HEAD: Libel Trial Investigates Bimbos, `Hommes Serieux'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: When the editor of The Sunday Times sues the former editor of The Sunday Telegraph for libel, fascinating issues are aired in court. Does it behoove ``hommes serieux'' to be seen in nightclubs? Should two editors pursue the same woman? If a bimbette is a younger bimbo, then what is an ``aging bimbette?'' Those issues arose this week as Andrew Neil, editor of The Sunday Times, waged his libel suit against Peregrine Worsthorne, former editor of The Sunday Telegraph. It's jam for the tabloids, of course, but the usually sober quality papers also are enjoying a wallow in a case rife with the personal and professional passions of Fleet Street, London's historic newspaper district. Neil alleges that Worsthorne and The Sunday Telegraph falsely implied that he knew that Pamella Bordes, his girlfriend for four months in 1988, was a prostitute. Miss Bordes, a former Miss India, was a low-paid researcher in the House of Commons a year ago when a tabloid broke the story of her other life. That created a hot market for photos of Miss Bordes, including one of her on the dance floor with Neil and another of her holding hands with Neil's Sunday competitor, Donald Trelford, editor of The Observer. In an editorial titled ``Playboys as Editors'' in the March 19 Sunday Telegraph, Worsthorne thundered that ``anybody who finds the company of bimbos ... indispensable to their professional fulfillment might do well to conclude that editorial chairs were not designed for them.'' Neil, a stocky, 40-year-old bachelor, alleges that the editorial, a cartoon and a subsequent article by another writer falsely implied that he knew that his girlfriend was a prostitute. The principals in the case are all well-acquainted. Rupert Murdoch owns The Sunday Times as well as The News of the World, which broke the Bordes story. After Worsthorne's editorial, Neil acknowledged, The Sunday Times had tried to hire him, and it has hired the author of the other Sunday Telegraph article cited in the suit. The defendants say Worsthorne's editorial was fair comment and not, as opposing counsel suggested, ``an overwritten piece of humbug.'' ``Newspapers are not in the business of being particularly tolerant or understanding about public figures when they get into a scandal,'' testified Worsthorne, a patrician figure with flowing silver hair. Neil met Miss Bordes at a club called Tramp, which Worsthorne regards as no fit milieu for the editor of The Sunday Times. It is not a place where one is apt to meet the archbishop of Canterbury, the prime minister ``or even an archdeacon,'' Worsthorne said, but a place where most men go ``for one reason _ to pick up girls.'' At least, he said on cross-examination, that's why he used to go to nightclubs. Editors, Worsthorne said, once were ``hommes serieux,'' serious men who frequented ``learned seminars, European chancelleries, establishment dinners.'' Neil said he had become aware that Trelford also was interested in Miss Bordes, but Neil warned Trelford away ``because I thought no newspaper could resist a story of two editors and the same woman.'' After a headline in The Sun, Murdoch's big-selling daily, called Trelford ``Dirty Don,'' Trelford publicly wondered why there was no mention of ``Randy Andy'' Neil. The Sun made amends with Thursday's screamer headline: ``DIRTY DON TRIED TO PULL MY PAM SAYS RANDY ANDY'' Earlier in the week, Mr. Justice Michael Davis was puzzled by the terminology in the gossip columns. ``Mr. Neil,'' the judge interjected, ``we heard yesterday the word bimbo. I presume a bimbette is a young bimbo. But can you help us? What is an `aging bimbette'?'' Neil said he did not know. Worsthorne was at least prepared to define a bimbo: ``An obviously very attractive young girl who tends to bat her eyelids and has a very attractive frontal _ whatever the correct word is.''

DOC.HEAD: Defeat of Visa Bill Won't Help New Applicants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: AP News Analysis
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The defeat of U.S. legislation that would have helped Chinese students extend their stays in the United States is not likely to reverse China's course of tightening exit controls. The door already has closed significantly on what had been the freest period for exit from China in its 40 years of Communist rule, during which almost anyone who could get a scholarship abroad and a foreign visa was able to go. Regulations being circulated internally bar anyone under 30 or with less than five years of work experience from obtaining official sponsorship to study abroad, sources in the education bureaucracy said this week. Other measures have made it harder for students to take tests for study abroad and obtain passports without official sponsorship. Fear of its students not returning home is only one reason for China's shift in policy. More basic is the government's fear that too many students are returning with anti-socialist ideas that could undermine their hard-won Communist revolution. In September, Premier Li Peng set out the new policy: ``Henceforth, those being sent to study abroad should mainly be visiting scholars and researchers because these people are older and more mature politically.'' More than educational exchanges were at stake in the showdown between the U.S. Congress and President Bush, however. A biting front-page editorial Friday in the party newspaper, the People's Daily, said if the legislation passed, the United States ``shall be held responsible for the grave consequences.'' It called the bill a ``naked expression of power politics,'' and said its supporters were ``anti-China addicts'' who hoped to coerce China into giving up socialism. The bill would have waived a requirement the estimated 32,000 Chinese in the United States as official exchange students return home for two years before seeking new U.S. visas to work or continue study. Its goal was to protect students who feared retribution for protesting China's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in June. Both houses of Congress passed the bill in November but Bush vetoed it. The House of Representatives voted Thursday to override the veto, but the Senate's 62-37 vote Friday in favor of the bill fell four short of the necessary two-thirds margin for an override. China did not comment on the bill's defeat, although it was reported on national television and radio. Bush's veto of the bill was one of a series of conciliatory U.S. steps that halted the serious deterioration in U.S.-Chinese relations after June. After the December visit of Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, China softened its comments on dissidents Fang Lizhi and his wife, Li Shuxian, who have been hiding in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing since June. However, Bush's success in quashing the controversial bill does not guarantee a speedy solution to the Fangs' dilemma. China has little reason to push for a resolution, which would require compromise on its part. Indications are that China continues to insist the Fangs promise not to make political statements if they are allowed to go to a third country _ a promise that those who know Fang believe he will not make. Moreover, the strong support for the bill in Congress and among the American public reveal ideological tensions that will prevent bilateral relations from returning to their rosy pre-June state. Americans have been awakened to the harsher side of China's Communist rule, and Chinese leaders have stressed the need for vigilance against what they consider subversive American notions of democracy. China won't stop sending students abroad _ they are vital to its plans for absorbing advanced technology _ but it will take strenuous measures to ensure that those who go abroad are loyal socialists and return that way.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Kathy Wilhelm has reported for The Associated Press from Beijing since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Romantic, Feminine Styles Winners in Summer Couture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Romance and femininity were in the air and on the runways as top designers unveiled their summer haute couture offerings. Short skirts, curvy silhouettes, swooping decolletes and charming colors were the most striking messages in the week of shows. If the top designers have guessed right, women want to be more feminine than ever as the new decade begins. There were also plenty of well-cut pants for daytime or evening as an alternative to women who would rather hide than bare their legs. It was a roller coaster week. The grandmasters like Yves Saint Laurent, Hubert de Givenchy, Karl Lagerfeld at Chanel and new master Christian Lacroix triumphed. Paco Rabanne, a 56-year-old Spanish-born designer, won the Golden Thimble award. Having worked in Paris for nearly 40 years, Rabanne finally overcame his ``metallic sculptor'' image to receive the coveted prize awarded twice yearly by fashion writers. But things didn't go so well in houses with new couture creators drawn from the ranks of ready-to-wear. The inventive Claude Montana, who took over as Lanvin's haute couture designer, drew sullen reviews. Although purely Montana, his clothes featuring mainly skinny pants with various toppers looked too self-consciously ``futuristic'' for the moneyed set that's used to feminine clothes from Lanvin. Another flop was Angelo Tarlazzi's second collection for Guy Laroche. Although he had some zingy raffia-bordered south-of-the border stuff plus cute stitched peasant dresses and gringo pants, the show didn't quite make the couture grade. But there was much to remember elsewhere, and the beauty of couture is that each client _ and those who are inspired by couture looks _ can opt for skirt lengths longer than the sensational runway models. Who's going to wear this, wonder bemused TV spectators treated to snippets of the spectacular shows. The answer is hardly anybody. The outfits costing around $10,000 and bought by only a handful of women are mainly money-losers for the big-name houses. But the designers' renown serves to give the houses big publicity and promote sales of the real moneymakers _ perfume and cosmetics, ready-to-wear and accessories. Gossamer-light luxury fabrics made these clothes look lighter than ever, though Yves Saint Laurent won kudos for his sleek white suits in heavy pique, ridged tussore, and Shantung silk. Memorable styles included the Lolita charmers at Chanel, though most real women couldn't wear the teeny hint-of-chiffon skirts in delightful shades of coral and pink peeping under the sharply fitted long jackets. Christian Lacroix had a field day with the light fabrics, mounding clouds of organza, lace or faille on wrapped or puffed skirts under skimpy or decollete tops for his incomparable high-waisted, trapeze look of luxury. The shoulder issue is irrelevant, because Saint Laurent and Givenchy's bold-shouldered daytime silhouettes still look elegant, while at Lacroix, Chanel, Dior and elsewhere they are mainly hidden under big organza collars or discreetly small and rounded by minimal padding. As in ready-to-wear that's already appearing in the shops, the bosom is a big couture winner. Many suits or draped dresses have slashed decollete effects. And transparent blouses are around _ although far from exclusively _ for those who want see-through chic. Evening wear inevitably bares shoulders, pushing up bosoms under strapless bustiers or daring decolletes a la Belle Epoque or the 18th century look of Marie-Antoinette. Other outstanding couture offerings included Jean-Louis Scherrer's repeat trip to the fabulous India of the Raj. His jeweled, lace-embroidered light silk draped dresses or trouser outfits in white or tender pastels were an exercise in opulent beauty. Ungaro made a hit by trimming down his line to the couture basics. His line of colorful short coat-dresses and suits combining arabesques of several bright colors were a delight to the eye. Typical of the haute couture were sophisticated draped and split-skirt models in sumptuous light fabrics at Balmain by designer Erik Mortensen. Fabric trends for the new soft looks include gabardine, cashmere, raw silk and textured linen, as well as shantung, silk crepe and cotton pique for daytime to the cocktail hour. For evening, romance came out in silk faille, satin and clouds of organza and chiffon. There's also lots of delicate or heavier guipure lace, plus re-embroidery and appliqued motifs, pearls, sequins and feathers. The color palette includes lots of white and ivory, regulation spring navy and brighter peacock blues. Khaki, tobacco, desert beige and chartreuse flash into sunbursts of yellows and mandarin orange, with gleaming lashings of gold brocade and lame for evening. Pastels range from flesh tones to the most delicate eggshell pinks and blues and absinthe green. Violet, salmon, flame and fuchsia reds were outstanding in a brighter vein. To go with this couture splendor, there were all kinds of eye-catching headgear, from satin turbans to enormous circular haloes at Cardin, funny visored pillboxes and piecrust-crimped crowns at Givenchy. Chanel showed new boaters with bows under the brims, and Valentino topped many of his sophisticated models with hats that had trellis-style woven brims matching latticework on some of the dresses.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors: Attorney General, Judge Appeared on Voodoo List
With Noriega Trial
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega may have tried to put a curse on U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and the judge in his case, federal prosecutors suggested Friday at the deposed Panamanian leader's bond hearing. When invading U.S. troops raided a Noriega office now referred to as the ``Witch House'' _ a room in his headquarters at Fort Amador just outside Panama City _ they found black magic paraphernalia, including an altar. One soldier described signs of animal entrails and ``vats of blood,'' as well as a portrait of Adolf Hitler. On Friday, Deputy Assistant U.S. Attorney Myles Malman asked U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler to deny bond to Noriega because he was a danger to the community, citing among other reasons a ``white sheet of paper with four names on it'' that the troops found with the other items in the ``Witch House.'' The list consisted of Thornburgh; Charles Sapho, the head Justice Department's drug section; Mark Schnapp, a former Miami federal prosecutor partly responsible for the Noriega indictment _ and Hoeveler himself. Malman did not mention a curse, but such lists are sometimes put on altars by practitioners of voodoo-like Afro-Caribbean religions to place a hex on those named. ``Maybe I better not enter it into evidence,'' the judge joked as Malman handed him the list. Hoeveler later denied bond to Noriega.

DOC.HEAD: Louella Luhrman, Nation's Oldest Vet, Dies at 108
DOC.TEXT: Louella Luhrman, a World War I Army nurse who was described as the nation's oldest veteran, died Friday at age 108. Luhrman, who joined the Army in 1918 when she was 36 years old, spent her military service at Camp Lewis, Washington. She was discharged in 1919. ``She is going to be a great loss,'' said Jean Kohr, the head nurse at Luhrman's ward at the Veteran's Administration Hospital. ``She had a wonderful sense of humor.'' Luhrman was born in Germany on Dec. 8, 1881, and emigrated to the United States with her family two years later, coming across the Atlantic in a sailing ship. The family first settled in Marysville, Calif., but after a few years moved to the San Jose area where Luhrman was to live off and on for much of her life. ``Up until 1986, Lou heard well enough to respond directly to questions asked by reporters,'' said her niece, France Malavos. She was interviewed on Veteran's Day that year and was asked what advice she had for world leaders. ``Peace,'' she said. ``Peace at any price. One people, we belong to one people.'' Luhrman became the nation's oldest veteran in 1987 when Jasper Garrison of Illinois died at the age of 107. Garrison served in the Spanish-American War. In the nation's capital, Veterans Administration spokesman Don Smith said he did not know immediately who is now the oldest veteran. ``There are still several veterans at least 100 years old, including Nathan Cook, a Spanish-American War veteran at our hospital in Prescott, Arizona,'' said Smith. ``He's 104.'' Luhrman never married but was the aunt to nine nieces and nephews, grand-aunt to 30 and great grand-aunt to 38. She earned her nursing degree from Fabiola Hospital in Oakland in 1905 and worked there until she joined the Army, according to Holly Fletcher, spokeswoman for the Department of Veterans Affairs. Luhrman returned to Fabiola Hospital after the war and worked there until the facility closed in 1932. She then became a nurse at Peralta Hospital in Oakland from where she retired in 1943. In the 1986 interview, Luhrman attributed her long life to a balanced diet, being able to put aside worries and living life to the fullest. ``I hope people will think well of me,'' she had said. ``That's all I wish for.''

DOC.HEAD: Betty Ford Honors Bradys, Other Couple
DOC.TEXT: Former first lady Betty Ford honored former White House press secretary James Brady, his wife, Sarah, and a second couple for using their experiences with adversity to help others. Mrs. Ford on Friday presented the Bradys and Kirk and Karen Ball of Aurora with the first Betty Ford awards at a ceremony in Beaver Creek, where Mrs. Ford and former President Gerald Ford own a home. ``It is gratifying to be involved with an award that recognizes the inner strength of individuals and their selflessness in aiding others,'' said Mrs. Ford, whose Betty Ford Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif., treats chemical dependency. The Bradys were honored for their efforts to gain passage of national handgun control legislation. James Brady, 49, was shot in the head during an assassination attempt on President Reagan in 1981. Brady remains partially paralyzed. Mrs. Brady is vice chairman of Handgun Control Inc., a citizens' group that lobbies for passage of federal legislation to place tighter controls on handguns. Kirk Ball, 31, and his wife, Karen, 32, have a 4-year-old daughter, Kaelin, who was born with a port-wine stain on both sides of her face. Doctors told the Balls the stain is a symptom of a rare, progressive disease known as Sturge-Weber Syndrome. Other symptoms include eye problems, seizures, partial paralysis and even mental retardation. They started the Sturge-Weber Foundation to help other parents learn more about the disease and to encourage research. The foundation now has more than 300 members worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Superintendent of Pennsylvania Prison Fired
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Freeman was...,' with 2 grafs to add background on investigation.
DOC.TEXT: The suspended superintendent of the Camp Hill prison was fired Friday for his actions during a three-day riot last year that left 123 people injured and more than half the institution in ruins. The dismissals of Superintendent Robert Freeman and one of his deputies were based on a recommendation by Gov. Robert P. Casey, who said Friday that Freeman was among the officials with primary responsibility for maintaining order. Casey concluded that ``those having responsibility for security ... (should) be held accountable for their actions.'' Three days of rioting at Camp Hill in October left 123 inmates, officers and firefighters injured and caused an estimated $14 million in damage. Administrators declared the prison secure after a first night of rioting Oct. 25, but inmates were able to free themselves and continued their rampage through Oct. 27. On Nov. 1, just days after the rioting ended, The Associated Press reported that guards had complained that prison officials ignored warnings of cell-locking mechanisms being broken after the first night of rioting on Oct. 25. Freeman was suspended without pay the same day. Attempts to reach him for comment on his firing were unsuccessful because his telephone number is unlisted. Also fired was Camp Hill's deputy for operations, Robert Smith, said Corrections Department spokesman Kenneth Robinson. The spokesman said the dismissals were ordered by state Prison Commissioner David S. Owens Jr. on the governor's recommendation. Terry Henry, Camp Hill's deputy for treatment, will be reassigned within the department, Robinson said. The governor said he would have recommended the dismissal of Maj. John Stover, captain of the guard, but Stover had resigned. In a news release, Casey cited the findings of an independent three-member investigative commission that concluded management at Camp Hill had failed to adequately search the prison after the first night of rioting. Management also failed to assure that cells were locked despite warnings that they weren't secure, the commission found. The commission, which presented its report in December, also said that supervisory personnel had failed to keep an adequate force of state troopers at the prison to prevent a second night of rioting, and that ample time was available for management to reconsider its decisions. The panel criticized Owens, the prison commissioner, for his ``hands-off'' dealing with the riots, but the governor said he had confidence in Owens. ``The commission recognized that direct and primary responsibility for the security at Camp Hill did not rest with him,'' Casey said. ``I have concluded that Commissioner Owens carried out his responsibilities in a competent and professional manner.'' Robinson said acting Superintendent Jeffrey Beard would remain in place at the prison.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Say Bush Fighting Drugs With Words, Not Money
DOC.TEXT: Big-city mayors, disappointed with President Bush's anti-drug efforts, are asking the administration and Congress to cut defense spending and raise taxes to finance solutions for inner-city problems. The U.S. Conference of Mayors ended its three-day winter meeting Friday after the president urged them to support his new drug strategy and proposal to increase federal anti-narcotics drug spending by $1.1 billion. But the mayors had more money in mind, and the group's policy-making executive committee adopted a resolution urging the immediate use of a ``peace dividend, in conjuction with increased revenues,'' for an injection of new aid for America's cities. ``The Bush administration's approach is to force the poor people to decide between heating and eating,'' said Newark, N.J., Mayor Sharpe James, a Democrat. ``I think they need both.'' The resolution was proposed by Madison, Wis., Mayor Paul Soglin. It repeats the mayors' longstanding call for more federal taxes to finance urban needs. It adds the so-called peace dividend, saying the lessening of world tensions and crumbling of communism in Eastern Europe should leave military money available for such pressing domestic needs as poverty, homelessness, AIDS and drugs. New York Mayor David Dinkins, in backing the proposal, said: ``The `peace dividend' is not the entire answer, but it is a good start. A mere 5 percent savings in defense spending will yield $15 billion that could be used for much-needed urban programs.'' Bush appealed to the overwhelmingly Democratic Conference of Mayors one day after unveiling his revised plan for fighting drugs. He offered the mayors no specifics and no other initiatives on urban problems. He repeated his call for more private efforts, pledging to use his ``bully pulpit'' to ask for volunteers. ``Let's join hands to inspire the millions of Americans who want to help America get clean and stay clean,'' he said. ``Together, let's defeat public enemy No. 1.'' But some mayors questioned whether the administration was really making drugs its top priority and faulted Bush for failing to provide enough money to make drug rehabilitation treatment available to any drug user who wants it. ``We have not yet seen a level of commitment in line with the size of the problem,'' said Mayor Kathyrn Whitmire of Houston, president of the conference and the elected leader of Bush's adopted hometown. ``We have not yet seen it move to the top of the agenda in the federal government.'' Mayors interviewed after the speech said they appreciated the symbolic support his appearance provided but that Bush had offered the cities little that was new. ``I guess you have to give the president a `B' for showing up,'' said Boston Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, a Democrat. ``I think there is strong disagreement as to how to proceed to address some of the issues of urban America that have been ignored for such a long period of time,'' he said. ``I like what he said about education,'' said Mayor Karen Vialle of Tacoma, Wash. ``But we need the bucks to do it.'' Whitmire, however, said city officials believe the Bush administration is more receptive to the mayors than President Reagan was. Reagan never addressed the Conference of Mayors in his eight years as president. ``I think his presence here indicates a little more willinginess to discuss those disagreements and see if something can be worked out,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Sing-along bandleader Mitch Miller has been named principal pops conductor of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra. Miller, who feuded with the Rochester Philharmonic this year after several decades as guest conductor, will conduct at least 10 concerts for the Buffalo orchestra. ``They've put me completely in charge _ budget, choosing of artists,'' the Rochester native said Friday. ``They've given me an absolutely free hand as long as I stay within the budget.'' Buffalo Philharmonic President Harry Stainrook said Miller's presence would bring in an additional $100,000 to the orchestra, which has been in financial difficulty in recent months.

A group of disgruntled residents of this desert resort city has abandoned a recall effort against Mayor Sonny Bono. Ron Winkler, a member of Save Palm Springs, said the recall ``basically just died out.'' One group member said more than 2,000 signatures had been gathered _ about half the number needed to trigger a special election. The group accused Bono, 54, of using the office to revive a flagging show business career, among other things. ``We thought Sonny Bono was a joke when we started and he is still a joke,'' said Dick Sroda, another member of Save Palm Springs. ``At the present time, he is laying a little low, which is good. ``I think the campaigning for signatures had some effect on him. He seems to be a little more conscious of the people.'' Bono, who has started a film festival and championed other efforts to revitalize the city's image, could not be reached by telephone at City Hall after business hours on Friday. The songwriter and nightclub singer was teamed for years with his ex-wife, Cher.

Grammy-winning singer Anita Baker has bought the mansion that for 75 years housed Little Harry's Restaurant, but she plans to use the building to turn out a different sort of platter. Baker, who turned 32 Friday, and her husband, Walter Bridgforth Jr., purchased the property for an undisclosed amount from the Phillips family, who had owned the building since 1956, the Detroit Free Press reported Friday. The Grosse Pointe Woods couple are expected to convert the restaurant to a recording studio. Baker's 1986 album, ``Rapture,'' had three hit singles and won the singer two Grammy awards.

Sheik Mohammed al-Fassi's bayfront mansion was invaded by police, prosecutors and Humane Society investigators who seized dozens of cats suspected of being mistreated, police said. About 30 cats found roaming the grounds of the sheik's ``Al Shams'' Palace on Biscayne Bay were loaded into crates and cardboard carriers Thursday and turned over to the Humane Society, Miami Beach police spokesman Tom Hoolahan said. ``It was for purposes of protecting the animals,'' Hoolahan said Friday. Last year, al-Fassi launched a one-man campaign to save the homeless cats of the world, inviting people to drop off unwanted felines at his luxury home. An aide to the sheik, Talaat Reafat, denied the cats had been mistreated. The sheik, who faces a warrant for his arrest because he owes $80,000 in back alimony to his ex-wife and unpaid legal fees to some of his former attorneys, has not been home since November, Hoolahan said.

An Internal Revenue Service auction of property belonging to comedian Redd Foxx was set for today, but a judge delayed the sale for a month. U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Clive Jones issued a 30-day stay on Friday despite protests by IRS attorneys and auctioneer Robert Deiro. Deiro said ``hundreds of people are descending on the city'' from as far away as Asia for the sale. He said Foxx would suffer from the delay because many who planned to attend today's sale would not return. ``I feel Mr. Foxx has shot himself in the foot,'' Deiro said. Foxx's lawyer, Paul Whitford, told the court that the sale would conflict with the interests of the bankruptcy court. Whitford said the issue was ``whether provisions of the bankruptcy code override provisions of the IRS code.'' Foxx, who filed for Chapter 11 protection from bankruptcy in 1983, owes the IRS $900,000 in back taxes, penalties and interest. He was not at the hearing. The IRS in November seized more than 400 items, including his Las Vegas home, antique cars, furniture and dozens of pieces of jewelry. Foxx gained his widest audience playing a junk dealer on the 1972-77 TV series ``Sanford and Son.''

Vocalist Tone Loc has been rapped with a lawsuit from his cousin, who says he served as the entertainer's manager and alleges breach of contract and fraud, according to court records. Filed by Greg Jessie in county Superior Court on Thursday, it alleges that Tone Loc denies any ``binding contractual obligation to pay management fees.'' The lawsuit said such a contract was signed in late 1987. The contract calls for Jessie to be paid 20 percent of the first $1,000 in gross earnings and 15 percent of all other earnings, according to the suit. A telephone call seeking comment at the office of Marty Schwartz, the rap artist's personal manager, was not answered after business hours Friday. Tone Loc has recorded a number of hit rap songs, including ``Wild Thing'' and ``Funky Cold Medina.'' He is earning more than $1 million annually, Jessie's suit claims.

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Repays $11,000 To Senate For Condo Reimbursements
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Dave Durenberger repaid $11,005 to the Senate on Friday, returning money he received from the government to make payments on a Minneapolis condominium, the Minnesota Republican said in a statement. Durenberger said he was notified by the Senate Rules Committee on Thursday that he was not entitled to the money because it was paid from October 1983 to November 1989 at times when the Senate was not in session. It was the latest bad news for Durenberger. The Senate Ethics Committee also is investigating him for arrangements involving his Minneapolis condominium, in addition to a book deal and lobbyist-paid trips to Boston. He's scheduled to go before the Ethics Committee next month. He has apologized to Minnesotans for what he said were mistakes and lapses in judgement but has denied any wrongdoing. Two recent statewide polls show that Durenberger's popularity has plummeted since the investigation began last year, and as many as 76 percent of Minnesota adults want Durenberger to resign if the Ethics Committee finds significant ethics violations. The senator said he asked the Rules Committee in December to review his receiving per diem reimbursements for daily rental payments for the Minneapolis condominium, which he uses when on official business in Minnesota. The committee ruled he was not entitled to reimbursements for daily expenses while using the condo during August recesses and recesses between congressional sessions in the years 1983-89, Durenberger said. ``This is a first-ever ruling,'' the senator said. ``In nearly seven years of submitting these expenses for reimbursement ... I have never been notified by either the Senate Disbursing Office or the Senate Rules Committee audit staff that the expenses where not reimbursable.'' The Associated Press was unable Friday night to contact Rules Committee staff members Friday night to confirm whether it was a first-time ruling. Durenberger said he calculated that the total amount of reimbursements received for per diem expenses during those recesses was $11,005, and he submitted a check for that amount to the Financial Clerk of the U.S. Senate. ``When there is an official determination of the amount of interest that is due, I will also pay that,'' he said in the statement. Because his condo in McLean, Va., is considered his usual place of residence during congressional sessions, Durenberger can claim expense reimbursement for time spent at the Minneapolis condominium during sessions, said Carrie Collins, his press secretary.

DOC.HEAD: Former Teacher Finds Success on National Radio
LaserPhoto RAC1
DOC.TEXT: Many of the 250,000 listeners who tune in to Michael Feldman's nationwide ``Whad'ya Know?'' program Saturday mornings on American Public Radio beg to hear about his personal life. But he's not talking about that anymore. ``Do you bother your minister or rabbi with that question?'' Feldman shot back at a caller on a recent show who asked how Feldman spends his time when he's not on the air. ``When I first started, I talked about my divorce,'' said Feldman, who said such talk was therapeutic. ``Now I figure it's none of their business. ``You have to save some for yourself.'' The 40-year-old bespectacled Feldman, known for his dry, off-beat humor, started ``Whad'ya Know?'' in 1985 after working as a high school English teacher and experimenting with other radio jobs. The program has developed a loyal following. It airs on 103 stations. ``He's one of the most popular radio personalities on American Public Radio,'' said Dan Jensen, APR's marketing director in St. Paul, Minn. ``Whad'ya Know?'' airs before a live audience and features music, a call-in quiz and the ``Town of the Week,'' a feature in which a town _ chosen by throwing a dart at a map _ is critiqued. Serious subjects are off limits on Feldman's show. Instead, the host prefers to ponder callers' questions like, ``If prunes are dried plums, where does prune juice come from?'' and ``Do radio show hosts get dressing rooms?'' ``Not this one,'' Feldman replied to the latter query during a recent show. ``I come dressed.'' Feldman said he hosts the show because it's fun and he only has to go to his Madison office twice a week. ``I'm very lazy,'' conceded Feldman, who spends much of his free time researching questions for the show's quiz or just ``doing nothing.'' ``I hate working for a living,'' he said. ``My main concern was doing something fun.'' Feldman's growing popularity has earned him a chance to take his wit, quizzes and other innovations on national television. The Disney Channel will air four taped segments of ``Whad'ya Know?'' in March. He said he presently makes ``as much money as a bad lawyer,'' but if the television debut proves succesful his salary could jump to that of ``an average lawyer.'' He began working odd jobs in radio in 1977 but his first big shot came in 1984 when he was hired for a show at WGN in Chicago. But he and his co-host clashed and both were fired. When the offer to host ``Whad'ya Know?'' came in 1985, Feldman was reluctant to leave Chicago. ``I wanted to stay and get my revenge,'' he quipped. But he went, and his show now is heard around the nation _ including back in Chicago, where Feldman recently did a live remote show that drew a sellout crowd of 1,300. ``I'm surprised sometimes at the dedication people tell me about,'' he said. ``I'm a little embarrassed by it all, but I'm glad for it.'' His show is usually aired from Madison and people sometimes arrive two hours early to get a seat. ``We have enjoyed Michael Feldman's zig-zag humor for more than 10 years,'' said Sandra Larson, who has been attending Feldman's show with her husband since the days he broadcast from the Madison diner. ``He's refreshing,'' she said. ``He has that sort of boyish charm that lets people open up.'' Feldman doesn't spend a lot of time pondering his future. ``I have an internal unattainable level of success,'' he said. ``In some ways I think it's morally wrong to want to be successful. But on the other hand, I don't want to fail because I've done that and it's not fun.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Propose $7 Billion Military Budget Increase
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is proposing $303.3 billion for defense in a new budget that would increase spending for the Strategic Defense Initiative and calls for five B-2 stealth bombers, say congressional sources and Pentagon documents. The budget plan, to be released formally on Monday, also would cut military personnel by 38,000, fund two land-based nuclear missiles and cancel a number of weapons programs, including another attempt to scrap the Marine Corps' V-22 Osprey aircraft. The plan would add $7 billion to the military budget, bringing it to $303.3 billion for the 1991 fiscal year _ a 2.4 percent increase from this year's $296.3 billion but about 2 percent less than what the Pentagon would need to keep pace with inflation. The figure includes $292.1 billion for Pentagon spending, up from $286.8 billion, with the rest representing Energy Department spending for nuclear programs, according to documents made available to The Associated Press Friday by congressional sources. Total budget authority for the military in the year beginning Oct. 1 would be $306.9 billion, up from $301.6 billion, also including Energy Department money. The budget figures come amid dramatic changes in Eastern Europe, where nations are pushing towards democracy, and administration officials concede the Soviet threat has lessened. ``This budget represents the first steps in responding to changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, as well as tighter budget constraints,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said in comments included in the documents. The budget total for SDI _ commonly known as Star Wars _ is $4.5 billion in Pentagon spending. Adding approximately $300 million in Energy Department money, the program would get $4.8 billion. The total is a $1 billion increase over what Congress approved last year and reflects ``strong support for a vigorous SDI program that includes the `brilliant pebbles' technology for space-based interceptors,'' the Pentagon said. Brilliant pebbles is a system composed of many small ground- and space-based interceptors that would sense enemy ballistic missiles. The interceptors would ram the missiles, causing them to explode. A number of Democrats in Congress question the system and favor long-term research on directed energy weapons. The budget proposal also includes $5.5 billion for five B-2 bombers, the radar-evading, bat-winged aircraft that has come under attack on Capitol Hill for its high price of about $530 million apiece. Last year, Congress gave the Bush administration two of the three bombers it sought and this year's total of five is certain to be attacked. Another thorny issue is the administration's plan to fund two land-based nuclear missiles _ the singled-warhead Midgetman and the multiple-warhead MX missile. The budget proposal calls for $202 million for the Midgetman and $2.8 billion for the MX. Among the other high-priced, strategic programs in the budget is $1.5 billion for one Trident submarine and $1.7 billion for 52 Trident II nuclear missiles. The budget also includes plans to mothball two battleships, the USS New Jersey and the USS Iowa, and cancellations of various weapons programs, some of which were on the chopping block last year. Among the programs terminated are the Marine Corps' V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft, the Navy's F-14D jet fighter, the Phoenix and Maverick missiles, the Apache helicopter, the Army Helicopter Improvement Program (AHIP), the F-15E fighter and the M-1 tank. Congress last year rejected the administration's attempt to eliminate the Osprey. The budget calls for a reduction in active troop strength by 38,000 from nearly 2.1 million and cuts in civilian forces of 5,000 and reserves by 3,000. At the Pentagon, a senior administration official said the spending would represent a decline in purchasing power after inflation is taken into account. ``It means that we will be able to buy fewer planes, tanks, and ships, and support fewer troops,'' said the official, who spoke only on condition he not be named.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Declares 28 more counties eligible for emergency loans
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter designated 28 more Florida counties disaster areas Friday as a result of the Christmas weekend freeze. Yeutter's three-page letter to Florida Gov. Bob Martinez makes farmers in those regions eligible for Farmers Home Administration loan assistance. The counties are: Brevard, Charlotte, Citrus, De Soto, Flagler, Glades, Hardee, Hernando, Highlands, Hillsborough, Indian River, Lake, Manatee, Marion, and Martin. Also, Okeechobee, Orange, Osceola, Pasco, Pinellas, Polk, Putnam, St. Johns, St. Lucie, Sarasota, Seminole, Sumter and Volusia. ``Everyone in Florida was affected by the freeze, some worse than others,'' said Jon Peck, press secretary for Martinez. ``But it's gratifying to know that those farmers in the counties most severly affected will get some assistance.'' President Bush earlier declared Broward, Collier, Dade, Hendry, Lee, Monroe and Palm Beach counties as major disaster areas due to damage from the freezing conditions that blitzed Florida Dec. 23-25.

DOC.HEAD: Watkins Drops Plan to Build New Nuclear Weapons Plant
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department is dropping plans to build a plutonium refinery in Idaho that the Reagan administration had called essential to modernizing the nuclear weapons complex, according to department sources. The decision reflects the Bush administration's reconsideration of nuclear arms priorities in light of democratic reforms in Eastern Europe and domestic budget pressures. The decision to end financing for the Special Isotope Separation plant, planned for construction at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory near Idaho Falls, will be part of the fiscal 1991 budget President Bush sends to Congress Monday, according to sources who spoke Friday on condition of anonymity. The plant was expected to cost at least $1.2 billion. But $400 million already has been spent on design and related work and construction has not started. Just 13 months ago, in an official blueprint for modernizing the nuclear arms production complex, the Reagan administration called the Idaho project ``time-critical and essential.'' It was to have been the first new atomic weapon plant since the N reactor, which produced plutonium at the Hanford nuclear reservation near Richland, Wash., was put into operation 27 years ago. The project's refining technology, which uses lasers to vaporize plutonium so that it can be used in nuclear warheads, has been criticized as unduly hazardous by environmental groups. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins strongly backed the Idaho project in congressional testimony early last year but has been reconsidering for several months. Phil Hamric, manager of the Energy Department's Idaho field office, declined to confirm the decision. The department announced Friday, however, that it had indefinitely postponed a series of public hearings that would form part of the foundation for a study of the environmental impact of a prototype for the Idaho plutonium refinery. The postponement, which was not explained by the department, apparently resulted from Watkins' decision to drop the Idaho project. Watkins had announced last year that the department would prepare an environmental impact report on plutonium refining experiments with the prototype, which is at Livermore, Calif. The hearings were to have been held Feb. 2 and 3 at Livermore and Feb. 7 at Idaho Falls. On Wednesday, Sens. James McClure and Steve Symms, Republicans of Idaho, issued a joint statement saying they expected the 1991 budget to contain no money for the project. Both were strong supporters of the project. ``If what we have learned is correct, it appears that there will be zero funding in the budget for construction'' of the plant, the senators said, adding that they accepted the decision ``based upon a variety of global developments and budgetary issues.'' The Snake River Alliance, a Boise-based environmental group, said they interpreted the Idaho senators' statement as meaning the project was dead. ``We believe that construction funds for this porkbarrel relic of the Cold War will never be seen in the federal budget again,'' said Elizabeth Paul, the group's executive director. In a related development Friday, the Energy Department announced it was replacing the manager of the troubled Rocky Flats plutonium processing plant near Denver, which has been closed since November to review management and safety procedures. Watkins said Robert M. Nelson Jr., deputy manager of the department's Nevada field office in Las Vegas, would take over at Rocky Flats for David P. Simonson, who will move to the deputy manager's slot there.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Bond; Defense Says Noriega a POW
LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega must remain in jail despite his claim that he is a prisoner of war and should be moved to a neutral country, a judge ruled. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler's decision on Friday came after prosecutors portrayed the fallen Panamanian ruler as a wealthy and dangerous man with cash and armed supporters potentially hidden around the world. ``Mr. Noriega is a danger to the community,'' said Deputy Assistant U.S. Attorney Myles Malman said during the bond hearing. ``He is a military man trained and skilled in the use of counter-terrorism, covert actions and weapons.'' Prosecutors said the 145-year sentence Noriega could be given if convicted of drug trafficking, coupled with his ``extraordinary wealth,'' made it likely he would flee the country if released on bond. Investigators and U.S. troops who invaded Panama found up to $30 million in Noriega assets, including homes in Panama, a condominium in France, sports cars and bank accounts, Malman said. On Noriega's ranch, soldiers found envelopes marked ``Confidential for my general,'' and stuffed with $5.8 million in cash, he said. But defense attorney Frank Rubino insisted the court has no jurisdiction in Noriega's case, and refused to participate in the bond hearing. ``To the best of my knowledge, this is the first time the United States has invaded a country, toppled its government and put its leader on trial,'' Rubino said outside the courthouse. Rubino told the judge that a letter from Noriega to President Bush was delivered Friday to the White House and the State Department claiming status as a prisoner of war under the Geneva Convention. The defense contended that an international tribunal, perhaps the World Court at The Hague or Geneva, must automatically be invoked by Noriega's alleged POW status. Hoeveler did not consider the motion immediately. Prosecutors emphasized Noriega's alleged dark side in their effort to keep him in jail, saying he was known for torturing opponents and personally ordered the execution of the leader of the failed October coup attempt against him. They also said soldiers found the names of the four people on a sheet of paper in Noriega's Fort Amador office, which contained so much black magic paraphernalia U.S. soldiers called it the ``Witch House.'' Malman implied that the list was part of a curse against the four men _ the judge himself; U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh; Charles Saphos, head of the Justice Department's drug section; and Mark Schnapp, a former Miami federal prosecutor who helped bring about the Noriega indictment. ``Maybe I better not enter it into evidence,'' the judge joked. Malman said Noriega, 51, has a $400,000 condominum in Paris and a $500,000 three-story home in Panama. The prosecution introduced photos of deposit slips showing that Noriega's 17-year-old daughter deposited $1.3 million in Panamanian banks in September 1989. The U.S. government also has frozen $20 million in Noriega assets scattered in bank accounts. The prosecution maintained that Noriega also transferred about $19 million from an account in London to one in Luxembourg after the indictment was unsealed. It was unclear whether the deposits and seizures were duplicated in the prosecution's listings. In addition to those sums, Noriega was said to have friends in countries at odds with the United States, including Cuba and Libya. He noted that Moammar Gadhafi had presented Noriega with ``his and hers Gadhafi watches.'' Asked by Hoeveler at the end of the session if he wished to rebut prosecution arguments, Rubino replied by reciting Noriega's name, rank and serial number _ 0001.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Sir Arthur Slug, a bulldog with a bent for betting, has picked the Denver Broncos over the San Francisco 49ers in Sunday's Super Bowl. Slug's predictions are nothing to sniff at, according to owner Frank Dunn. The 100-pound oddsmaker was right 18 games out of 23 Dunn had his dog call this season. ``I write the name of each team playing on a separate piece of paper. Then I put dog food on both pieces of paper,'' said Dunn, 40, a part-time bartender who lives in this Pittsburgh suburb. ``Whichever one he eats off of is the team I bet on. Of course, I have to grab the other pile of dog food real fast before he eats both of them.'' Dunn said he seeks his pet's advice only on professional football games because he doesn't want the 2-year-old Slug to turn into a compulsive gambler. ``I guess one of the reasons he's so smart is that he's pedigreed. He cost me $700, but I've been winning all that back,'' Dunn said.

Jackaroos and Jillaroos who are fair dinkum are sidling up to Elko's billabongs trying their hands at being spruikers instead of ringers and drovers. That's the Australian version of events at the sixth annual Cowboy Poetry Gathering that winds up today in this town between Reno and Salt Lake City. What the Aussies mean is that male and female ranch hands who are the real thing are going to Elko watering holes to become reciters of poetry instead of cowboys. Six balladeers from Down Under joined some 70 American cowboy poets from 16 Western states in this year's celebration of poetry readings. Cowboy poetry was spawned around nighttime campfires on the open range. ``I think people will be surprised to find (Australians) basically have a parallel tradition to our cowboy poetry tradition,'' said Hal Cannon, co-founder of the Elko event. ``They have a similar stockman tradition and their history of settling the Outback is similar to our settling the West.'' Elko declared Friday Australia Day in honor of the first European settlers who landed in Sydney on Jan. 26, 1788. In celebration, the Elko High School band played ``The Star Spangled Banner'' and a version of Australia's national song, ``Waltzing Matilda,'' written by bush poet Andrew Barton ``Banjo'' Patterson. More than 7,000 people were expected to visit Elko, population 25,000, through the weekend to hear the lyrical tales.

DOC.HEAD: After More Than Half a Century, Hawkins Calls End to Era
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Augustus F. Hawkins, one of the last New Deal-era liberal Democrats still in office, is retiring after pressing to help the needy during his 27 years in Congress. ``Maybe I can do a better job calling attention to my concerns on the outside than on the inside,'' the 82-year-old chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee said in an interview after announcing he would not seek re-election next November. Hawkins, the longest-serving black in Congress, said he made the decision Thursday night with his wife and did not consult with party leaders before making the announcement Friday. He said he considered retiring before but ``there was always another project, another bill I wanted to see passed, so I just kept going on.'' Hawkins has represented the primarily black and Hispanic Watts area of Los Angeles and surrounding Hispanic suburbs since 1963, when he became the first black elected to Congress from California. Before that he had been a member of the state legislature since 1934. In 1984, he replaced the late Rep. Carl D. Perkins, D-Ky., as chairman of the education and labor panel. His most likely successor as the panel's chairman is Rep. William D. Ford, D-Mich. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., who chairs the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, called Hawkins ``a tireless champion of a better and fairer America.'' ``Few, if any, members of Congress have done more over the past quarter century to fulfill the nation's commitment to those who need our help the most,'' Kennedy said. Narrowing the disparity between rich and poor has always been the focus of Hawkins' agenda. A year after entering Congress, he co-authored the 1964 Civil Rights Act's Title VII, which created the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and mandated fair employment practices. In 1978 he was the co-author with the late Sen. Hubert Humphrey of the Humphrey-Hawkins full employment bill, which officially targets an unemployment rate of 4 percent as the nation's goal. But for most of the past decade, Hawkins was forced into a role of tilting at windmills as a critic of the so-called Reagan Revolution. The adamant liberal with a 100 percent favorable voting record from the AFL-CIO six of the past eight years has often taken a pragmatic approach in forging alliances with conservatives to advance his agenda. In 1982, he worked with Dan Quayle, then a conservative Republican senator from Indiana, and Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, to assure unions and community activist groups a voice in allocating wage subsidies to businesses under the Job Training Partnership Act. ``I never tried to play the role of superstar, that's just not my nature,'' Hawkins said Friday. ``My approach has always been to get some tangible results. You can't let your ego stand in the way.'' Last year, he and Hatch joined to emphasize early, school-based education for 3- and 4-year-olds as part of a multibillion-dollar child care bill that remains stymied because of opposition from Bush and conservative Democrats. Hawkins said he fears a compromise may produce ``two systems, one in which the poor will go to inferior care facilities and the wealthy will be able to take care of their own children.'' Hawkins complained that Bush, while touting himself as the ``education president,'' has consistently opposed appropriating the money needed to carry out an $8.3 billion school improvement act that Hawkins wrote and former President Reagan signed two years ago. ``It's the same old story: There's just no money,'' he said. ``If we only implemented that law as it should be, education would be at the top of the agenda. Instead, we're moving in just the opposite direction, fooling around with fads.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Decry Bush Plan on VA Home Loans
With PM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The chairmen of the two congressional committees that oversee veterans affairs say they will fight a Bush administration proposal to require down payments on veterans home loans. ``I'm not going to buy that,'' Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee said when details of the proposal were disclosed Friday in advance of President Bush's release of the fiscal 1991 budget. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., chairman of the Senate veterans' panel, added he would ``strongly oppose all changes in the fundamental nature of this important veterans benefit.'' The lawmakers applauded, however, the administration's request to boost health care spending for veterans to $12.3 billion. Health care is the most expensive service provided to the nation's 27 million veterans, especially as that population ages. The budget, details of which were obtained in advance of the formal Monday presentation to Congress, will propose $31 billion overall spending for the Department of Veterans' Affairs in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The appropriation for this fiscal year totaled $11.5 billion for health care, $743 million more than President had asked for. The budget supports a health care staff of nearly 195,000. The down payment proposal would cover loans of more than $25,000, essentially all new loans since the average under the program is $70,000. The $25,000 loans generally are made for home improvements. According to the veterans department, 178,000 guaranteed loans will be closed in this fiscal year. VA borrowers may make a form of ``down payment'' in order to bring the loan down to an amount they can afford, or if the home purchase should exceed $184,000. According to Warren Lasko, executive vice president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, 70 percent of VA loans have no down payment. Lasko said the proposal is part of an attempt that began in the Reagan administration to ``throttle'' the program, but the down payment proposal is a ``new wrinkle.'' ``If the 4 percent proposed down payment to the VA home loan above $25,000 is part of the budget, it represents a drastic change in the very concept and intent of the 45-year-old VA home loan program,'' said Larry W. Rivers, executive director of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. He called it an ``unreasonable, an unfair proposal, which dashes the dreams of countless veterans of participating in the American dream of home ownership.'' Lasko said he was equally disturbed by a proposal to raise the mortgage indemnity fund fee for borrowers to 1.75 percent of the mortgage from 1.25 percent. That fee, which took effect this month to provide a new fund to insure against bad mortgages, replaces a 1 percent borrowers fee that went to the VA. ``It's a standard user fee story'' comparable to the Social Security, airport and highway trust funds, Lasko said. Critics say the government uses those funds to finance the deficit. Veterans organizations were not happy with the health care increase, arguing $13.4 billion is needed to keep services in line with 1988 levels. But Cranston and Montgomery were satisfied. Montgomery said the proposal for health care funding was ``fair and realistic'' and ``one of the best we've seen in years.''

DOC.HEAD: Cavazos: `I Know I'm the Right Person for This Job'
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos is trying to put aside rumors of his imminent departure, declaring ``I'm the right person for the job.'' ``Never once, never once has the president expressed dissatisfaction at the way I'm doing my job or the quality of work that is coming out of this department,'' Cavazos said Friday. ``The day the president says, `Pack it up, it's done,' I'll say, `Yes, Mr. President.''' The education secretary said in an interview with the cable television network The Learning Channel that he was disappointed by criticism about his low-key management style and his distaste for publicity. ``If this secretary of education can move this nation into thinking about what it must do in the coming decade about education, what difference does it make whether you have someone who shouts, yells, screams and tears their shirt?'' Cavazos said. ``I expect them to understand what I'm saying rather than worrying about style. Style gets you nowhere. If shouting and carrying on is what they want, they got the wrong person for the job, ...'' he said. ``But I know I'm the right person for this job.'' Criticism of Cavazos focuses on his unwillingness to argue for raising federal education spending and to use his office as a ``bully pulpit,'' as did his flamboyant predecessor, William Bennett. Since his first day in office, Cavazos' professorial style, which he said evolved through many years as dean of a medical school and president of Texas Tech University, has been compared with that of Bennett. Cavazos said improving America's schools is a massive project that includes giving parents a choice of where to send their children to school, allowing local officials to manage their own affairs and using alternative methods to certify some teachers. ``In order to bring this about it means a total restructuring of the educational process,'' said Cavazos.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News, Unions Gear Up for Contract Talks
DOC.TEXT: The picture at New York's Picture Newspaper is not pretty _ a cost-cutting management is set to take on the unions in negotiations that could decide the fate of the Daily News. Contracts with the paper's 10 unions expire March 30. Despite protests from the unions that they have no intention to strike, News executives have done little to hide their extensive preparations to handle a walkout. John T. Sloan, the News' vice president of human resources, called it ``the most critical negotiations in our history.'' ``The fundamental issue in these contract negotiations revolves around the survival of the New York Daily News ... because over the last 10 years we have lost over $115 million in over $4 billion in revenue,'' he said. Sloan said the paper wants to cut ``labor abuses that exist in our contracts,'' and has submitted proposals to two unions that would cut manpower, reduce insurance coverage, freeze wages, remove foremen from the union and eliminate seniority rights except for vacations. The unions are placing equal emphasis on the negotiations. Theodore Kheel, the unions' adviser, said it was of ``critical importance ... to the whole labor movement.'' The unions have been unreceptive to Daily News proposals. ``If they need relief, let them come up to the bargaining tables like men and say to us where they need the relief,'' said Michael Alvino, president of the Newspaper and Mail Delivers union. ``If there's waste, let them prove where the waste is.'' Both sides acknowledge that the Daily News, founded in 1919, needs to replace aging machinery with automated equipment and color presses. Both sides know that the News _ which still sells more newspapers than any other locally circulated, general interest newspaper in America _ has lost readers. The News once sold more than 2 million papers a day; it now sells 1.2 million weekdays and 1.4 million on Sundays. Analysts say the three-tabloid city _ the New York Post and New York Newsday are the other two _ can support only one or two. And both labor and management know that advertising is harder to come by as many of the city's big department stores closed in recent years. The concord ends there. The unions claim the real goal of the News' Chicago-based parent, the Tribune Co., is to sell the paper _ something it tried to do in 1982 _ or fold it. News officials deny it. The News said it wants to spend $300 million to $500 million on plants and equipment to replace machinery more than 30 years old. But labor leaders say the company already has reneged on a 1987 promise that if the unions made concessions of $30 million, it would invest $300 million in plants and presses. Sloan said that pledge was never made. The two sides even dispute whether the newspaper is losing money. Edward Atorino, an analyst for Salomon Brothers, said the News has made a marginal profit of a few million dollars in recent years. But he said that is not enough: the News must streamline its operations, build a new plant and get rid of inefficiencies in its labor contracts. ``Before the Tribune Co. starts writing some checks, they want to get a return for their money. Otherwise, they will keep it in the bank,'' he said. ``If you look at the last two or three years, the newspaper business has had very good economic periods and many newspapers have made a lot of money. The News hasn't. Why? Because the costs are too high.'' Management's preparation for strife includes the hiring of two law firms that unions regard as union busters. The News also has put up reinforced glass, blocked off its composing room with a doorway and issued new card keys to employees that limit their access to areas they once could enter freely. The newspaper bought 22 acres in North Bergen, N.J., and said it intended to use it and 39 acres in Syosset, N.Y., for future expansion. But the unions say buildings on the New Jersey acreage have been used to train people on News machinery and would serve as a barbed wire-enclosed enclave protecting a makeshift newsroom during the strike. The News acknowledged that training has taken place there, but said no more. The News' success in weathering a strike would depend on whether deliverers worked; despite an enticing News proposal that would make the drivers into independent operators who could make up to $250,000 a year, drivers leader Alvino insisted that ``my union will stick.'' ``The New York Daily News wants a strike and we have no intentions of getting suckered into that,'' Alvino said. ``We will negotiate, negotiate, negotiate. We have no intentions of putting our people in the streets.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge OKs Drug Testing for 19 White House Workers
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has lifted a ban on drug testing for 19 employees in the Executive Office of the President who have ``top secret'' security clearances, but has continued to bar the tests for 10 others with ``secret'' clearances. The employees have filed a lawsuit challenging random, mandatory urinalysis called for by Bush administration officials, who declare that the employees hold sensitive positions and should be tested. The employees are in the Office of Management and Budget, the Office of Administration and the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative. U.S. District Court Judge Louis Oberdorfer said Friday that it is ``unlikely'' that those with top secret clearances will prevail in the case, although he allowed that portion of the lawsuit to proceed. The judge said ``the permissibility of subjecting'' the 10 others to drug tests ``is less clear'' and he kept the ban in place. The government contends, in effect, that information classified as secret is by definition as truly sensitive as top secret information, noted the judge. A 1982 executive order draws the distinction between top secret and secret information by saying that disclosure of the former could reasonably be expected to cause ``exceptionally grave damage'' to the national security. Disclosure of secret information could reasonably be expected to cause ``serious'' damage, says the executive order.
DOC.HEAD: Ex-Sperry Executive Sentenced to 60 Days in Halfway House
DOC.TEXT: A former Sperry Corp. marketing executive who admitted initiating a scheme to bribe a Navy procurement official has been sentenced to 60 days in a halfway house. Frank J. Lavelle, 69, of Dunedin, Fla., was sentenced Friday in U.S. District Court in Alexandria, Va., on his guilty plea to conspiracy to defraud the government and commit bribery of a public official. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton gave Lavelle a two-year sentence, before suspending all but 60 days and ordering the defendant to serve that period in a halfway house. Lavelle, former marketing director of Sperry Corp.'s Clearwater, Fla., facility, could have received a 20-year prison term for initiating the scheme to bribe Navy procurement officer Garland L. Tomlin Jr. Lavelle, who pleaded guilty Oct. 20, has agreed to cooperate with the Justice Department's investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud code-named ``Operation Ill Wind.'' Lavelle admitted that he introduced Tomlin to Sperry Corp. vice president Charles F. Gardner, telling Gardner that Tomlin wanted a ``nest egg'' for his retirement. Tomlin has pleaded guilty to accepting $400,000 in bribes from Sperry, which later merged with Burroughs Corp. to become Unisys Corp., and $75,000 from Honeywell Inc. in exchange for confidential bid information.
DOC.HEAD: Government Announces `String Confetti' Recall
DOC.TEXT: The government is recalling three million cans of an aerosol string confetti because the propellant used in the product may be highly flammable. The product, ``Extra Thick Super String,'' often used at children's birthday parties and other celebrations, is hazardous if sprayed near an open flame, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Friday. The commission received reports on consumer hotlines that six children were burned when fires started after the string was sprayed in the area of birthday cakes with candles, said CPSC spokesman Ken Giles. Approximately three million cans of the string were sold nationwide from December 1988 until October 1989, when the New Jersey-based manufacturer, E. Davis, Inc., developed a new inflammable propellant formula, the agency said in a written statement. Consumers should discard any pre-October cans of the product and mail the each orange, blue, pink or green plastic can cap to the company for two replacements with the reformulated items. Send to: E. Davis, Inc., P.O. Box 8060, Piscataway, N.J. 08854-8060.

DOC.HEAD: Silber Lashes Opponents And Media Because of Racism Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8th graf, `Silber, the ...' to insert name of newspaper that published interview.
DOC.TEXT: Gubernatorial candidate John Silber said he will not apologize for remarks he made about immigrants to Massachusetts that his opponents and other state officials have labeled as racist. ``I think anyone who raised the suggestion that I was either hostile to immigrants or in any sense a racist definitely owes me an apology,'' Silber said Friday, adding his father was a German immigrant. Asked if he owed anyone an apology, Silber said: ``Certainly not.'' Gov. Michael S. Dukakis called Silber's comments about immigrants to the state offensive and pressed him to apologize. And two of Silber's Democratic opponents, state Rep. John Flood and Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, renewed their criticism Friday after expressions of outrage the day before. ``It is insidious to make unfair and unwarranted generalized or stereotypical comments, especially at a time when Massachusetts is engaged in the delicate task of restoring racial harmony,'' Flood said. ``I would have hoped he could have found an apology today,'' Murphy said. ``I was offended. I think he ought to be reflecting on all this long and hard.'' Silber, the president of Boston University, called the news conference Friday after controversy arose from an interview published in the Telegram & Gazette of Worcester in which he questioned whether the state has become a ``welfare magnet.'' ``Why has Massachusetts suddenly become so popular for people who are accustomed to living in the tropical climate?'' Silber told the newspaper. He also told the newspaper, ``Why should Lowell be the Cambodian capital of America? It is extraordinary. Why should they all be concentrated in one place? This needs to be examined.'' At the news conference Silber said: ``Opponents have taken my remarks out of context and twisted them beyond recognition. Some have even suggested that I am racist and hostile to immigrants. Like Sen. Joseph McCarthy, who smeared his opponents with the charge of communism, they have attempted to smear me with the charge of racism.'' But he did not back away from his views that some people come to Massachusetts to collect welfare. ``Some come because of the accessibility and elevation of welfare payments. That is not a criticism. That is a description,'' Silber said. ``Sometimes we have to look at the facts. People who want to avoid the facts are not going to solve the problems of Massachusetts.'' In addition, he accused the news media of poor reporting. ``People ought to know the distortion of reporting is so great they would be well advised to hold their piece until they could get a complete transcript of what one is alleged to have said,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Candidate Seeks Legalized Casino Gambling
DOC.TEXT: Although he's considered a longshot for winning his party's gubernatorial nomination, Miami Democrat Alcee Hastings is willing to bet the state is ready to legalize casino gambling. Hastings _ a Miami attorney who became Florida's first black U.S. district judge, only to be impeached by the U.S. Senate last year _ said Friday he favors changing the Florida Constitution to allow casino gambling with profits helping the state meet its growth needs. Similar efforts to legalize casino gambling failed in 1978 and 1986. ``It's a new idea, one that will at least meet with some resistance, but I believe with some favorable responses as well,'' said Hastings. One of those resisting is U.S. Rep. Bill Nelson, one of three Democratic gubernatorial hopefuls. ``You look at the other states that have horse racing and then you look at the states that have casino gambling, and there's a distinct attitude, atmosphere and element that is attracted to casino gambling that I don't think fits the family-oriented, high technology-oriented, business-oriented atmosphere of our state,'' Nelson said Friday. Hastings' plan would locate casinos in 10 regions of the state, blocking out only a three-county area around Walt Disney World because of its reputation as a family recreational center. ``We have serious revenue needs,'' said Hastings, who will seek his party's nomination in a Sept. 4 primary against Nelson and state Sen. George Stuart. He said half of the casino profits would go to education with the other half split between crime prevention and general revenue.

DOC.SECOND: Haitian Leader Lifts State of Siege
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Haiti's military ruler, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, says he is lifting a 30-day state of siege under which security forces rounded up dozens of political activists and forced at least seven into exile. In a speech Friday night carried live on state radio and television, Avril said the state of siege would be withdrawn Tuesday _ 18 days early _ ``in view of the positive results already obtained.'' It was unclear whether Avril was bowing to diplomatic pressure or simply felt he had effectively stifled open opposition to his 16-month-old regime. The announcement came the same day the French government said it was suspending economic assistance and talks on a $500 million aid package for Haiti, one of the world's poorest nations, to protest Avril's crackdown on his political opponents. The 12-nation European Economic Community also issued a strongly worded protest Friday. Avril has also been under pressure from the Bush administration, which denounced the state of siege as a ``blatant assault on basic civil liberties.'' The United States suspended $60 milion in annual direct aid to Haiti after an election massacre in 1987. In his speech, Avril did not say whether the seven exiled opposition leaders would be allowed to return. However, the interior and defense minister, Brig. Gen. Fritz Romulus, said earlier in the week that the seven could take part in elections scheduled for next fall. Avril also did not say whether censorship imposed on independent radio and television stations would be lifted along with the siege declaration. The military leader, wearing his uniform and sitting at his desk at the National Palace, addressed the nation before the start of the 10 p.m. news on state TV. He read from a prepared text in French, rather than Creole, the language of 90 percent of Haiti's 5.7 million people. The state of siege was imposed on Jan. 20, one day after unidentified gunmen killed army Col. Andre Neptune, his wife and their housemaid. Avril, who attended Neptune's funeral Friday, blamed the assassination on unspecified ``terrorists'' and ``anarchists.'' In apparent reference to the exiled opposition leaders, Avril said ``political demagogues'' had helped create a climate of insecurity in the country. Among the politicians forced into exile were Dr. Louis Roy, one of the main authors of the 1987 constitution, and Hubert De Ronceray, a prominent conservative and former presidential candidate. They were among an estimated 50 activists arrested and reportedly beaten in the military sweep last weekend. Although he did not acknowledge mistreatment by the military, Avril said the ``furor of the soldiers'' after Neptune's killing was understandable. He said the security forces had been hamstrung by certain constitutional guarantees, such as a 48-hour limit on holding suspects without bringing charges. Extraordinary measures were necessary, Avril said, ``to safeguard our young, tottering, stammering democracy.'' Critics have accused Avril of using the colonel's assassination as a pretext to suppress opposition and renege on his pledge to turn over power to a democratically elected government. Elections are scheduled for Oct. 28. But Avril reiterated his pledge to hold elections. ``The democratic process will not be put into question,'' he said. ``On the contrary, in a more serene climate, the electoral machine will advance more securely.'' Avril gained power in September 1988 when a soldiers' rebellion ousted Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, who took over after a popular uprising forced dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier to flee to France in February 1986. The last time Haiti attempted free elections, in November 1987, armed thugs in collusion with government troops shot or hacked to death at least 34 voters and the balloting was canceled.
