DOC.HEAD: Woman Keeps Vigil for Husband, Two Adopted Colombian Children
With PM-Jetliner Crash, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After waiting more than a year, William and Aleta Heidt were ecstatic to learn last week that their plans to adopt two children from Colombia had finally been approved. But the joyous anticipation turned into hours of hellish desperation for Mrs. Heidt when Avianca Flight 52 crashed with her husband and new son and daughter aboard. Mrs. Heidt of Wyckoff, N.J., went to John F. Kennedy International Airport on Thursday night carrying two small parkas _ blue and purple _ for her new children and a camera to take their pictures. The adoptions had taken more than a year to set up and she knew her son and daughter _ Blanca Beltron, 12, and her brother Pedro, 10 _ only from a snapshot. But Avianca Flight 52 never arrived and Friday morning, after a night of telephone calls, Mrs. Heidt learned that her husband and the children were being treated for serious injuries of three separate hospitals. Her husband, William, 51, was in critical condition early today at Nassau County Medical Center. Blanca was moved out of intensive care and was reported in stable condition at Glen Cove Hospital. Pedro was in stable condition at North Shore University Hospital. Adoption agency officials say Blanca and Pedro may have been among many adoptive children aboard the plane. Changes in Colombian law that took effect Jan. 20 have made adoption more difficult, and there has been a rush among adoptive parents in the past week to adopt children there and bring them home. ``All the orphanages are rushing people through,'' said Cheryl Simon, a leader of the Latin American Parents Association, a group that helps people adopting Latin-American children. ``We have 15 families down there now, due to a combination of new adoption laws and courts opening up after Christmas break.'' Hospitals reported treating at least 25 injured children among the 89 people who were injured aboard the Avianca plane. It was not clear how many of those children might have been adopted, however. Mrs. Heidt, eyes ringed by streaked mascara and clutching a silver crucifix, said her husband had flown to Colombia on Sunday after they met the Jan. 20 deadline with help from U.S. Rep. Marge Roukema, in whose district they live. ``I'm self-employed and we couldn't afford to take the time,'' Mrs. Heidt said. ``He went and took vacation from work.'' Numbed and distracted, Mrs. Heidt retreated into silence. ``When he's up and healthy and I see his beautiful brown eyes, then I'll feel like talking,'' she said. ``She was so excited. She has their room ready. She left the Christmas tree up and everything,'' said Lucy Ferguson, a Travelers' Aid director who befriended Mrs. Heidt at the airport during the desperate hours following the crash. Ms. Roukema called the air disaster ``an ultimate irony'' for the Heidts. ``They have worked so hard over the past year to get these children here. Now to have this tragedy is just unbelievable irony.''

DOC.HEAD: Greek Government Announces Date for National Poll
DOC.TEXT: The coalition government has announced that parliamentary elections will be held April 8, ending an administration that united leftists and conservatives in an uneasy partnership. Friday's announcement came after a meeting of the heads of the conservative, socialist and Communist parties with Premier Xenophon Zolotas. It did not mention whether a caretaker government would oversee the vote. The three parties put aside their differences in November to form a temporary goverment and avoid calling immediate new elections after inconclusive national voting June 18 and Nov. 5. Constantine Mitsotakis, leader of the conservative New Democracy party, insisted that the coalition be short-lived, saying it could not cope with the pressing economic and foreign policy issues facing the country. The socialists and Communists wanted a longer-term government, but they were unable to muster a parliamentary majority without the conservatives. The government is struggling with 14.8 percent annual inflation and a budget deficit estimated at $1.6 billion for 1989. The political deadlock developed when the socialists, after eight years in office, lost the election June 18 amid charges that Premier Andreas Papandreou and senior ministers were involved in financial and wiretapping scandals. Papandreou has been indicted in connection with the scandals, but no trial date has been set.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgaria Lifts Communist Control from Army, Police
DOC.TEXT: The military, police and other armed units will no longer be under the control of the Communist Party, the government and the army announced. The announcement Friday on national television appeared to be an effort by the Communists, who still control the goverment, to bolster their sagging image before a key party congress starting Jan. 30. On Thursday night, the policy-making Central Committee approved a platform for the congress that commits the Communists to pluralism and social democracy, the official BTA news agency said. A showdown is expected at the upcoming congress between reformers and more orthodox Communists, many of whom kept the powerful local posts they gained under former leader Todor Zhivkov, who was ousted Nov. 10 and replaced by party leaader Petar Mladenov. A 12-party coalition of opposition groups, the Union of Democratic Forces, is negotiating with the Communists for a greater share of power. On Friday, BTA quoted the union's chairman, Zhelyo Zhelev, as holding out the possibility his alliance would enter a coalition with the Communists, but only if it were made clear the union did not share responsibility for past mistakes under Communist rule. ``We do not want to share responsibility with people who are guilty,'' Zhelev told BTA. According to a decree made public Friday, no political parties will be allowed to operate in the future in the army and in subdivisions of the Interior Ministry, including the police. In practice, that means abolition of Communist Party control, because it has been the only party allowed to function in those organizations. The decree by the State Council _ Bulgaria's collective presidency _ made clear that individuals in the army and police force may continue membership in the party ``at their place of residence.'' Defense Ministry spokesman Radnyu Minchev disclosed under a resolution of the party's eight-member Politburo, dated Wednesday, all Communist political organs and Komsomol, or Communist Youth organizations, are being abolished in the army. ``This is proof of the party's renunciation of its monopoly on power,'' he declared. Minchev said that under an emerging multiparty system, ``it is inadmissible to wage a political fight within the army. '' Lyuben Gotsev, first deputy interior minister, said all committees and organizations of the Communist Party and Komsomol that are under his ministry's control will be dissolved, such as the police, border troops and fire departments. Also Friday, a one-week strike of virtually all Bulgarian mines was suspended pending negotiations involving the official trade unions, the independent union Podkrepa and mining management. The TV report on the suspension did not say how many miners struck, but noted that 14 strike committees joined in the protest for higher pay, better retirement terms and greater safety on the job. Numerous strikes have increased social tensions in this Balkan nation as it moves toward democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Surprise for Surgeons Operating on Air Crash Victim
With PM-Jetliner Crash, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Doctors operating on a survivor of the Avianca airline crash made an unexpected find as they worked to stop his internal bleeding _ several condoms filled with a white powder believed to be cocaine. The chief of special surgery at North Shore University Hospital, Dr. Robert Ward, said physicians operating on the man Friday found what he estimated to be more than a pound of the drug inside the victim's bowels. The flight from Bogota stopped in the drug-smuggling capital of Medellin before continuing on to New York. The plane crashed Thursday night in Cove Neck, killing 72 of the 161 people on board. The man, identified only as passenger No. 7, was in critical condition, but was expected to survive. He suffered broken legs and internal injuries, the doctor said. Police went to the victim's bedside to question him, Ward said. After the surgery, when doctors told the middle-aged man ``we have to know what this is,'' the patient admitted it was cocaine, Ward said. Ward removed four drug-filled condoms from the man's bowels and believed more remained inside him, he said. Each, he said, contained enough cocaine to kill the man, had one ruptured. The doctor said it would be dangerous to remove the remaining condoms, adding that he hoped nature would take its course and the man would discharge them with a week or so.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Communists Kill President's Guard
DOC.TEXT: Three suspected communists today shot and killed one of President Corazon Aquino's guards, then ran over and dragged his body for about 100 yards before escaping, police said. Sgt. Sadiri Cadsap, 39, assigned to Mrs. Aquino's ceremonial and escort company, died from multiple gunshot wounds, said Michael Tambawan, a police investigator. He said the ambush took place along a busy street in Pasay City, a Manila suburb, while the guard was waiting for a ride to work. Tambawan said communist New People's Army assassins walked up slowly from behind and shot the soldier several times in the head and back at point-blank range, killing him instantly. One of the gunmen then flagged down a passenger jeep, ordered the driver and his wife to get out, then drove over Cadsap's body, dragging it for about 100 yards before escaping, Tambawan added. He said the jeep was recovered in Quezon City. The communists are waging a 21-year-old insurgency against the national government.

DOC.HEAD: Airliner Low on Fuel Before Crash; 72 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf, `Investigators picking ...' to CORRECT town name to Cove Neck, sted Cove Glen. ^LaserPhotos NY4,5
DOC.TEXT: The crew of a Colombian jetliner was worried about running low on fuel just before the plane crashed, killing 72 people, federal investigators say. National Safety Board member Lee Dickinson told a news conference Friday that the crew, on a voice recorder recovered from the wreckage, expressed concern several times about fuel levels after an aborted landing attempt. But the pilot did not declare an emergency landing priority that would have required controllers to immediately clear Avianca Airlines Flight 52 for a landing Thursday night, he said. Although many clues indicate the plane had little or no fuel when it crashed into a hill on the north shore of Long Island, federal investigators would not say that the crash was caused by the plane running out of fuel. No homes were hit and there were no casualties on the ground, though one part of the plane came to rest on a home's patio. Dickinson said 89 people survived the crash. Investigators picking through the wreckage of the Boeing 707 in the woods of the isolated, wealthy suburb of Cove Neck said the fuel gauges indicated the jet had 10,000 pounds, or 1,500 gallons, of fuel, Dickinson said. Investigators had not yet checked the tanks. Boeing spokesman Jack Gamble in Seattle said that could have been enough fuel to fly the jet from the crash site to its destination, Kennedy International Airport, ``but not much more.'' The airport is about 15 miles away. The flight from Bogota tried to land in fog and rain at 9:24 p.m., but aborted the attempt because of electronic warnings that the plane was sinking too fast and approaching at an improper angle, Dickinson said. The crew asked the airport's traffic controller for permission to try again. ``They said they ... were running out of fuel or they were low on fuel,'' Dickinson said. The tower gave directions; the crew repeated that the plane was running low on fuel. The crew then reported two engines out. The jet disappeared from the radar screens at 9:34 p.m., he said. The Colombian radio network RCN has reported that the 23-year-old plane had been sent to the maintenance shop 37 times in the past four months. Dickinson said he had no information to confirm the plane's maintenance record. More than 12 hospitals worked Friday to treat survivors. At least 25 of the injured survivors were either in serious or critical condition, and more than two dozen children were among the injured. Dickinson said only nine of the dead had been identified. Only one member of the crew, the chief steward, survived the crash. Survivors said the plane circled for more than hour before the crash. NBC News reported that the plane ran into delays along the East Coast and was put in a holding pattern over Norfolk, Va., and twice over New Jersey for 75 minutes. Dickinson and a FAA spokeswoman said they could not confirm that. One passenger, Colombian businessman Jorge Lozano, said there was no warning before the crash. ``I had time to say a prayer. ... In about five seconds we were crashing into the trees,'' said Lozano, who suffered a cracked spine. Scores of emergency workers from as far away as New York City laid ladders up the steep wooded hillside where part of the fuselage came to rest, then passed survivors down. ``What a way to come to America,'' one of the passengers told rescue worker Jay Krul, 30, of Oyster Bay. Several factors show the plane may have run out of fuel: no fire on impact; the low-speed landing; the lack of fuel odor; and the angle of the nose, wings and body, which came down level instead of thrusting forward, as they would have if the engines were running. Among the injured were a number of children who were bound for adoption in the United States. ``A lot of the kids we got out alive,'' said rescuer Charles Harris. The crash occurred a quarter-mile from the home where the parents of tennis pro John McEnroe live; their lawn was used as a makeshift morgue. Dickinson said there was no evidence thus far of sabotage. One victim of Thursday's crash appeared to have a cocaine connection, however. Daniel Rossett, a spokesman for North Shore University Hospital, said surgeons at work on a 30-year-old victim who suffered abdominal injuries found condoms believed packed with cocaine in the man's intestines. The man was in critical condition.

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Begging a Form of Free Speech
DOC.TEXT: A no-begging rule in the subway is unconstitutional because the First Amendment applies to panhandling as much as any other form of speech, a federal judge declared. U.S. District Judge Leonard Sand invalidated regulations of the Transit Authority, which runs the subways, and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which prohibits begging in the World Trade Center and the Port Authority Bus Terminal. He ruled Friday that the bans should be rewritten to include ``reasonable time, place and manner restrictions.'' The authorities can forbid begging on moving vehicles and near token booths, narrow platforms and on stairs and escalators, Sand said. ``It is the total prohibition of all begging on all of the defendants' facilities which is constitutionally impermissible,'' he said. The lawsuit was brought by two homeless men who beg in the city's subway system. Their lawyer, George Summers, said the ruling was the first time a federal court had determined that begging is protected by the First Amendment. Summers had argued that begging is nothing more than one person asking another a question. The judge adopted that approach. Sand wrote: ``The simple request for money by a beggar or a panhandler cannot but remind the passer-by that people in the city live in poverty and often lack the essentials for survival. ``Even the beggar sitting in Grand Central Station with a tin cup at his feet conveys the message that he and others like him are in need. While often disturbing and sometimes alarmingly graphic, begging is unmistakably informative and persuasive speech.'' Douglas Lasdon, an attorney with the Legal Action Center for the Homeless, said the judge's ruling ``reaffirms the principle that in this country you cannot solve a social problem by silencing poor people.'' Sand's ruling stemmed from a class-action lawsuit filed Nov. 28 by Lasdon's group on behalf of homeless and needy people. Spokeswomen for the Transit Authority and Port Authority declined to comment, saying their lawyers were reviewing the decision. The Transit Authority's begging ban was part of its program to enforce set rules for subway conduct. The lawsuit claimed the program was designed to roust the homeless from the subway. The judge's decision came at a time of heightened scrutiny of safety issues raised by the presence of homeless people in the subway. On Sunday, a man who was waiting with his 3-year-old son at a Manhattan station was spat at and punched by a homeless man. Police said he turned on the homeless man, hit him on the head and beat his head on the platform, killing him. The man was charged with first-degree manslaughter.

DOC.HEAD: UMW Rallies During `Cat and Mouse' Game
LaserPhoto CN1
DOC.TEXT: Union miners shut down a coal plant employing non-union workers when more than 500 supporters from three states marched up an Appalachian hollow in the union's largest show of strength since June. ``We want to send a clear message that we're not going away,'' Bob Phalen, president of UMW District 17, said Friday. ``When injustice is being inflicted upon our brothers and sisters, we'll be there to support them.'' The United Mine Workers want Rum Creek Coal Sales Inc. to stop using non-union contractors to operate a preparation plant and the truck lines serving it. Union members had held the jobs until last August. The miners chanted ``UMWA all the way'' as they walked up Rum Creek Hollow, blocking both lanes of traffic behind a West Virginia State Police escort. Many were upset that a federal court judge ordered miners off a private bridge leading to the plant and limited the number of pickets to 15. No violence was reported. Rum Creek, which the past four days had ordered its coal trucks to smash through vehicles left in their path, told federal and state police they would not attempt to run coal Friday. ``It's a cat-and-mouse game,'' Phalen said. ``We know who the rat is.'' The march and subsequent rallies at the picket site and a union camp were the largest gatherings of UMW miners since June, when a rally in Charleston attracted more than 1,000 miners, the union said. The A.T. Massey Coal Co., Rum Creek Coal's parent company, credited police for keeping the peace. The June rally in Charleston triggered wildcat strikes the next day. During June and July, more than 43,000 miners in 10 states walked off their jobs in violation of other union contracts. Many took days off work on Friday. Miners struck Rum Creek in mid-August after it re-opened the preparation plant with non-union contractors. State troopers had advised the miners not to block the public road. The union already was under court order not to block an adjacent private road leading to the plant. Many of the miners said they were prepared to be arrested. Two UMW members were charged on Wednesday with assaulting federal officers and released Thursday. Three other miners have been charged with violating a court order. The Rum Creek strike is not related to the 9-month-old strike against the Pittston Coal Group, which was tentatively settled Jan. 1. The proposed pact has not yet been submitted for ratification by the rank and file.

DOC.HEAD: China Celebrates Beginning of Year of Horse
DOC.TEXT: With 12 chimes of a 500-year-old bell, the beat of a drum and a deafening roar of firecrackers, Beijing welcomed the Year of the Horse today. At the stroke of midnight, the city's Mayor Chen Xitong struck the 500-year-old bronze bell _ China's largest and heaviest _ a dozen times. Residents set off a hail of firecrackers and fireworks to greet the Lunar New Year, which in China is called Spring Festival. Each lunar year is represented by one of 12 animals of the Chinese zodiacal calendar. The Year of the Horse follows the Year of the Snake. As the mayor struck the bell, a worker and a soldier nearby beat two large, red drums atop Beijing's Drum Tower. But both the drums and the bell were drowned out by the cacophony of firecrackers that lasted, unbroken, for about 15 minutes. The sounding of the bell and drum revived an imperial tradition, and the official Xinhua News agency said they would be sounded on the eve of every Spring Festival. The Bell and Drum Towers were timekeepers for imperial Beijing, but neither has been used for 66 years, since the last emperor left the Imperial Palace. ``In the old society, that's how we knew the time,'' said a 60-year-old native of Beijing who lives near the two towers. The woman, who did not give her name, said it was the first time she had heard the bell or the drum since 1949 when the Communists took power. Also at midnight, Premier Li Peng and Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin gave their holiday greetings on television. The unusual appearance was part of an annual pre-recorded, four-hour New Year's Eve variety show, one of China's most-watched television shows. The Chinese leadership earlier this week traveled to the provinces to bring Spring Festival holiday greetings to workers and to thank soldiers for their role in putting down last spring's pro-democracy movement. During a six-day tour of Shanxi province in northern China, Jiang emphasized the role of the working class and said socialism will triumph in China if ``we learn from (their) spirit of fearing no hardship and quietly contributing to the country and the people.'' Such exhortations have been common in the wake of last year's pro-democracy movement, which was violently crushed by the military. Hundreds, perhaps thousands of people died. This year's Spring Festival celebrations in Beijing seemed more subdued than in past years, when the sound of firecrackers could be heard all night long. Traditionally, Chinese set off firecrackers for almost any special occasion, but especially at the Lunar New Year because it is supposed to ward off evil spirits. Beijing was bustling for most of the day, as shoppers made their final purchases for the long weekend. Huge quantities of food have been brought into the capital to ensure bounty for the holiday, and in recent days, the Chinese media have been filled with reports of an abundent food supply throughout the country. Beijing stores were stocked with $370 million worth of food and other unspecified commodities, Xinhua reported. Fruits from temperate climates, like oranges and bananas and even kiwi, were on sale, and Xinhua reported that more than 50 kinds of vegetables have been shipped from southern China. The news agency said prices for some fruits was down by 20 percent from last year. Inflation, which peaked at an annual rate of 36 percent in 1988, has been a major complaint among the Chinese, and the government has scrapped plans to cut back on subsidies. Tens of thousands of people turned out for the first day of the Longtan Park temple fair, according to a woman at the ticket window. But inside, vendors selling toys and snacks complained that the turnout was lower than expected. The fair offered a variety of ``Beijing-style snacks,'' from spicy pancakes to small deep-fried eggs on a stick to candied crab apples, as well colorful plastic trinkets and household goods. Gamblers could try their hand at a portable roulette table, which offered Lux soap and Hilton cigarettes as prizes, and children could ride in a dog-drawn cart for about 20 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Pilot Pleads Guilty to Cocaine Smuggling
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian pilot who flew cocaine for two Medellin cartel bosses faces possible life in prison and a $4 million fine after pleading guilty to conspiracy to import cocaine. Jorge de la Cuesta pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy on condition that a cocaine-distribution conspiracy count be dropped. U.S. District Judge John H. Moore II set sentencing for April 6. De la Cuesta was arrested in a crackdown on cocaine traffickers in Colombia after the assassination of a presidential candidate and was flown to Jacksonville on Nov. 30. Carlos Fernando Arenas Ortega, a former pilot for Lehder and a government witness, identified de la Cuesta as a pilot for both Pablo Escobar Gaviria and Carlos Lehder Rivas, two of the cartel's founders. De la Cuesta was indicted nearly a year ago as part of the so-called ``Son of Lehder'' case. It was so named because it was an outgrowth of testimony and information gathered during a 1987-88 trial that netted Lehder a lifetime in prison on drug-smuggling charges. In the spinoff trial that ended last October, two men were acquitted and three were convicted. Ten other defendants pleaded guilty. According to court documents, de la Cuesta learned to fly as a youth and by age 21 was a pilot for Avianca, the Colombian national airline. He began flying cocaine for Lehder in 1979 and continued into 1980 but left over a dispute about money, court documents said. He rejoined the cartel in 1984 and flew about a ton of cocaine in two flights from Colombia to the Bahamas and a third flight from Nicaragua to the islands over Cuban airspace, the documents said.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Officially Retires Blackbird Spy Jet
DOC.TEXT: The high-flying Blackbird spy plane, which flew faster than a bullet, was officially grounded after a quarter-century of service. The SR-71 ``is an aircraft that has ... truly reached out and touched the face of God,'' Gen. John Chain Jr., chief of the Strategic Air Command, said Friday, referring to a famous poem about flight. The crews who took the plane to record heights at speeds of 2,100 mph are ``true American heroes,'' Chain said at Blackbird's retirement ceremony attended by about 1,000 people. The dagger-shaped planes, which the Air Force calls the world's fastest and highest flying airplane, were permanently grounded in November. The unarmed twin-engine planes capable of photographing a vehicle license plate from 15 miles above the earth will be exhibited at museums across the nation. ``For me, it's a sad day,'' said Ben Rich, a Lockheed Corp. vice president who helped design the Blackbird. ``I was there at its birth,'' Rich said. ``I'm here at its retirement. ... We gave the world its finest. But we must go on.'' A federal budget measure signed last year by President George Bush deleted more than $200 million for the aging Blackbirds. Critics in Congress said the loss of the more versatile SR-71 will leave a gap in U.S. surveillance capabilities. ``It's not that there's no need for it. It's just that we're constrained by money,'' Lt. Col. Rod Dyckman said after flying an SR-71. ``This will all hit me a little later, that this was my last flight.'' The nine existing SR-71s surrounded the stage at the ceremony. Originally the Air Force had 30 Blackbirds; officials said some crashed and others simply wore out. The Blackbirds' destinations include the National Air and Space Museum in Washington, D.C., and the Air Force Museum at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio. Other Air Force base museums scheduled to receive the Blackbirds will be Offutt in Nebraska; Lackland in Texas; Robins in Georgia; and Edwards, March and Castle in California. One of the jets will go to the museum here, about 110 miles northeast of San Francisco. The aircraft also operated out of air fields in Mildenhall, England, and Kadena Air Base in Okinawa. Its pilots and navigators, who wore spacesuits during flight, say they have been attacked numerous times by missiles fired from ground forces or jet fighters. The plane was the first to employ the stealth or radar-evading technology that is the hallmark of the nation's newest military aircraft. Nearly three decades after the first Blackbirds were built by Lockheed, the jets still hold world records for speed and altitude. The Blackbird's top capabilities remain secret, but the Air Force says it flies to more than 85,000 feet at more than 2,100 mph _ or over three times the speed of sound. That's roughly 35 miles a minute _ faster than a bullet; fast enough to streak from San Francisco to New York in 1 hour, 45 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Papers Publish Appeal for Release of American Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Two Beirut newspapers today published an appeal by a city university for the release of three American educators kidnapped by Iranian-backed Shiite Moslem extremists three years ago. ``We plead with those in a position to help to ensure the release of our professors,'' said a statement released by Beirut University College, where the three taught. ``Those teachers taught with sincerity and diligence for many years and shared difficulties and dangers with their colleagues,'' the statement said. The Arabic-language statement was carried by the prestigious An-Nahar and leftist As-Safir dailies. The three Americans _ Alann Steen, Robert Polhill and Jesse Turner _ were kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987, from the campus of the American-affiliated Beirut University College in the city's Moslem sector by gunmen disguised as policemen. Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, an underground pro-Iranian group, claimed responsibility for their abduction. A fourth University College educator kidnapped with the Americans, Mithileshwar Singh, an Indian who lived in the United States, was released Oct. 3, 1988 after 20 months in captivity. Steen, 50, of Arcata, Calif., taught journalism at the college, Polhill, 55, formerly of New York, was assistant professor of business and lecturer in accounting at the college, and Turner, 42, of Boise, Idaho, was a visiting professor of mathematics and computer science. Fifteen other Westerners, including five other Americans, are held hostage in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Social Philosopher Lewis Mumford Dead at 94
DOC.TEXT: Lewis Mumford, a philosopher, planner, critic and educator who warned of the dehumanizing effect of technology, died in his spartan, functional country home. He was 94. He died on Friday ``of old age'' in his sleep, said his grandson, James Morss. ``He was frail, but there was no sickness.'' Mumford, best known for his writings on cities, culture and architecture, authored more than 30 books, including ``The City in History,'' for which he received the 1961 National Book Award. He was awarded the National Medal of Arts by President Reagan in 1986. Recipients are honored for their lifetime contributions to American arts. The roots of Mumford's philosophy grew from the America of a century ago. He embraced the notion of self-reliance put forth by Whitman and Emerson. He also was inspired by Melville and Thoreau, who stressed the virtues of humanism and a personalized society. ``The test of maturity, for nations as well as individuals, is not the increase in power,'' he said near the end of his life, ``but the increase of self-understanding, self-control, self-direction and self-transcendence. For in a mature society, man himself, and not his machines or his organizations, is the chief work of art.'' Mumford urged people to turn away from faceless technology and return to human feelings and moral values. He vehemently denied accusations that he saw science as evil and wanted to destroy machinery with the hope of bringing back a pre-industrial society. What he feared, he said, was science without conscience and ``a dominant minority'' of those people who had mastered high technology holding power over others as a result. The illegitimate son of a businessman, Mumford was born in New York City on Oct. 19, 1895, and grew up on Manhattan's West Side. He attended night classes at City College for five years, but failing health prevented him from completing his degree. Instead, he took graduate courses at Columbia University and at the New School for Social Research. It was then he discovered the works of Sir Patrick Geddes, a Scottish town planner whose influence he called the most important in his life. After serving as a naval radio technician in World War I, Mumford became associate editor of The Dial magazine. His essays on housing and urban matters led him to become acting editor of The Sociological Review. Mumford was co-founder of the Regional Planning Association of America and served on the staff of the New York Housing and Regional Planning Commission. In the 1930s, he began weekly art columns and monthly architecture critiques for The New Yorker. From 1934 to 1951, he published four books that became known as the ``Renewal of Life'' series. They made his international reputation and landed him on Time magazine's cover. The volumes _ ``Technics and Civilization,'' ``The Culture of Cities,'' ``The Condition of Man,'' and the ``Conduct of Life'' _ established Mumford as a first-rate thinker. Visiting professorships at MIT, Dartmouth, Stanford and the University of Pennsylvania followed. Among honors bestowed upon him were the President's Medal of Freedom in 1964, the Gold Medal of the Town Planning Institute, the Emerson-Thoreau Medal of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the Leonardo da Vinci Medal of the Society for the History of Technology and an honorary knighthood of the Order of the British Empire. He is survived by his wife, Sophia; his daughter, Alison Mumford Morss, and two grandchildren, James and Elizabeth.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Woman's Family Money for Toxic Shock Death
DOC.TEXT: A Circuit Court jury has found a tampon maker responsible for a woman's death from toxic shock syndrome in 1978 and has ordered it to pay her family $905,750. The jury deliberated 11 hours over two days before deciding on Friday that Johnson & Johnson Consumer Products Inc., maker of O.B. Tampons, was responsible for the death of Donna Marie Davis of Decatur. Ten years ago, toxic shock syndrome was linked to dozens of women's deaths, and studies suggesting that tampons were a major cause prompted scores of lawsuits against tampon makers. Ms. Davis, 31, was using the O.B. Tampons just prior to her death, said attorney John Nickley, who tried the case for the woman's estate. Spokesmen for Johnson & Johnson said the company will appeal the verdict. The spokesmen said the company believes the tampon brand is safe and was no factor in the woman's death. Toxic shock syndrome is a rare, but sometimes fatal condition linked to tampon use. The common bacterium staphylococcus aureus can use tampons as a breeding site in the body and produce poisonous waste which can enter the bloodstream and cause the illness. Ms. Davis died Sept. 2, 1978, after suffering from vomiting, diarrhea, fever and a rash. All are symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. ``The verdict means more to me than the award does,'' said Ms. Davis' husband, Harold, 46, who owns and operates a service station. ``We have tried to find an answer to why she died for 12 years. We wouldn't rest until we found the answer and now we feel that we have.''

DOC.HEAD: Superintendent Fired For Role In Prison Melee
DOC.TEXT: The state's corrections commissioner fired the suspended superintendent of the Camp Hill prison for his actions during a three-day riot that left 123 people injured and much of the institution in ruins. The dismissal of Robert Freeman on Friday came shortly after Gov. Robert P. Casey recommended the action, citing a commission report that was sharply critical of management decisions during the riot in October. In addition to the injuries, the rioting caused about $14 million in damage. Prison administrators declared the prison secure after a first night of rioting Oct. 25, but inmates were able to free themselves and continued their rampage though Oct. 27. On Nov. 1, The Associated Press reported guards had complained that prison officials ignored warnings of cell-locking mechanisms being broken after the first night of rioting. Freeman was suspended the day the report was made. His telephone number is unpublished, and he could not be reached for comment. ``The extreme seriousness of the Camp Hill incident ... requires that those having responsibility for security at Camp Hill be held accountable for their actions,'' Casey said. Corrections Department spokesman Kenneth Robinson said the dismissal was effective immediately. He said acting Superintendent Jeffrey Beard would remain at work at the prison. Prison Commissioner David S. Owens Jr., acting on Casey's recommendation, also fired Camp Hill's deputy for operations, Robert Smith. Terry Henry, deputy for treatment, will be reassigned within the department, an action also taken at Casey's request, Robinson said. Casey said he also would have recommended the dismissal of Maj. John Stover, captain of the guard, but Stover had resigned. Owens, who had been criticized in the commission report for a ``hands-off'' approach to dealing with the riot, was not sanctioned by Casey. The governor on Friday cited the findings of the Adams Commission, an independent three-member panel that concluded management at Camp Hill failed to adequately search the prison after the first night of rioting, and failed to assure that cells were locked when the guards said they weren't secure. The commission, which presented its report in December, also found that supervisory personnel failed to keep an adequate force of state troopers at the prison to prevent a second night of rioting, and that ample time was available for management to reconsider its decisions, which did not happen. State Rep. Jerry L. Nailor said he was perplexed if the firings were based on the commission report, because the panel recommended no dismissals. Conflicting testimony during House and Senate hearings from guards and officials at Camp Hill have raised more questions than they've answered, he said. ``I'm wondering what information the governor has now that the rest of us haven't heard,'' Nailor said.

DOC.HEAD: 76 Killed In Flooding, 14 in Landslide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sudharmono one name is cq
DOC.TEXT: Floods triggered by two days of heavy rains have devastated the central Java capital of Semarang, leaving 76 people dead and 24 missing, an official said today. Also today, a landslide buried 14 people alive and left three others missing in Jayapura, about 2,000 miles northeast of Jakarta. The Banjir Kanal Barat River poured over its banks Friday in the worst floods in the city in 20 years, breaking an embankment and crippling traffic in much of the Semarang. Hundreds of homes were damaged or destroyed. Sudharmono, spokesman of the central Java governor's office, said a rescue team was still searching for the missing. He said thousands of people were evacuated from the stricken areas and were being accommodated at schools and other public buildings. Large pools of water still cover part of the city, he said. In addition to the 14 dead, 16 people were injured in the landslide in Jayapura, said Rudolf Rahauzune, spokesman of the governor's office. He said the landslide, which followed a night of rain, damaged or destroyed 20 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Hope To Stabilize Patients' Immune Systems
DOC.TEXT: A new treatment for AIDS that involves removing, stimulating and then re-injecting certain white blood cells has the potential to stabilize patients' immune systems, a researcher said. ``It's taking advantage of one's natural defense against the virus,'' said Dr. Monto Ho, chairman of infectious diseases and microbiology at the University of Pittsburgh's Graduate School of Public Health. Ho, who is heading what is believed to be the nation's only clinical trials of the new treatment, said researchers plan to remove white blood cells that attack cells infected with the AIDS virus. The removed cells will be treated with stimulants and incubated for two weeks so they can multiply. The activated cells, called killer T-cells, then will be injected back into the patient from whom they were taken. The treatment is being administered to only one person, although the six-month study calls for six to be tested. ``The purpose is to really see if it's toxic,'' Ho said. ``If it's not toxic, a bigger program will be initiated to find out if it will really kill the infected cells. Whether it will do that, we don't know.'' Researchers hope the activated killer T-cells, or CD8 cells, will kill or at least inhibit the growth of AIDS-tainted cells and fight other infections afflicting AIDS patients. The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases is financing the study. ``What happens to the immune systems in AIDS patients, it keeps going down and eventually they die,'' Ho said. ``If you can stabilize the immune system by restricting the infected cells, then you have something.'' The patient who has undergone the treatment was diagnosed about a year ago with AIDS and has received three infusions in the past six weeks. He has shown no signs of acute toxicity, Ho said. Dr. Jeffrey Laurence, director of the laboratory for AIDS research at Cornell University, said researchers must make sure the removed cells cannot harbor the virus. ``If they make certain they're not multiplying the virus along with the killer cells, it sounds like a very good idea and something worthy of a clinical trial,'' Laurence said. Some AIDS patients, however, already have an expanded pool of killer T-cells, according to Dr. Susan Zolla-Pazner, professor of pathology at New York University. As a result, providing even more might not eliminate the infected cells although it might help slow down the disease, she said. ``It's an interesting approach,'' she said. As of the end of December, 117,781 cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome had been reported to the Centers for Disease Control. The death count was 70,313. University of Pittsburgh researchers plan to treat six patients with AIDS or AIDS-related complex, a condition preceding the disease, as part of the study. Six doses of their own activated cells over 13 weeks will be administered, followed by 11 weeks of tests. The removed cells will be stimulated with interleukin-2, an immune system booster, as well as another substance. The technique for isolating and purifying the cells was developed by Applied Immune Sciences Inc. of Menlo Park, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``What a way to come to America.'' _ An unidentified passenger pulled from the wreckage of a Colombian jetliner that crashed near Kennedy International Airport, to rescue worker Jay Krul, 30, of Oyster Bay, N.Y.

``The Bush administration's approach is to force the poor people to decide between heating and eating. I think they need both.'' _ Sharpe James, Democratic mayor of Newark, N.J., at the conclusion of the U.S. Conference of Mayors' three-day winter meeting.

``I hope the reception is a good one. My message will be one of friendship, consultation, where do we go from here. How do we build democracy in Panama. How do we build democracy in our Western Hemisphere.'' _ Vice President Dan Quayle, beginning a trip aimed at healing relations with Latin America nations after the U.S. invasion of Panama.

DOC.HEAD: High Winds Continue; Mild Temperatures in East
DOC.TEXT: High winds blew from the Pacific Northwest to the Appalachians early today, with 50 mph gusts expected in the western mountains. Light snow accompanied a cold front in the eastern Rockies and western Plains. In eastern New York, colder temperatures threatened to freeze flooded areas. Flood warnings in the state were called for the Mohawk River near Schenectady, and for the Ausable, Bouquet and Hoosick rivers. The state's heaviest precipitation fell in a 10-county area around Albany, the National Weather Service said. Spencertown, south of the capital, received 2{ inches of rain on Friday. Floating ice jams were expected to cause localized flooding until the freeze returned. On the warmer side today, southern areas of California, Texas and Florida looked for highs in the 70s. On Friday, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter designated 28 more Florida counties disaster areas as a result of the Christmas weekend freeze. Mild air was predicted from Louisiana to southern New England today. Winter storm warnings were posted for the Oregon Cascades. A snow advisory was in effect for the state's coastal range and the northeast mountains. Twelve inches of snow fell at Stevens Pass, Wash., on Friday. A winter weather warning was in effect across the Washington Cascades and Olympics, where forecasts called for up to a foot of snow. On Friday, winds in Utah gusted to 58 mph at Delta and to 52 mph at Springville. Flurries were forecast today for Upper Michigan and northern Wisconsin. Snow showers were scattered over parts of Idaho, Nevada, Wyoming, Pennsylvania and New York state late Friday. In parts of Maine, snow changed to rain. Jamestown, N.D., enjoyed its warmest Jan. 26 on record with a reading of 52. The nation's high temperature Friday was 85 degrees at Spring Valley, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Avianca Plane Reportedly Plagued by Maintenance Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for 5th pvs, `The plane...' to CORRECT number of passengers on board; pickup graf 6 `Avianca and...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Jetliner Crash, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Colombian jetliner that crashed on Long Island, N.Y., killing 72 people, was 23 years old and had been sent for maintenance 37 times in the last four months, a national radio network said. The RCN network quoted unidentified airport sources in its report Friday on the maintenance problems of the four-engine Boeing 707. Colombia's Civil Aviation Authority does not permit news media to review aircraft maintenance records, but RCN indicated it spoke to someone with access to the records. It gave no further details on the maintenance records, such as what the problems were and whether any regulations had been violated. The plane, which had 161 people on board, crashed Thursday night in Cove Neck, Long Island as it was approaching John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York. The flight originated in Bogota and stopped in Medellin. Avianca and airport officials have declined to comment on the possible cause of the accident. Some reports said the plane had lost use of an engine, but Alfredo Parra, a airline pilot instructor inteviewed in Bogota, said the aircraft could have continued to fly even if it lost two engines. ``Why the aircraft didn't try to land at an alternate airport even if one or two of its engines was inoperative is an important question to be asked in the investigation,'' Parra said in an interview with the Caracol radio network. Colombian aviation experts said investigators should try to determine why the plane _ which some reports said ran out of fuel _ was circling New York instead of heading for an alternative airport where weather conditions were better. It was raining the night of the crash. A veteran Avianca pilot noted the pilot had to abort his first landing attempt. He said that when this happens and the 707 must gain altitude quickly, without much fuel left, the remaining fuel is forced to the back of tanks and may cause engines to shut off. He spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. However, a preliminary investigation showed that 10,000 pounds of fuel were left in the airplane tanks, National Transportation Safety Board spokesman Lee Dickinson said Friday night in New York. Dickinson said there were indications that at least three of the four engines were not working at the time of the crash. An Avianca spokeswoman, who would identify herself only as Mercedes, told the AP by telephone that the 52-year-old pilot, Laureano Caviedes, worked for Avianca since 1962; the co-pilot, Mauricio Klotz, 27, for 3{ years; and the flight engineer, Matias Moyano Rojas, 44, for 24 years.

DOC.HEAD: McMartin Defense Attorney Assail Prosecutor, Media, Judge
DOC.TEXT: Defense attorneys in the McMartin preschool molestation case blasted the prosecutor, judge and news media after winning acquittals in the nation's longest criminal trial. Attorneys Daniel G. Davis and Dean R. Gits, who represent Ray Buckey, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, said Friday they plan to file misconduct complaints with the state bar association against the chief prosecutor. They accused Deputy District Attorney Lael Rubin of unfairly blocking bail for Mrs. Buckey. ``She's not fit to have a license to practice law,'' Davis said of Ms. Rubin. ``I am the prosecutor now.'' Ms. Rubin said Davis has a ``history of making outrageous, unfounded and unproven allegations.'' ``I look forward with a lot of good feelings about Mr. Davis claiming he's going to refer an investigation to the state bar,'' she said. ``I think it's a wonderful idea and I look forward to complete vindication.'' The defense lawyers also said the news media reported the case inaccurately. They said they believed that the reports led some to conclude the defendants were guilty. Gits said he counted 19 people who heard every day of evidence in the case. Twelve were jurors; the rest were lawyers, the judge and court personnel. But he noted that TV stations which took polls of their viewers found that 70 percent to 80 percent believed the verdicts were wrong. ``What the viewers were reflecting was media dissemination (of the case),'' he said. ``The public had made up its mind the defendants were guilty. That's a terrible, terrible thing.'' The Buckeys were cleared of 52 molestation charges last week. The jury deadlocked on 13 other charges against Buckey. The district attorney's office must decide by Wednesday whether it will retry the former preschool instructor on those charges. Rubin said she has been consulting with children and their parents on the matter. Davis also criticized the post-trial TV appearances of Superior Court Judge William Pounders. ``I am saddened to see the trial judge in this case, with litigation (still) pending, trooping about in television land like a lightweight, bit actor, making comments about the children,'' Davis said. Pounders could not be reached for comment by telephone after business hours Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Elementary School Principal Convicted on Crack Charge
DOC.TEXT: An elementary school principal whose drug arrest touched off investigations into city school boards has been convicted of crack possession. ``It was not unexpected,'' said Matthew Barnwell as he left the court after the jury convicted him. He faces a year in jail and a $1,000 fine when Judge William Leibovitz sentences him on March 9. ``This was a sad duty,'' said Hope Hagler, 43, an attorney and teacher who was on the Manhattan Criminal Court jury that convicted Barnwell. ``We were all upset. He was a fine gentleman who gave in to a weakness.'' Civil liberties attorney William Kunstler, who represented Barnwell, said there are ``enormous grounds for appeal.'' He cited Leibovitz's refusal to permit the jury to visit the site of the alleged crack purchase. The judge allowed the visit in the last trial, which ended with a jury hung 4-2 for acquittal. Barnwell's first trial ended in a mistrial before testimony began. Barnwell, 56, was arrested on Nov. 11, 1988, minutes after he bought two $2-vials of crack from a New York street dealer. His arrest sparked an investigation of local school boards when it was revealed that he had kept his job as principal of Public School 53 in the Bronx for 16 years despite a long record of absenteeism and tardiness. Barnwell was fired two weeks ago by his local school board, which carried out the recommendation of a disciplinary panel that found Barnwell had betrayed his pupils and ``the enormity of his act is clear.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Tells Africans Not to Be Embarrassed by Poverty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with speech today, pope leaving for Guinea-Bissau; pickup graf 10 pvs `The islands...'
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II told citizens of this impoverished island nation today that ``there is no shame in being poor.'' Later, he left for Guinea-Bissau, the second country on his tour of Africa's sub-Saharan nations. In a farewell speech to President Aristides Pereira, other officials and hundreds of faithful, the Roman Catholic leader said: ``I know the difficult problems that Cape Verde, like other countries of this region ... has to solve _and solve urgently.'' ``But I also know you can count on the tried and tested spirit of your people, who hold no illusions that the fight against the inclement climate and adverse social conditions will be easy.'' He reminded the people of this Atlantic island nation of a local proverb: ``There is no shame in being poor.'' In his final speech Friday to tens of thousands in this onetime slave-trading center, the pontiff appealed for an end to discrimination and modern-day slavery of all kinds. The pontiff was on his first visit to this 10-island archipelago about 380 miles west of Senegal in West Africa. He is on an eight-day tour of Africa's sub-Saharan Sahel region, which has long been plagued by drought, famine, and the spread of the desert. The 45th trip of the pope's 11-year papacy will also take him to Mali, Burkina Faso and Chad. Speaking at an open-air Mass on Quebra Canela beach near the capital Cidade da Praia, the pontiff said the former Portuguese colony still bore historic scars from the ``abominable commerce of human beings.'' Looking down from a custom-built altar onto the crowded, black volcanic beach, John Paul said his message was: ``No to discrimination of any kind, never slavery of man by man, never again any form of violence that degrades human dignity.'' This island nation, although arid and poor, appears more prosperous than other countries of the region thanks mainly to foreign aid and money sent back by thousands of islanders who live and work abroad. The United States provides $6 million a year to Cape Verde, making it the second-highest recipient per capita of U.S. foreign aid in Africa after Egypt, diplomats said. Up to 700,000 Cape Verdians _ nearly double the island population of 360,000 _ live and work abroad, mainly in the United States, Portugal, France, the Netherlands, and Italy. Up to 400,000 are estimated to live in Massachusetts and Rhode Island. The islands of Cape Verde first prospered in the 16th century as a major post for the Portuguese empire's slave trade between Africa and the Americas. With the demise of the slave trade, the largely desolate islands slid into decline as a colony of an increasingly isolated empire. Cape Verde gained independence from Portugal in 1975. Speaking in wind and rain, the pontiff also warned thousands of young islanders gathered at Praia's sports stadium against another form of slavery. He cautioned against ``moral slavery ... that threatens you most when you are the least aware ... (persuaded) by the subtle influence of the latest fashion or the dominant opinion.'' John Paul urged youths not ``to follow the idols of personal success, power, riches and eroticism.''

DOC.HEAD: Violent Three-Month Rail Strike Ends
DOC.TEXT: Black workers of the state transport company today halted one of South Africa's most violent strikes, a 12-week walkout marked by widespread sabotage and more than 35 killings. The union failed to win even part of its requested 150 percent pay increase, but South African Transport Services agreed to recognize the union and rehire all of the more than 23,000 strikers who were fired. Officials of the company and the South African Railway and Harbor Workers Union signed the settlement today at a ceremony in Johannesburg. Afterward, they said they hoped for smoother relations after two strikes in a three-year period. In the latest strike, the workers walked out Nov. 2, demanding that the minimum monthly wage be increased from $240 to $600. Numerous battles between strikers and non-strikers followed, including one clash between hundreds at a train station near Johannesburg. Railway coaches and tracks were sabotaged in dozens of incidents, and the company said it suffered property damage of $16 million. One key issue in the dispute was whether the transport service would officially recognize the strikers' union. The company maintained the union had not followed proper procedures for recognition, and insisted on bargaining with a smaller black union not tied to the militant Congress of South African Trade Unions. Jay Naidoo, general secretary of the congress, said at the signing ceremony today that the settlement ``laid the basis for a sound relationship'' between the union and the transport service. However, the Conservative Party's transport spokesman, Jurg Prinsloo, said, ``It is shocking that after one of the most violent strikes .. . the strikers have again been installed in their posts.'' The walkout was illegal under legislation that bars strikes in essential services. The transport company employs about 170,000 people and runs rail and harbor operations nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: White Extremists Scuffle With Protesters At Segregated Park
DOC.TEXT: Right-wing whites equipped with whips and clubs scuffled today with mixed-race demonstrators trying to hold a picnic at a whites-only park. The confrontation occurred at Boksburg Lake, a park that was declared whites-only in late 1988 after the far-right Conservative Party took control of Boksburg city council in municipal elections. About 100 residents of Reiger Park, a mixed-race neighborhood, arrived at the lakeside park this morning to picnic. Among the whites who confronted them were khaki-clad members of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement. No injuries were reported. But two white men were arrested after they tore down a protest banner that said: ``Mandela: The freedom of Boksburg awaits you.'' Jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela is expected to be freed soon after more than 27 years in prison. Residents of black and mixed-race communities adjoining the industrial city outside Johannesburg staged a 12-month consumer boycott of white-owned Boksburg stores. They called off the protest in December after President F.W. de Klerk proposed that Parliament, in its upcoming session, consider repealing the law that allows segregation of local facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Developments in the Soviet Bloc at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief summary of today's developments in the Soviet bloc.
DOC.HEAD: SOVIET UNION:
DOC.TEXT: Soviet forces consolidated their occupation of Azerbaijan by reportedly detaining 40 leaders of extremist groups. The Soviet media said the leaders were planning to capture administrative buildings and prisons in a bid to take power in their war-torn southern republic. The media said other extremist leaders have gone underground and are preparing ``new mass disorders.''
DOC.HEAD: ROMANIA:
DOC.TEXT: Four top associates of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu went on trial today, charged with abetting genocide, the official media said. The trial of Ceausescu's interior minister, Communist Party secretary and two Politburo members was nationally televised. It came one day after the vice president resigned from the provisional government, saying the leaders who replaced Ceausescu are resorting to ``Stalinistic methods.''
DOC.HEAD: POLAND:
DOC.TEXT: Poland's faltering Communist Party opened its final congress today with a surprise announcement by party chief Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski that he will not lead the leftist group that is to replace it. Rakowski said new leaders are needed in the party, which this year turned over governing power to the Solidarity movement after a disastrous defeat in multiparty elections.
DOC.HEAD: EAST GERMANY:
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Communists recommended today that foreign observers be invited to monitor the fairness of the nation's first free elections in May. The party newspaper said the election would gain credibility if it and the preceding campaign were observed by outsiders. Also today, Joachim Herrmann, a former Politburo member who controlled the state media in the Honecker regime, became the latest disgraced top official to be arrested.
DOC.HEAD: BULGARIA:
DOC.TEXT: The government said the military, police and other armed units will no longer be under the control of the Communist Party. The announcement Friday appeared to be an effort by the Communists, who still control the goverment, to bolster their sagging image before a key party congress starting Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest More Suspected Militants in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: Troops arrested suspected Moslem militants and searched houses today as they continued a weeklong crackdown on secessionist violence in Indian-held Kashmir that has killed more than 70 people. Sporadic gunfire was heard late Friday night, but there was no word of new casualties. A senior police official said soldiers in the northern Indian city of Srinagar were still looking for ``die-hard terrorists'' who slipped in despite a tough, 24-hour curfew. At least 72 people, mostly curfew-defying protesters, have been killed since Jan. 20 in Srinagar and surrounding towns. The separatists want to secede from predominantly Hindu India and establish an independent Kashmiri nation or join the neighboring Islamic country of Pakistan. ``The situation is well under control,'' said Jitendra Narain Saxena, the top police official in Jammu-Kashmir state, by telephone. ``We have enforced very strict curfew because we have information that die-hard terrorists have infiltrated into Srinagar.'' As a result of search operations Friday night and early today ``some arrests'' have been made, Saxena said. He refused to give any numbers. A virtual news blackout was imposed Thursday night when local officials rescinded journalists' curfew passes and warned them that they risked arrest or getting shot if they tried to leave their hotel. Most communication with the hotel was cut off at the same time. On Friday, while most of India celebrated the 40th anniversary of the constitution that marked the founding of the Indian Republic, Srinagar resembled a ghost town with only military patrols and a few officials allowed on the streets. A gasoline bomb was thrown at soldiers, but no one was injured, according to police sources in Jammu, the winter capital of Jammu-Kashmir state. Across the frontier, the leader of Pakistan-held Kashmir threatened Friday to launch a jihad, or Islamic holy war, unless the United Nations calls a special session on Kashmir before Feb. 17. Sikander Hyat Khan demanded the United Nations take action on its 1948 resolution calling for Kashmiris to vote on whether they want independence or union with either Pakistan or India. The plebiscite was never held, and the Kashmir question has simmered for four decades. India and Pakistan have gone to war twice over Kashmir since they became independent from Britain in 1947. Jammu-Kashmir is the only state in India with a Moslem majority. Moslems make up 64 percent of the state's 5 million people, but nationwide they form only 12 percent of the population of 880 million.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Rebels Attack Philippine Villages
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 Moslem rebels today attacked six predominantly Christian villages, killing at least one person and causing thousands of residents to flee, the military said. An undetermined number of other people _ villagers, soldiers, and rebels _ were reported killed or wounded. Brig. Gen. Orlando Soriano, army regional commander, said the simultaneous attacks took place around 1 a.m. in the southern villages outside Pikit town in North Cotabato province, 590 miles southeast of Manila. The Moslem separatists assaulted and burned several homes, forcing more than 5,000 villagers to leave and seek shelter in government buildings and schoolhouses in Pikit, Soriano said. He said at least one woman villager died in the cross fire. Government troops, backed by two helicopter gunships and mortar fire, were sent to aid village militiamen. They counterattacked in areas where rebels were believed to be hiding. Soriano ordered troops to stop the counterattacks 16 hours after the rebels assaulted the villages. Government representatives, led by Norodin Matalam, governor of the nearby province of Maguindanao, was to negotiate with the rebels' Moro Islamic Liberation Front. The rebels attacked to avenge the massacre of five members of a Moslem family in October by suspected Christian militiamen, Matalam told reporters. On Nov. 19, 1989, several southern provinces and cities vote in favor of a regional autonony plan proposed by President Corazon Aquino in an effort to placate the demands of Moslem secessionists.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Calls for Foreign Election Monitors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with offer for foreign observers to monitor balloting, former propaganda chief arrest. Pickup 9th pvs, `But the...' TRIMS.
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Communists today said foreign observers should be invited to monitor the nation's first competitive elections in May as ``an additional safeguard'' to ensure free balloting. Also today, the propaganda chief under ousted Communist leader Erich Honecker was arrested and officials were investigating charges of high treason against him, the official news agency ADN. A front-page editorial in the party daily Neues Deutschland said having a team of foreign observers monitor the campaign and elections would be ``good and practical.'' The paper urged opposition groups to accept the proposal, which has been proposed to Parliament by interim President Manfred Gerlach, a member of one of the non-Communist parties in Communist Premier Hans Modrow's coalition government. ``Even if all precautions are taken for free and fair elections, an additional safeguard cannot hurt,'' Neues Deutschland said. The development is the latest effort by the Communists to buoy their standing since a pro-democracy revolution toppled Honecker on Oct. 18, opened the Berlin Wall and set up the coalition government. ADN said former propaganda chief Joachim Herrmann was arrested, and it quoted the chief prosecutor as saying he was also being investigated for his alleged ``responsibility for the unconstitutional media policy of past years.'' Herrmann, 61, was the top propaganda official in the now-dissolved Communist Party Central Committee, a post through which the Communists controlled national media, including television and radio. The office also ordered the arrest of Gerhard Schuerer, former head of the State Planning Commission, on corruption charges, ADN said. Herrmann and Schuerer, the latest officials under Honecker to be ordered arrested, were kicked out of the party Jan. 20. New Forum, the largest opposition movement but one of its most diffuse, began a two-day congress in East Berlin today. About 150 delegates of a breakaway group today gathered in Karl-Marx-Stadt to form the German Forum Party. A delegate, Frank-Thomas Heinze, said the party will advocate free-market concepts and German unity, according to ADN. On Friday, opposition groups agreed to join Modrow's shaky government in an effort to keep it afloat until scheduled elections in May. But the reform forces said they will participate only if all members of Modrow's coalition Cabinet renounce their party loyalties. It was not immediately clear if Modrow or the other ministers were willing to serve in such a non-partisan capacity. The show of unity from a splintered opposition suggested that the reformists feel the risk of domestic chaos outweighs their own concerns of being tainted by association with the current leadership. ``It is simply becoming clear that our responsibility is to keep the country governable,'' Wolfgang Schnur, chairman of the conservative Democratic Awakening movement, said on West Germany's ZDF television. In joining the government, the opposition also seems to be hoping it will benefit from any national exposure, and get some credit for guiding the country through an uncertain reform phase until the May 6 vote. Opposition representatives declined to say which ministerial posts they will demand when they open talks with Modrow on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Claim Capture of Azerbaijani Nationalist Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with new casualty figures, number of extremists arrested, details of strikes and weapons in hands of nationalists. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet forces found a weapons arsenal and captured Azerbaijani nationalist leaders accused of trying to seize control of the tense republic, Soviet media said today. Forty leaders of extremist groups allegedly linked to the nationalist Azerbaijani People's Front were being held, Komsomolskaya Pravda said, quoting Lt. Col. A. Sorokovikh, a police official. The daily Trud said more than 1,000 uniforms and a large cache of arms were found in the front's headquarters. The newspaper said that some leaders of the front had gone underground and were preparing ``new mass disorders.'' The Tass news agency said that Rakhmi Gadzhiyev, identified as one of the leaders of the front, had been arrested. Nearly 150 people were detained overnight in the Azerbaijani capital of Baku by Soviet troops, who intervened last week in an effort to quell ethnic bloodshed between Christian Armenians and Moslem Azerbaijanis. Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov told Soviet journalists in Baku on Friday that troops were forced to enter Jan. 19 because nationalists were trying to take control of the republic. Earlier reports had suggested the occupation was designed to stop attacks on minority Armenians in Baku. Also Friday, Baltic activists said Azerbaijani and Armenian representatives tentatively agreed to negotiate their ethnic dispute next week in Riga, Latvia. However, Romaldus Razhukas, a director of the Latvian People's Front, said in a telephone interview from Riga that the Azerbaijanis will hold direct talks only if the Armenians renounce their claim to part of Azerbaijan's territory. The Armenians have demanded that the Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan, a predominantly Armenian enclave, be united with Armenia. The Azerbaijanis want to limit the talks to refugees, humanitarian issues and securing the withdrawal of Soviet troops. Activists in the Baltic republics have something of a stake in peacefully resolving the ethnic strife in Azerbaijan. They fear that the continued use of force by Moscow could set the stage for similar intervention in their own pro-independence republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. The Tass news agency said today it is becoming more difficult to find housing for growing numbers of refugees from Azerbaijan. It did not give the nationalities of the refugees, but it recent days more Russians have been fleeing in the face of growing anti-Russian tension. Baku, the scene of heavy fighting earlier in the week, was reported to be calmer today. Stores were beginning to open, although there were shortages and long lines, Trud reported. Strikes continued to paralyze the region with 400 enterprises at a standstill in Baku alone, Komsomolskaya Pravda reported. The Soviet military intervened after Azerbaijani extremists began killing Armenians living in Baku on Jan. 13. The military raid has drawn criticism and support in the country and abroad as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev struggles with perhaps the most difficult of the nation's many crises. In remarks published by the government newspaper Izvestia, Yazov appeared to stress that controlling the political situation was the reason for the Soviet military action. He said the People's Front had declared its own state of emergency in Baku a full day before the soldiers moved in, and ``in many regions of the city ... Soviet and party organs had ceased to control the situation.'' Previously, Gorbachev and other top officials have cited public safety _ dozens of people were killed during anti-Armenian riots in Baku _ as the reason for the military assault. But critics of the military move have contended that most of the Armenians had been evacuated before the army moved into Baku. Azerbaijani nationalists have accused Moscow of trying to crush their movement. Tass said today that 125 people, including 27 soldiers and police, had died during the assault by Soviet forces on Baku and the ensuing battle with nationalists. In an interview published today in Komsomolskaya Pravda, Yazov said that an estimated 40,000 weapons were in the hands of the population in Azerbaijan.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Meet to Overhaul Party; Party Chief to Step Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 4 grafs after 8th, `A schism...' to UPDATE with Rakowski trying to prevent party split, other quotes. Pickup 9th pvs, `Rakowski appealed...'
DOC.TEXT: Communist leaders met today to dismantle their faltering party and replace it with a pro-democracy group. Party chief Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski announced that he will not lead the new organization. Rakowski said it was time for ``a new generation'' to take over the party, which this year relinquished power to the Solidarity movement after a disastrous defeat in Poland's freest elections since World War II. The weekend congress planned to expunge the party of its of Communist ideology, endorse parliamentary democracy and create a new social democratic organization. The party, formally known now as the Polish United Workers Party, hopes its new incarnation will become the main left-wing party in a new democratic political spectrum. ``I consider it appropriate to pass over the helm to a new generation,'' said Rakowski at the close of an hour-long speech reviewing the party's past and the future at the start of the congress. ``I personally am not going to run for leadership of the party and I think that comrades of my generation will not do so.'' More than 1,600 delegates gathered at Congress Hall in Warsaw's imposing Stalinist-era Palace of Culture and Science. The party now claims 2 million members, but the group that emerges from the congress will be much smaller, said party Politburo member Janusz Reykowski in an interview Thursday. A schism is possible with either orthodox Communists or progressives leaving to form their own parties, he said. Rakowski appealed to delegates to prevent a split. ``If we want to exist as a real force in the Polish political scene, we should not leave the Congress Hall through different exits,'' he said. Rakowski said he struggled to reform the party since the Stalin era ended in 1956, but failed because many members clung to old ideas and the Soviet Union interfered with reforms until the emergence of Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1985. ``It's true that we deserved a good whipping,'' he said of the past. But he said the Polish party also deserved credit for being ``braver'' than its East bloc counterparts in carrying out reforms. He praised President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former party chief, for the decision a year ago to lift the ban on Solidarity. Lech Walesa, leader of the Solidarity trade union movement that forced Poland's changes, and the Communist Party's delegation in parliament have supported parliament deputy Tadeusz Fiszbach, 54, to be the reformed party's new leader. Fiszbach is a former Gdansk party chief ousted from official positions in the 1980s because he opposed the 1981 imposition of martial law. Rakowski, 65, said early in January that he also would run for the top spot. But he appeared to be reconsidering this week in the face of opposition from those who argued that the new party stands no chance unless it introduces an entirely new leadership. Reykowski had also said it might be time for a ``clear generational change.'' Possible candidates include Slawomir Wiatr, 37, the founder of a liberal faction in the party; Aleksander Kwasniewski, 35, who is in charge of national sports and recreation; and Leszek Miller, 43, a party secretary and Rakowski loyalist. The Communist Party was a merger forced by Soviet leader Josef Stalin of the Communist Polish Workers Party and the Polish Socialist Party, a left-wing party dating from the 19th century that enjoyed broad popular support. Now the party says it wants to give up the Communist part of that heritage and build on the old socialist tradition.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Archbishop Who Battled Over Funding Dies in Canada
DOC.TEXT: Anglican Archbishop Lewis Garnsworthy, an outspoken cleric who tangled with political leaders over school funding and once scolded his own church for being too ``respectable,'' has died. He was 67. A church spokesman said Garnsworthy died in his sleep Friday at Toronto Western Hospital, where he had been admitted last weekend. No cause of death was given. However, in 1983 Garnsworthy had a cancerous lung removed. Two years ago, he had abdominal surgery to remove a tumor. Garnsworthy, a tall, stern-faced man with a booming voice, tackled some of the church's thorniest questions and often expressed what others left unsaid. ``He constantly raised issues people had to struggle with,'' said the Rev. Elizabeth Kilbourn, who was ordained by Garnsworthy to become one of denomination's first women ministers. ``He wasn't a wimp.'' He once said a proposed union of the Anglican and United churches had a ``snowball's chance in Hades.'' He criticized the Roman Catholic Church for its ``fortress mentality.'' He also derided his own Anglican church of the 1940s as ``a sort of mascot at cocktail parties _ part of the respectable scene.'' He once described many church services as boring and called for the burning of church pews and the melting down of collection plates. Garnsworthy, who was born in Edmonton, studied theology at Wycliffe College in Toronto. He was ordained into the priesthood in 1946 and served in Halifax before coming back to Toronto. In 1972, he took over as the ninth bishop of Toronto, the largest Anglican diocese in Canada. He said he wanted to reach out to secular society. Elected Archbishop of Ontario in 1979, Garnsworthy's later battled then Premier William Davis' plan to extend funds to Catholic school on a separate basis from the public system. Garnsworthy favored one publicly funded system. A week before the election, he compared Davis to Adolf Hitler for making the decision ``by decree.'' The archbishop lost that fight, but some angry Conservatives later blamed him after the 1985 provincial election ended the party's 43-year dynasty in Ontario. Garnsworthy, who retired in 1988, is survived by his wife Jean, a son and daughter and a granddaughter. A funeral service will be held Monday at St. James Cathedral in Toronto.

DOC.HEAD: First Trial of Top Ceausescu Associates Begins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with charges read, Politburo member saying he helped Ceausescu with order. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A nationally televised trial began today for four former associates of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu charged with participating in a crackdown that led to thousands of deaths during the revolution. One of those on trial, former Poliburo member Ion Dinca, testified he helped Ceausescu ``put into practice the criminal measures to suffocate in blood the justified revolution of the people.'' The four were being tried by a panel of five uniformed military judges in a hall seating hundreds of people at the Romanian military academy in Bucharest. The trial is the first of top associates of Ceausescu, whose brutal 24-year rule ended in a popular revolution in December. Prosecuting Ceausescu loyalists is a key test of the provisional government, which is struggling to gain the support of the people and has promised free elections in May.
