Kissinger gave Gorbachev ``at best'' a 50-50 chance to survive the nationality and other crises threatening his rule. The Kremlin leader's greatest assets, he said, are that ``he has established an extraordinary position in the outside world, and secondly the mess inside the Soviet Union is so great that no alternative leader wants to take over.'' Kissinger said in a TV interview earlier this month Gorbachev might survive secession of the Baltic states but not the loss of more central Soviet republics now shaken by an upsurge of nationalism. He said the Kremlin currently is using more force than needed to quell clashes between Armenians and Azerbaijanis in the Soviet Union's southern republic of Azerbaijan. Kissinger said the ``real motive for the massive Soviet intervention is to keep Azerbaijan in the Soviet Union ... to demonstrate that the center cannot be defied with impunity.''

DOC.HEAD: Black Woman Accuses Black Boss of Skin-Color Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: Trial begins Tuesday in a unique race discrimination case with legal and social implications: A black woman fired by the IRS is suing her boss, a darker-skinned black woman, claiming discrimination because of color. Tracy Lynn Morrow would become the first black worker to collect damages from a black supervisor because of skin-shade discrimination, according to her attorney and federal equal opportunity officials. U.S. District Judge Charles Moye ruled last spring that such light vs. dark, black-on-black discrimination is possible and that the issue should be decided in court. Ms. Morrow contends that she was targeted for harassment because of her skin tone. Her boss, Ruby Lewis, contends that Ms. Morrow _ then Tracy Lynn Walker _ was error-prone, belligerent, frequently late and dishonest. Ms. Morrow, a former Internal Revenue Service temporary employee in Seattle, was hired in Atlanta as a clerk-typist in 1985. She entered probation for a permanent position on Dec. 9, 1985, but was fired on March 14, 1986. A race relations expert in Atlanta, Charles King, believes Ms. Morrow will have a tough time proving discrimination because both sides acknowledge the position eventually was filled with another black woman. ``The whole thing is lamentable, that the courts would accept this as discrimination,'' said King, nationally known for his confrontational race relations seminars. ``To me, it's interesting, but logistically and logically, there's no case.'' Ms. Morrow's attorney, Stephen Katz, disagrees. The judge, he noted, has already ascertained that Ms. Morrow is a member of what is known in the law as a ``protected class.'' Now, he said, she must prove that she was improperly replaced by someone outside the protected class, or show direct evidence of discrimination. Katz declined to discuss his evidence before trial, but said he is confident he can prove discrimination. The non-jury trial is expected to take about four days. Ms. Lewis and Ms. Morrow's earlier boss, a white woman, Virginia Fite, gave depositions indicating Ms. Morrow was repeatedly cited for tardiness and poor work. Ms. Fite said the employee showed an ``inability to write,'' had a ``stubborn or immature'' attitude and prompted the personnel office to report ``she was driving them crazy'' complaining about things. Her work was ``just adequate,'' Ms. Fite said. Ms. Lewis contended that Ms. Morrow ``became more demanding'' after she was made a permanent employee, made increasing errors amid a ``further deterioration of attitude and conduct'' after a leave request was denied, and finally lied about crucial mistakes she had made. Ms. Lewis said she has never been prejudiced on the grounds of race or color. Ms. Fite backed her up, saying Ms. Lewis was ``not someone who would discriminate for any reason, and certainly not for race.'' And Ms. Lewis said she never regarded Ms. Morrow as fair-skinned anyway _ rather as ``medium brown,'' the same as she is. Katz said Ms. Morrow would prefer not to discuss the case before trial. But he said he would show the unfavorable reviews of Ms. Morrow's job performance are not accurate. Ms. Morrow is seeking reinstatement and up to $60,000 in back pay and other payments. She has since found employment with a car rental agency but would prefer to resume her job in government, Katz said. ``It's good work if you can get it,'' he said. The judge, in certifying the case for trial, said there is ``evidence that Ms. Lewis might have harbored resentful feelings towards white people, and therefore by inference, possibly towards light-skinned black people.'' King said black-on-black discrimination ``has its basis in blacks adapting white institutional attitudes and behavior patterns. It's not that blacks are discriminating against blacks, but they try to conform to white standards and procedures. ``Also, there is a class struggle within the black race, based upon complexion,'' he said. He said darker complexioned blacks may transmit hostility they have toward white people toward light-complexioned blacks who display ``conformity to white behavioral patterns.''

DOC.HEAD: Darman Waxes Somewhat Poetic in Budget Message
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 13th graf pvs, bgng: Darman asks, to CORRECT quote attribution to Browning, sted Shakespeare
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Budget Director Richard G. Darman will liken the federal budget to a voracious ``Cookie Monster'' in a fanciful message to Congress that also will warn lawmakers against expecting a ``peace dividend'' from reduced tensions in Eastern Europe. ``The budget, for all its intimidating detail might be seen ... as the Ultimate Cookie Monster,'' Darman will assert in an introduction to Bush's $1.2 trillion fiscal 1991 budget. ``Its excess tendencies toward consumption are not exactly ennobling. ... But at the same time, its underlying motivation is clearly not malevolent. What harm it might cause is largely unintended,'' Darman writes. Darman, in the introduction to be formally released with the budget on Monday, tells Congress that the job of responsible public officials is to seek to get the cookie monster under control. Darman also will caution lawmakers against seeking a ``wonderland'' in which military savings can be diverted to domestic programs. ``The near-term `peace dividend' is likely to be smaller than commonly assumed,'' Darman says in his introduction. Some members of Congress have proposed that the reductions in military tensions in Eastern Europe can be turned into a so-called peace dividend and spent on expanding social programs. Darman, however, tells Congress it would be ``naively euphoric'' to expect that the crumbling of the Soviet empire will spell a final end to East-West tensions. Still, Bush's budget will propose an austere $292.1 billion in Pentagon spending for the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1, representing the lowest increase in more than a decade and an actual reduction of about 2 percent if inflation is taken into account, according to administration sources. Excerpts from Darman's introduction were first published in Saturday's editions of The New York Times and later confirmed by administration officials. Darman asserts that the ``great historical shift'' in Eastern Europe ``has been almost trivialized in its translation into public debate about the budget. The issue has been framed as ``how big is the peace dividend'' and, in effect, ``how can I get mine?'' He said the prime objective of the budget was not to find other ways of spending military savings, but ``how can it best preserve and build on America's strengths.'' Darman asks in his partly whimsical introduction: ``How big is the deficit?'' And, paraphrasing Elizabeth Barrett Browning, he answers the question: ``Let me count the ways.'' Darman also will tell Congress that many programs in the budget are like the hungry monsters in ``Pac Man'' the popular video game, ``waiting to spring forward and consume another line of resources dots in the budget maze.'' But, then he adds: ``At some point, it is appropriate to put games aside _ at least for a while. At some point, there is an obligation to be serious.'' ``At some point, partisan posturing must yield to the responsibility to govern.'' Darman also weighs in on the current controversy over Social Security funding. Bush's budget proposes no change in either benefits or taxes, but would use surpluses in the system after the year 1993 _ when the annual budget is required to be balanced under the Gramm-Rudman law _ to help pay off the national debt. By contrast, a popular proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., would roll back the Social Security tax increase that took effect in January and reduce it further next year. Darman calls the Moynihan plan a ``superficially attractive proposal.'' But the budget director asserts that, in reality, cutting the Social Security tax at this time would either force the government to raise other taxes to offset the loss in revenues, or lead to a reduction in benefits. ``The president's proposal ... is a responsible way to protect the future interests of today's workers,'' Darman says. However, he concedes, ``Social Security is a notoriously volatile subject when it enters the political domain. And whether rationality will prevail remains to be determined.'' ``This year's budget meets the responsibility to be serious,'' Darman says in his not-completely-serious introduction. ``This, of course, is not to assert that the budget will be treated seriously in the very next `beat-the-budget' game. It is simply to suggest that it should be.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Poll Ratings Don't Sway Congress
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 5th graf, The president, to CORRECT that Bush had three, sted four, more votes than needed to override veto; only one of the four votes against override was needed to block it. Also moved in advance Jan. 25 as b0769
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is dealing with the reconvened Democratic Congress from a position some of his predecessors would have used to get votesor get even. It doesn't seem to work that way for Bush. Lyndon B. Johnson twisted congressional arms to gain support for his proposals, and called it reasoning together. Ronald Reagan said that if Congress didn't see the light, his way, he would make them feel the heat. Their hardball lobbyists offered political rewards, threatened punishments, using the popularity of their presidents and warning that straying members might pay at the polls. Bush opens the 1990 campaign year with job approval ratings that surpass the first-year standing of those predecessors and that haven't been matched since John F. Kennedy. But so far, at least, his personal popularity has not been convertible into lobbying clout in Congress. The president did use some old-fashioned lobbying to get his way in the first test of the year, finding three votes more than he needed on Thursday to sustain his veto of a bill to extend the visas of Chinese students, a step he said he already had taken with presidential powers. He'd been told he would lose on the veto, even by the head-counting Republican whips of both the House and the Senate. They were half right; the House overrode 390 to 25. The Senate failed to do so, 62 to 37. Bush and his lobbying allies used party loyalty, presidential prerogatives and the argument that the vetoed bill was redundant in the two-day drive that turned it around. Because the issue was a veto, the president needed only a minority to keep the Senate count below the two-thirds it takes to override. That's enough when the objective is to stop something from happening. It takes majorities to change things or to start new ones. Bush has the poll numbers, but he doesn't have the coattails Reagan showed in his first presidential election. Reagan had grounds to claim a mandate for major change in government, and he had a conservative movement behind it. That gave his lieutenants a network that could apply pressure from home districts on wavering congressmen as the administration built its coalition of Republicans and conservative Democrats in the House. Reagan also had the most saleable of issues in his first year _ the income tax cut that had been a centerpiece of his campaign. Enacting it and pruning down the size and power of government were his mandate. Bush was elected to carry on, to make it all work despite giant budget deficits left in part because taxes were indeed cut but government shrank little, if at all, under Reagan. Bush has a leftover tax cut to push, a capital gains reduction that is likely to be passed this year. But he also is confronted with the risk of a runaway toward the Social Security tax cut proposed by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y. His State of the Union address on Wednesday night is likely to restate familiar proposals and priorities rather than seek new ones, and to be coupled with a renewed call for bipartisanship. With neither the money nor the inclination to undertake major new programs at home, Bush is sure to emphasize successes abroad as he keynotes the election-year congressional session. Seeking to head off the inevitable pressure for peace dividend cuts in the defense budget, Bush said in advance that he will soon present a new military plan of his own, ``to restructure America's defenses in the wake of the dramatic changes that are taking place abroad.'' The defense budget he will present on Monday seeks an increase in Pentagon spending, but Bush said it will begin ``the transition to a restructured military, a new strategy that is more flexible, more geared to contingencies outside of Europe while continuing to meet our inescapable responsibility to NATO and to maintaining the global balance.'' Bush also will ask Congress to promote the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet rank. That will be the 15th seat at the Cabinet table. Overall, it is a manager's agenda, not a script for dramatic change or a catalog of Republican issues for the campaign year. Bush said going in that his agenda was not one of drastic change but of building on eight years of Republican administration under Reagan. The major arena of change in 1989 was outside his reach, although it certainly worked to his benefit. The administration and Congress could only react and respond to the largely peaceful revolution that undid communist dominance in Eastern Europe. For a while, Democratic leaders criticized Bush, saying he was too timid and too passive. But the issue didn't take. Republicans are trying to make Eastern Europe into a 1990 issue on their own terms, contending their military and foreign policies created the conditions for change. ``Freedom and democracy are breaking out across this entire planet,'' Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater told party leaders. ``I guarantee you that would not be happening today if it were not for a decade of leadership by Ronald Reagan and George Bush.'' The guarantee is debatable, but there is no question that Bush has been buoyed by those changes and by public support for his intervention in Panama. For all of that, there is no sign that his current popularity will enable the administration to move many votes, or to build a Reagan-style coalition in Congress. That has more to do with the last election than with the latest polls. In winning the White House, Bush saw his Republican ticket lose strength in Congress. Democrats gained three seats in the House, one in the Senate. A winning presidential candidate usually leads his party to congressional gains, but Bush did not. He ran weaker than congressional candidates in 389 of the 435 House districts. Off-year elections historically are difficult for the president's party. The White House party hasn't gained House seats in an off year since 1934.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Insists Benefits of Attending Drug Summit Outweigh Risks
DOC.TEXT: The White House is receiving ``a lot of phone calls'' urging President Bush not to go to a drug summit in Colombia but he has decided that any risks to his security are outweighed by other factors, his chief of staff says. ``He understands the pluses and minuses. There are a lot of hard decisions in this ... and not every decision is all plus,'' said John Sununu. Colombia has been wracked by bombings, shootings and kidnappings ever since President Virgilio Barco declared war on the country's cocaine drug lords last year. By some accounts, drug barons have put out a $30 million assassination contract on Bush and are trying to buy surface-to-air missiles to shoot down his plane when he travels to Cartagena for an meeting Feb. 15 with Barco and officials of Bolivia and Peru. While reaffirming that Bush will attend the summit, Sununu said the White House is taking extraordinary steps for his protection. ``This is critical enough that whatever we decide in terms of logistics and timing, we will probably keep as close to the vest until the very last minute,'' he said in an interview Friday with five reporters. ``We have three or four alternatives that are reasonably comfortable alternatives and we're trying to work with all the South American countries involved to make sure that everybody feels comfortable with the options we're looking at,'' he said. ``We'll pick _ probably at the last minute _ one option,'' he said. For example, sources say the travel arrangements are being reviewed. Rather than go into Cartagena on Air Force One, Bush might fly somewhere else, perhaps spend some time on an aircraft carrier and then take a helicopter to the summit. Sununu said all of the options involve going to Colombia. He said Bush weighed the risks and determined ``the pluses outweigh the minuses. We ought to be going to Cartagena.'' Acknowledging apprehensions about Bush's trip, Sununu said, ``I told the president we're getting a lot of phone calls, and I communicated that to him.'' Another security issue being examined is where to put the press corps and White House press staff that traditionally accompany the president. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said last week the press operation probably would be based in another country, such as Costa Rica, Venezuela or Panama. However, a number of reporters and news organizations have objected to that idea, and Fitzwater now says the decision could go either way. Commenting on that topic, Sununu said, ``Frankly, the hard part that we have to deal with ... is that we really don't have a structure for full protection of people beyond the president. ``That's a real concern, that we don't have a security structure that extends that far out in the circle of the onion layer,'' he said. ``And so, we are looking for combinations that allow us to use the inherent security we have for the president and, if you will, the logistics and the geography to the best benefit of everybody else that is there.''

DOC.HEAD: Baby Girl Found, Returned to Mother
LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: A baby girl stolen when she was 36 hours old snuggled in her mother's arms again Saturday after police found the child safe and well in a rented cottage. ``She looks exactly the same as she was before,'' Dawn Griffiths said Saturday as she held her baby, Alexandra, at St. Thomas' Hospital, where the child was stolen Jan. 11. Acting on a tip, police found the baby Friday night in Burford, 65 miles northwest of London. The infant was in the care of a 35-year-old woman at a cottage known as the Old Police House, the village's former police station. Scotland Yard said the woman had been arrested, but a spokesman said her name would not be released unless she was charged. Police said the baby was taken by a woman who claimed to be a health service aide and told Miss Griffiths she needed to give the baby a routine blood test. The abduction and the anguish of Miss Griffiths, 20, and the baby's father, Geoffrey Harris, 25, was front-page news during their 15-day ordeal. Their appeals for the return of their daughter were broadcast on television and radio. Detective Chief Superintendent John Bassett, the police officer in charge of the hunt, said detectives recovered the baby after a tip by neighbors. Bassett said the arrested woman answered the door when the detectives arrived. They found the baby asleep in an upstairs room, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Statehood Advocates Hope to Prevail Despite Barry Arrest
DOC.TEXT: Advocates of statehood for the nation's capital plan to make sure their message will not be lost in the turmoil caused by Mayor Marion Barry's cocaine possession arrest. Any tourists wishing to visit the Vista Hotel, where Barry allegedly smoked crack cocaine, first will have to pass signs advising them that they are entering the ``nation's last colony.'' Barry's arrest Jan. 18 on a federal charge of possessing cocaine has focused attention on his crumbling political fortunes and a possible mayoral candidacy by Jesse Jackson. But it has also stirred a quieter debate over the impact on a long-moribund drive to make the city the 51st state. ``Clearly this sets that back,'' Rep. Stan Parris, R-Va., a city critic, said last week after Barry's arrest. ``There is not an organized crescendo'' (against home rule), he said. ``There is an increased discussion about whether this thing is really working.'' Jackson has taken up the statehood cause, regardless of whether it leads to a personal candidacy. ``Maryland was not disenfranchised when (Gov. Marvin) Mandel went to jail,'' the two-time Democratic presidential hopeful said last week. ``There is no valid argument for denying statehood to the nearly 700,000 people who live here.'' Residents of the District of Columbia have no voting representatives in Congress, even though the city claims a larger population than either Delaware, North Dakota, Vermont or Wyoming. The city's budget must be approved by Congress, and the House and Senate have permanent committees to oversee the district's affairs. Congress approved home rule in 1974 _ Barry is only the city's second mayor to be elected _ but took back some of the powers 15 years later. Both houses passed a proposed constitutional amendment for statehood in 1978, but it expired seven years later when only 16 of the required 38 states ratified it. New legislation is expected to be introduced in Congress again in the near future. But before the district's chances for statehood are improved, touchy issues having nothing to do with the mayor need to be resolved. One is the question of whether the city should still get an annual payment from the federal government. Another is the difficulty of winning Republican support for statehood when the district, with its overwhelmingly black population, almost certainly would wind up with two Democratic senators. The view from the pro-statehood forces, not surprisingly, is that Barry's arrest will not do lasting harm. ``We will persevere,'' said Josephine Butler, chairwoman of the district's statehood commission. ``His arrest is important, but it is a short-term thing, while statehood is enduring. Statehood has been a long and tedious process, and we will overcome this and our other problems.'' The board is advertising the city's unique status with road signs that say, ``Welcome to the Nation's Last Colony. All residents must leave their rights at the border. D.C. Statehood Now.'' Walter Fauntroy, the city's non-voting delegate in the House, sees a possible silver lining in Barry's difficulties. Envisioning a city with a new mayor, Fauntroy said, ``Members of Congress who would use a man who admittedly has a problem ... no longer have that excuse.'' Whatever the impact on the city, there is no doubting the effect on Barry's fortunes. Longtime Barry fund-raiser Robert Johnson, president of Black Entertainment Television, said he would not back any re-election effort by the mayor. Several influential ministers said likewise, as did a prominent business group that has supported the city's leader in the past. Barry, who entered a private treatment facility in West Palm Beach, Fla., for what an aide said was treatment of alcoholism, has not said publicly what his political plans are, but sources have said he has said he would not seek a new term. With each new sign that Barry's political career may be doomed, more attention is paid to Jackson, whose move to the nation's capital last year fueled rumors that he might make a bid for the mayor's chair. Through the week, the mystery surrounding Jackson remained the same: he said time and again that he is not interested in running for mayor; he also repeatedly refused to rule out the possibility that he might get into the race if Barry bows out. ``A public servant ... never says never,'' Jackson said. Meanwhile, a group of prominent local labor leaders and businessmen held a pair of meetings to devise a draft-Jackson strategy; a separate group of attorneys did the same thing.

DOC.HEAD: `Robin HUD' Says She'll Plead Guilty To in HUD Thefts Plea Bargain
DOC.TEXT: A real estate agent dubbed ``Robin HUD'' after admitting she stole millions of dollars in federal housing funds and gave some money to the poor says she has decided to accept a bargain with prosecutors and plead guilty to two counts. ``I don't want to spend taxpayers' money in a court proceeding,'' Marilyn Louise Harrell told The Sun in Baltimore on Friday. Harrell, 46, of Waldorf has admitted taking millions in U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development money, and said she has prepared herself for imprisonment since 1985, when she first started diverting HUD funds. Scheduled to appear Monday in U.S. District Court, Harrell said she hopes to be sentenced to perform community service, but regards prison as a chance to get a college degree. ``I told the kids (her son, John, and his wife, Vicki), just think of it as Mom going away a few years for college,'' said Harrell, who will become a grandmother sometime next month. In a deal with the U.S. attorney's office, Harrell said she will plead guilty to stealing government property and failing to report income for taxes. In return, prosecutors will drop two other tax counts, two counts of lying to HUD and one count of lying to a bank on a loan application, Harrell said. She was to go to trial on those charges Monday. If convicted on all counts, she would have faced a maximum of 31 years in prison and more than $1 million in fines. The two charges she says she will admit to Monday carry a maximum sentence of 13 years in prison. But under federal sentencing guidelines, she could serve 2{ to 3 years in prison, Harrell said. Harrell's attorney, Anthony R. Gallagher, declined to comment Friday, as did Gary P. Jordan, first assistant U.S. attorney, the newspaper said. Attempts by The Associated Press to reach them by telephone Saturday were unsuccessful; there was no answer at their offices and their home numbers are unlisted. There was no answer at Harrell's home Saturday. Harrell, who confessed her crimes to government officials in December 1988, became a symbol of mismanagement at HUD when scandal erupted there last summer. Following her indictment last November, U.S. Attorney General Richard L. Thornburgh said the case was the single largest involving the theft of federal funds by an individual. Harrell went against the advice of her attorney and freely discussed taking the money in testimony before Congress and in several nationally televised interviews. ``I never did have a problem with pleading guilty on No. 1, the embezzlement charge,'' Harrell said. ``Obviously, that's something that's known nationwide.'' Prosecutors say Harrell took at least $5.67 million from sales of HUD properties she handled as a private escrow agent. Prosecutors acknowledge that some money went to charities, but say much of it went to Harrell and her family. Harrell said she has documents to prove that she took only $4.75 million in HUD funds and that ``less than 6 percent'' of the money benefited her family. Many charities and individuals acknowledge having received thousands of dollars in gifts and donations from Harrell, but she has said she does not want those people to testify on her behalf. ``I really truthfully consider it an honor to give up years of my life to help some of the people I've helped,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Refugees Recall Military Horrors
DOC.TEXT: Keson Kaleu was able to save three of her own children and four of a stranger's. But when she arrived in this Ivorian village, she broke down and cried for the son she said was shot by Liberian soldiers. ``They killed my child,'' the young woman wailed as she limped into Kanta Yole, ending a two-day trek through dense forest and across the Cavally River. Here, 300 Ivorian villagers are sharing their homes and meager food supplies with more than 900 people who say they survived a massacre by Liberian government troops. Bloodshed began Dec. 24 when rebels supporting former civil servant Charles Taylor tried to overthrow the government of President Samuel Doe. Government troops were sent in to put down rebel attacks in eastern Liberia, and a Western diplomat and an Ivorian official said Thursday the soldiers had killed about 500 civilians. Liberian officials say troops shot some civilians, but only armed civilians who attacked them. The Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said rebels retaliated by moving south and slaughtering citizens from Doe's Krahn tribe, one of several ethnic groups in Liberia. Ivorian officials and international aid agency workers visiting Kanta Yole when Mrs. Kaleu arrived during the weekend asked her to describe the killing of her son. But she was too distraught even to repeat his name. ``They just shot him down as we ran to hide,'' she kept saying as she nursed a crying baby. Later, she told a reporter: ``It was Samuel Doe's soldiers who killed my baby.'' Mrs. Kaleu has three daughters, but male children are valued above females in Africa. In her misery, she failed to see the happy reunion of Moses Duo and his four children. Mrs. Kaleu hid the children in the thick bush every time she heard the gunfire that still echoes from across the Liberian border. English teacher John M. Layweah, 44, who fled the Liberian town of Kahnplay on Jan. 3, said the sounds of battle reached Kanta Yole on Tuesday. ``New refugees say the rebels pushed the government forces out of the town,'' he said. Layweah said nearly 192 residents of the town of 3,000, including Mrs. Kaleu, have found their way to Kanta Yole. Kahnplay is 60 miles from the border and Kanta Yole is five miles beyond. Refugees have crowded into the small thatched huts of the villagers. Many have relatives here. ``Forty and 50 people are sleeping head-to-toe in huts designed for 10,'' said the Rev. Gnalla Henri, a Roman Catholic priest who came from the nearby town of Danane with 25 blankets. Reunited with his three daughters and son, Duo took them to a half-finished hut of sticks and palm fronds he began building when he arrived Wednesday. He said he lost his children in the chaos of trying to dodge bullets. ``First, we hid under the beds. When the firing stopped for awhile, my daughter started crying that a child was dead. I crawled to the hallway and saw the body of a neighbor's child. That's when we ran for the bushes, even though there was still gunfire and, the next thing, I did not know where my children were.'' Fears that haunt the refugees surfaced at Kanta Yole when villagers accused two new arrivals of being collaborators who led government troops to hiding places of some victims and helped soldiers set homes ablaze. They gathered in muttering groups around a hut where the accused men were dragged before a village headman. He struck one of them with a belt when the man tried to declare his innocence. The headman said he would hand over the two men to the Ivorian military. Layweah described the beginning of the conflict, which has forced more than 72,000 Liberians to flee to Ivory Coast and Guinea. ``In Kahnplay, we were celebrating New Year's Day when we heard gunfire. We ran into our homes. Then the rebels moved in and demanded that we cook them food. ``Later that night, the soldiers came. We fled into the bush to escape and watched them just rattle off their guns into people's homes. God knows how many innocent people died.'' Layweah said he did not know the aims of the rebels but said, ``It is obvious that Doe's soldiers are out to kill off the Gio and Mano people. How else can you explain such barbaric and unprovoked attacks?'' Liberia has more than 15 ethnic groups. The Guere, Gio and Mano tribes, who live along the eastern and northern border, long have complained of oppression by Doe's Krahn people, who comprise about 5 percent of the population but dominate positions of power. Doe seized power in 1980 from the descendants of freed American slaves who founded Liberia in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Sudanese Rebels Announce Daylong Cease-Fire to Evacuate Foreigners
DOC.TEXT: Sudanese rebels said they will stop shelling the provincial capital of war-torn southern Sudan on Monday to allow foreigners to leave and emergency supplies to be brought in. In a broadcast monitored in London on Saturday, the Sudan People's Liberation Army, or SPLA, said the cease-fire was agreed upon during a meeting with an unidentified U.S. diplomat representing the United States, Britain and international relief agencies. It said the meeting took place Friday in the Ethiopian capital. The broadcast said rebels agreed to stop shelling Juba for 12 hours Monday to allow evacuation of foreigners. The only foreigners known to be in Juba are relief workers. There was no immediate comment from Sudanese government officials. The government suspended international relief flights to war-affected areas in southern Sudan on Nov. 3, raising fears that hundreds of thousands of malnourished Sudanese would die of famine. In 1988, the United Nations estimated that 250,000 people died of starvation in the war-torn area; others put the figure at twice that. On Wednesday, the government said it would allow relief organizations to airlift 5,000 tons of food donated by the European Economic Community from Nairobi, Kenya, to Juba. The government also said it had given permission to the International Committee of the Red Coss to airlift relief supplies to Juba and rebel-held areas. The Red Cross said it hopes to begin relief flights Monday. ``Within that period, the SPLA would not shell Juba, nor would it shoot at the planes evacuating these foreigners,'' the broadcast said. ``Should any military plane fly into Juba at times not within the specified hours, these agreements will be rendered null and void,'' the broadcast warned. Juba has been under periodic artillery bombardment from the rebels. The broadcast said the rebels on Tuesday captured the garrison town of Umm Dawrayn and assumed full control of the entire Umm Dawrayn district. Fighting between rebels and government forces has intensifed in southern Sudan since late October when an informal truce broke down. In addition to Umm Dawrayn, the rebels claim to have captured 11 government-controlled towns near the Zaire and Uganda borders this year. The mainly Christian and animist rebels began their struggle in early 1983, demanding greater autonomy from the Moslem-dominated government and economic reforms in the three southern provinces of Bahr el-Ghazal, Upper Nile and Equatoria.

DOC.HEAD: Savimbi Visits Portugal to Discuss Angolan Civil War
With AM-Angola
DOC.TEXT: Angolan rebel leader Jonas Savimbi arrived here Saturday to discuss the civil war in his country and to ask Portuguese officials to help mediate the conflict in their former colony. The war between the U.S.-supported guerrillas and Marxist government forces began when Angola became independent from Portugual 16 years ago. Portugal had refused Savimbi an entry visa until peace talks began in earnest in June with the signing of a short-lived cease-fire agreement. The nine-day visit takes Savimbi away from the battlefront, where 12,000 of his guerrillas are holding off what rebel officers describe as the biggest government offensive ever mounted against the rebel movement. A few hours before Savimbi landed in Lisbon, Angolan Deputy Defense Minister Colonel Antonio Paulo Kassoma arrived for an official visit that will include talks on military cooperation between the two countries. Hundreds of supporters, many from the 150,000-strong Angolan community, shouted ``Viva Savimbi'' and waved rebel flags as the guerrilla leader arrived at Lisbon Airport aboard a private jet. ``I hope my contacts in Portugal will help open a new chapter in which our two peoples can move forward together,'' toward peace in Angola, Savimbi said in brief remarks at the airport. He then drove in an armor-plated limousine through streets lined with posters calling for peace and democracy in Angola. In a later speech to a group of prominent political figures, he said: ``Portugal could serve as a link between the rebels and the government ... serving as a moderator helping to bring about a sincere and honest dialogue.'' Savimbi said President Mario Soares would receive him in an unofficial capacity. Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva and other government leaders have declined to confirm reports they will also meet Savimbi in a private capacity. Alcides Sakala, a spokesman for the guerrillas _ known as the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA _ said of Savimbi: ``No important political figure will fail to meet him.'' Savimbi has said that Portugal, the colonial ruler of Angola for four centuries, could play a more important role in peace talks. ``Portugal needs to be better informed about what is happening in Angola so that it can better fulfill the role of a mediator,'' Savimbi told a Portuguese newspaper before his visit. ``Without the Portuguese, the reconstruction of Angola will never be possible.'' Zaire's President Mobuto Sese Seko is the official mediator of peace efforts in Angola. But UNITA and the Angolan government have both said Portugal has a part to play in furthering the peace process. Savimbi said discussions on Angola between Cavaco Silva and President Bush in Washington earlier this month show that Portugal has a role to play. Western diplomats in Lisbon said Cavaco Silva had urged the United States to take a more even-handed approach to the Angolan conflict, giving greater recognition to the Angolan government. Washington has repeatedly refused to recognize the Angolan government and reportedly supplies Savimbi with $50 million a year in military aid.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: A welding supply company was struck two nights in a row by a cat burglar _ a four-legged one. James Rich Jr., president of J.A. Welding Supply Co., said police responded early Thursday when the company's burglar alarm went off, but officers found nothing. Then when employees came in, they found a huge 20-pound cat huddled in the bathroom. Rich put the animal back outside, and employees taking a look around the plant determined that the cat had fallen through some ceiling tiles to get inside the building. On Friday morning, employees opened the store and were surprised to find insulation all over the floor. The cat apparently did not set off the burglar alarm this time, however. Rich said the robust kitty didn't look like it wanted a bowl of warm milk or some Tender Vittles. He said it more closely resembled the junkyard variety that feeds on mice and rats. Lots of mice and rats. ``That has got to be the biggest cat I've ever seen,'' said Rich. The animal refused to be coaxed into the box. Finally, two employees nabbed it and put it in the box. Rich said the animal would be turned over to authorities to make sure it doesn't have rabies.

DOC.HEAD: New Honduran President Pledges to Work For Regional Peace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with inaugural speech; picks up 11th pvs, `The new...'
DOC.TEXT:
Rafael Leonardo Callejas was sworn in Saturday as president and pledged to work for peace in Central America, where he said people ``live with machine-gun fire and terror.'' Vice President Dan Quayle and four Latin American presidents were among dignitaries from 60 nations at the inauguration, which marked Honduras' first peaceful transfer of power to an opposition party in 57 years. Callejas urged Central Americans to unite ``to fight for dignity and progress in our republics, because nobody in the world has the right to choose our destiny searching for greater progress and winning dignity and honor.'' He also outlined goals of raising the life expectancy and literacy rates, creating more jobs, reducing the nation's debt, selling off state-owned companies and improving public health in one of the poorest nations in the Western Hemisphere. ``We are confronting our worst economic problems Honduras has faced in its history as a republic. However, it will not discourage us because we are convinced that by adopting adequate measures in an opportune manner and rousing up national willingness, we will move ahead,'' Callejas said. Callejas, 46, comes from a landholding family and was trained as an agricultural economist at Mississippi State University. He was not expected to change Honduras' strong ties to the United States. The National Party candidate won the election Nov. 26 by beating Carlos Flores of the governing Liberal Party. He replaces Jose Azcona Hoyo. The new president of the legislature, Rodolfo Irias Navas, placed the presidential sash on Callejas, whose term runs through January 1994. Among the 40,000 people attending the ceremony at the national soccer stadium were presidents Vincio Cerezo of Guatemala, Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador, and Oscar Arias of Costa Rica. Callejas said peace will come to the region only through cooperation with other governments. ``Lasting peace in Central America will come only when it is built through the reduction of armies and the elimination of offensive arms,'' he declared. ``We must systematically apply democracy so nobody in Central America is threatened by tanks and solders and so nobody believes that the opportunities for personal development are available only for the few,'' he said. ``Our Central American sister countries still live with machine-gun fire and terror,'' he said. Relations between Honduras and Nicaragua have been tense for years because Honduras has allowed anti-Sandinista Contra rebels to set up bases on its territory. Callejas has said he wants the U.S.-backed rebels removed but wants to keep close military relations with the United States, which maintains an air base in Honduras. He made no specific mention about the Contras or U.S. base in his inaugural address.
The new president has promised to decentralize the government, sell some state-owned companies and create incentives for investment and exports. Honduras has a per capita income of about $500. Honduras' principal exports are bananas, coffee, beef, lumber, metals and sugar. Its major trading partner is the United States. Honduras returned to elected government in 1980 after nearly 20 years of military rule. The last time there was a party-to-party transition came in 1933, when Tiburcio Carias Andino of the National Party took over from Liberal Vicente Mejia Colindres. Carias didn't allow another vote until 1948.

DOC.HEAD: State: No Labor Laws Violated in Crash That Killed 10
DOC.TEXT: A harvest crew chief may face traffic charges in the deaths of 10 Mexican migrant workers who drowned when their van plunged into a fog-shrouded canal, but broke no state labor law, investigators say. Rutilio Escobedo, 28, the driver, did not break state law regulating the transportation of farm laborers by driving 11 co-workers to a citrus grove near this Lake Okeechobee farm community, a preliminary state report says. Escobedo, whose wife died in Wednesday's crash, was discharged Friday from Hendry General Hospital after treatment for injuries received when his van ran off a curve south of Clewiston and plunged into the canal. He may face charges of driving on a suspended license, but no charges will be filed for two or three weeks, a police spokesman said. The U.S. Labor and Transportation departments and the National Transportation Safety Board also are investigating of the crash. Escobedo blamed the crash on a frozen steering mechanism, but investigators said there was no evidence of a mechanical problem. W.T. Coppage Harvesting Inc. of La Belle, a farm labor contractor that hired Escobedo as a crew chief, also was cleared of any state labor-law violations, said Gil Hill, chief of the Bureau of Agriculture Programs in Tallahassee. FHP officers have released the names of five victims in the crash. Names of the other five victims were withheld while police tried to contact relatives in Mexico. Escobedo's uncle, Nicolas Escobedo, 50, was the only other survivor of the accident.

DOC.HEAD: State Trial of Hazelwood Set in Nation's Worst Oil Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 11th graf, `Anchorage Assistant...', to add detail and comment on subpoena of third mate. Picks up 12th graf, `Madson said...'.
DOC.TEXT: Fired Exxon skipper Joseph Hazelwood would rather be at sea than in a courtroom this week, but is looking forward to making the case that he should not bear criminal blame for the nation's worst oil spill. ``I'd like to get rid of the misconception that I got drunk, ran the ship aground, and just shrugged my shoulders and walked away _ because that's just not what happened,'' Hazelwood said in an interview with The Associated Press last week in his New York lawyer's office. The 43-year-old former captain of the tanker Exxon Valdez is scheduled to go on trial Monday in Anchorage Superior Court. Judge Karl Johnstone expects to spend at least the first day briefing news media representatives about courtroom rules and considering motions before jury selection begins in what could be at least a six-week trial. Hazelwood's attorneys recently submitted motions after losing several efforts to have charges dismissed in various courts, including Johnstone's. There are new analytical twists to the latest motions, but essentially they are the same as earlier requests. One challenges the state's jurisdiction in the case and another seeks to prohibit as evidence the results of a blood-alcohol test that Hazelwood failed about 10 hours after the Exxon Valdez ran aground. The hull of the tanker ripped open March 24 on a charted reef in Prince William Sound and gushed nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude into the pristine waters. The oil blackened shores in the sound and the Gulf of Alaska, killed thousands of animals and disrupted commercial fishing seasons. Exxon says the cleanup has cost $2 billion. Hazelwood, who was not on the bridge when the crash happened, faces a felony charge of criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of operating a vessel while intoxicated, reckless endangerment and negligent discharge of oil. The charges carry combined, maximum penalties of seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Defense attorney Dick Madson is expected to argue that Hazelwood left sound instructions for members of the crew and cannot be held criminally responsible for their actions. Third Mate Gregory Cousins was at the wheel of the 987-foot tanker when it ran into Bligh Reef after leaving designated shipping lanes. Anchorage Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole would not discuss the prosecution's plans. In the past, prosecutors have said that Hazelwood should have been at the helm since he was the ship's only authorized navigator for Prince William Sound. His lawyers say the Coast Guard relaxed the rules in 1986. In an affidavit accompanying a subpoena served Friday on Cousins in Tampa, Fla., Cole said Hazelwood put the tanker on a southward course to avoid ice and set the automatic pilot before he left the ship in Cousins' hands. Cousins said he would not talk to reporters before testifying at Hazelwood's trial. ``I'll be saying it all in Anchorage _ probably over and over,'' Cousins said. Madson said witnesses will include a computer expert who will discuss a computer simulation for the ship's course. The witness will testify the ship would have cleared Bligh Reef had Hazelwood's instructions been followed, Madson said. He also plans to call crew members and experts on naval architecture and the physical effects of alcohol. Hazelwood is expected to be in the courtroom for the whole trial. The seaman has been living with his wife and teen-age daughter in Huntington, N.Y., on Long Island, and working as a lobsterman in the months since Exxon fired him. Before his tanker ran aground, the longest he had been ashore since he was an adolescent was two or three months. ``I get stark crazy when I am too far from the salt water,'' he said, chain-smoking at the interview in Manhattan. Hazelwood said he is confident that once Alaskans hear the case against him ``they will agree that this was a tragic accident, nothing more.'' His trial, originally scheduled for October in Valdez, the port town from which the tanker sailed a few hours before the accident, was delayed as the court system reassigned judges and processed thick stacks of motions. The trial was moved to Anchorage on grounds a fair proceeding could not be obtained in Valdez, and because Alaska's largest city has a substantial jury pool and facilities needed for extensive media coverage. Court officials said it could take at least a week to screen about 75 prospective jurors for 12 jury positions plus those of alternates.

DOC.HEAD: Winnie Mandela Says ANC Must be Legalized Before Husband's Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Winnie Mandela Saying Nelson Mandela demanding ANC's legalization before release, other conditions; pickup 15th pvs, `The union...'; ADDS 2 grafs at end on cricket protest.
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela does not want to be freed from jail until the government ends its state of emergency and legalizes the African National Congress, the wife of the anti-apartheid leader said Saturday. Winnie Mandela also said her husband wants the government to allow exiled African National Congress officials to return home as a condition to his freedom. Previously, Mandela's colleagues have said the ANC leader was eager to go free as soon as the government approved his unconditional release. However, Mrs. Mandela, returning to Johannesburg after a four-hour visit to Victor Verster Prison Farm near Cape Town, said her husband would refuse freedom until the government ended the state of emergency, lifted the ban on the ANC, and allowed exiled ANC officials to return. ``I think the government has serious problems meeting the demands the government has to meet before his release,'' she said. ``There is no question of him walking out of Victor Verster without those demands having been met.'' The demands she mentioned have also been listed by the ANC as conditions the government must meet before the guerrilla movement agrees to negotiations. Mandela's release was widely expected to precede any lifting of the ban on the ANC. ``It is quite clear there are a lot of hurdles along the way,'' Mrs. Mandela told journalists when she emerged from the prison. ``It is quite clear problems have cropped up about his immediate release.'' Mrs. Mandela appeared pensive and uneasy after visiting her husband. Three weeks ago, she emerged from a visit brimming with optimism that his freedom was imminent. She said Mandela was in lower spirits on this visit. Mandela, 71, has been jailed since 1962 and is serving a life sentence for helping plan the start of the ANC's anti-government sabotage campaign. He is the country's best-known black leader, and the government has expressed interest in his offer to mediate in negotiations with the ANC. President F.W. de Klerk has said he would like to remove obstacles to negotiations and is expected to speak about the ANC's conditions in an address to Parliament on Feb. 2. In other developments Saturday, officials of the state-run South African Transport Services and the South African Railway and Harbor Workers Union signed an agreement ending one of the country's most violent strikes. The union failed to win even part of its requested 150 percent pay increase, but the company agreed to recognize the union and rehire all of the 23,000 strikers who were fired. The workers had demanded that their minimum monthly wage be increased from $240 to $600. Numerous battles occurred between strikers and non-strikers. Railway coaches and tracks were sabotaged, with a loss to the company estimated at $16 million. The company employs about 170,000 people and runs rail and harbor operations nationwide. In Boksburg, an industrial city near Johannesburg, 100 mixed-race residents arrived at a whites-only lakeside park for a picnic and were confronted by a group of conservative whites, including khaki-clad members of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement. The park was declared whites-only in late 1988 after the far-right Conservative Party took control of the city council in municipal elections. No serious injuries were reported in the clash. However, two white men were arrested after they tore down a protest banner that said: ``Mandela: The freedom of Boksburg awaits you.'' In the town of Kimberley, several hundred protesters staged a relatively peaceful demonstration outside a stadium where an English team was playing a squad of second-division local players. The team is defying a ban on sports contacts with South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Clash With Police Over Presence of English Soccer Team
LaserPhoto KBL2,KBL3
By DENIS FARRELL
DOC.TEXT: Blacks protesting the presence of an English cricket team that broke a boycott clashed with police Saturday in a township outside this mining city. Police said protesters burned down the home of a black constable and threw stones at vehicles. There were unconfirmed reports that some protesters were injured by shotgun pellets. Earlier in the day, several hundred protesters staged a relatively peaceful demonstration outside the stadium where the English team, in South Africa for a six-week tour, was playing a squad of second-division local players. At one point, someone inside the stadium threw a bottle over the fence at protesters, and stones were hurled back. There was no serious trouble until police confronted some protesters on their way back home and fired rubber bullets at them. On Friday, the start of the three-day Kimberley match, witnesses said black youths ran through the city center breaking car and shop windows after police refused to allow a protest. Police said 31 youths were arrested and reported that a 52-year-old man was injured by the protesters. Protest leaders met with Ali Bacher, managing director of the South African Cricket Union, and demanded they be allowed to march on the stadium. Bacher, who has been seeking to minimize conflict related to the tour, later went to a local magistrate and obtained his approval for a protest to be held outside the stadium Saturday. The English team is defying a ban on sports contacts with South Africa that was imposed to protest its policies of racial segregation. The English players face expulsion from international cricket for five years for taking part in the tour. Activists have vowed to stage protests throughout the visit by the English team, led by former national captain Mike Gatting. There have been protests outside the hotels where the players have been staying in Johannesburg and Kimberley. The English players have not said how much they are being paid for the tour, but local newspapers have put the figure at $160,000.

DOC.HEAD: Dead Businesman Told of Secret Service Connections
DOC.TEXT: A slain Israeli businessman told friends he traveled with Secret Service agents four times in preparation for President Bush's trip to Colombia, but an agency spokesman said he knew of no such connection, a newspaper reported Saturday. Arik Afek, 39, apparently traveled on a U.S. diplomatic passport issued under a sealed federal court agreement signed in Miami, The Miami Herald said, quoting unidentified sources. Afek told friends that the agreement included the government's promise to help him avoid prosecution for his part in helping mercenaries who allegedly trained paramilitary groups for Colombian drug cartels, the newspaper said. His body was found Wednesday in the trunk of his parked car at Miami International Airport in what police describe as a gangland execution-style shooting. No arrest has been made. Afek's shadowy past also reportedly made him a target of the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Immigration and Naturalization Service, but federal agencies neither confirm nor deny any interest in the murder case. ``It's just another homicide in Miami to us,'' said Secret Service spokesman Allan Cramer in Washington. Secret Service agents preparing for Bush's planned anti-drug summit next month in Colombia interviewed Afek after NBC reported his links to paramilitary groups also involving Israeli army reserve Lt. Col. Yair Klein. Both were named on arrest warrants issued by a Colombian judge in September, charged with enlisting civilians in military operations without government approval. The pair reportedly acknowledged a role in paramilitary training but said it was limited to training farmers against guerrilla attack and had no connection to drug traffickers. Asked about Afek's role last September, Eyal Dror, business manager for Klein's security company, said, ``I know Afek and he can't be taken seriously.'' Dr. Nardo Zaias, a Miami dermatologist and a former partner in Afek's imported flower business, told The New York Times: ``He was not a very clever guy. He was a big kid, somewhat emotional and naive.''

DOC.HEAD: Residents of Blasted Neighborhood Wait For Rebuilding
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The street names are the same, the faces familiar. Gossip still makes the circuit, drugs sometimes change hands, and families still struggle to get by. This is no longer the El Chorrillo neighborhood, however, but its essence, distilled down by an invasion and filtered into an airplane hangar at Albrook Field, a joint-use air base used by U.S. and Panamanian forces. ``We paid the highest price for the invasion,'' says Francisco Martinez ``We had little, but we lost it all.'' Martinez is among the estimated 16,000 refugees from El Chorrillo, the neighborhood with the bad luck to be the home of the Panamanian Defense Forces headquarters, the U.S. Army's main target during the invasion of Panama on Dec. 20. President Bush on Thursday proposed giving $1 billion in economic aid to Panama, and local officials said they are discussing plans to provide new homes for the refugees. But despite those good intentions, the refugees most likely will be living in tents or in small cubbyholes in a big hangar for at least a year. ``It is unjust. Things ought to move a lot faster. These people need a home,'' said Sergio Galvez, director of the camp sheltering 3,500 refugees on the northwestern edge of Panama City. A U.S. civilian affairs group is working with Panamanian officials, trying to determine how to house the homeless while rebuilding goes on. ``We can only make recommendations,'' said Vince Ryan, a Houston city councilman who is a member of the group. ``The Panamanian government must make a decision. They are talking about different things that could be done ranging from building apartment buildings, giving each family credit to build a home or turning this area into a commercial area.'' ``But anyone who tells you they can rebuild in nine months is an optimist,'' said Ryan. Families live in partitions made of wooden frames and canvas. Some of the alleys have been given names of streets from the old neighborhood, less than two miles away. ``No gossips allowed,'' reads a piece of canvas that serves as a door on one of the partitions. ``Gossip and disinformation are some of the problems,'' said Galvez. ``People get desperate, there are nearly 6,000 unemployed among those who lost their homes. Some people go around telling others that the U.S. Army is giving cash to every family, and within minutes you have a mob asking for the money.'' ``Everybody is looking out for himself,'' said Miguel Martinez, 23. ``We were not a very united community back in El Chorrillo.'' Martinez was working as a helper in a home for the elderly next to El Chorrillo's church when the U.S. effort to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega began at 12:30 a.m. U.S. officials say most of the damage wasn't caused by the attack itself, but by fires set by Noriega supporters. ``We got everyone out safely the next morning,'' Martinez said. ``The church did not burn down.'' ``I guess I could go back, but I'm trying to help here. Some of us get together and do volunteer work distributing medicines, food, cleaning up and doing other jobs. We are here sharing the suffering of our brothers,'' he said. Polio left Manelis Sanchez, 19, without the use of his legs. He was a popular figure in El Chorrillo, moving around on his crutches doing odd jobs or going to a busy corner downtown where he stopped cars and asked drivers for money for ``an operation.'' He lived in a shack next to the church. ``I was in bed when they started shooting,'' he said. ``My friend told me, `This is Bush's Christmas gift for Noriega.''' There are problems at the camp. A security officer said there was some low-level drug selling and consumption. ``Remember a lot of the people in El Chorillo lived off the sale and distribution of drugs and contraband,'' said the officer, who refused to give his name. This week, the U.S. Army stopped distributing ration packages to the refugees. From now on food will have to come from private donations. U.S. soldiers still provide security, but camp administration is being taken over by the Panamanian Red Cross, with help from the U.S. Agency for International Development; Caritas, a Roman Catholic charity; and other charities. ``It was a tough neighborhood. They are boisterous, complain about things, want their own kind of food, and are always arguing. You have to understand them,'' Galvez said. ``You must understand the trauma of an invasion, the desperation of living in a refugee camp while others are discussing how long you are going to stay here and you hear them saying a year.'' El Chorrillo has been leveled and cleared by U.S. Army engineers. Most of the wooden three-story structures dating back to the beginning of the century are gone. Still standing are three concrete apartment buildings in need of extensive repairs. Estimates of the cost of rebuilding El Chorrillo alone range from $30 million to $50 million; the White House said Thursday that it was earmarking $42 million in aid for housing, emergency public works, small business rehabilitation for looting victims and technical assistance to the government. It is not certain Congress will approve everything Bush wants, even though President Guillermo Endara said even $1 billion is only half what Panama needs.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Record Budget Will Give `Opportunity for All'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, bgng: Bush's budget, to CORRECT $63.1 trillion to $63.1 billion
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's $1.23 trillion federal budget for fiscal 1991 will contain a warning to Congress from budget director Richard G. Darman against seeking a ``wonderland'' in which military savings can be diverted to domestic programs, administration officials said today. ``The near-term `peace dividend' is likely to be smaller than commonly assumed,'' Darman tells Congress in an introduction to the budget document, the officials said. Bush's budget plan will propose a reduction of the federal deficit to $63.1 billion, roughly half as much as the current expected deficit, through a series of austere military and domestic programs, said the officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Bush will propose total spending of $1.233 trillion and will project revenues to the government at $1.17 trillion. The budget includes an austere $292.1 billion for the Pentagon, which works out to a slight increase over current spending but a reduction of about 2 percent after inflation is taken into account, the sources said. Some members of Congress have proposed that the reductions in military tensions in Eastern Europe can be turned into a so-called ``peace dividend'' and spent on expanding social programs. Darman, however, will tell Congress it would be ``naively euphoric'' to expect that the crumbling of the Soviet Empire will spell a final end to East-West tensions. In his preface to the budget, to be formally submitted on Monday, Darman will compare the federal budget to the ``ultimate Cookie Monster,'' a reference to the character in the popular children's television show ``Sesame Street,'' the officials said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. ``It's excess tendencies toward consumption are not exactly ennobling...But at the same time, its underlying motivation is clearly not malevolent. What harm it might cause is largely unintended.'' Excerpts from Darman's introduction, first published in today's editions of the New York Times, were confirmed by administration officials. Darman also will tell Congress that many programs in the budget are like ``Pacman'' in the popular video game, ``waiting to spring forward and consume another line of resources dots in the budget maze.'' Details of the budget were surfacing on Friday in advance of the formal submission to Congress. Bush himself tipped his hand on one major program increase, announcing the proposal for the increase in spending on the Head Start program for low-income children. He said every youngster ``deserves the opportunity for a full and happy life.'' Bush said the new funds would permit Head Start's enrollment to grow to 667,000 children, or 70 percent of the nation's disadvantaged four-year-olds. Currently, it reaches 39 percent of eligible youths. However, the budget will also contain spending cuts and program slowdowns. Veterans will be among the victims of Bush's proposed cutbacks. Sources who spoke on the condition of anonymity said the budget would require veterans to make down payments on VA loans for the first time _ 4 percent on loans of over $25,000. Larry W. Rivers, executive director of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, called it ``an unreasonable'' proposal that ``dashes the dreams of countless veterans of participating in the American dream of home ownership.'' Bush, who frequently says he wants to be remembered as ``the education president,'' was proposing a $500 million overall increase in education spending, but at the expense of some programs. For instance, the budget would reduce the Guaranteed Student Loan program by $500 million, sources said. Another $155 million would be cut from the Perkins loan program for low-income college students. And although Bush will call for long-term increases in Pell Grants, another source of money for low-income students, his budget will reflect a cut in the grants by some $66.5 million for this coming fall. As a result, more than 1.3 students will either have their stipends reduced or eliminated, the sources said. ``Overall, it's an inadequate investment,'' said Gerald Morris, deputy director of legislation for the American Federation of Teachers. According to administration and congressional officials, the budget will also include: _The most austere Pentagon budget in more than a decade. Bush will propose $292 billion in new outlays, up slightly from current spending but representing a 2 percent cut after adjusting for inflation. However, the budget will include a request for increased spending on the Strategic Defense Initiative to $4.8 billion, up from $3.8 billion this year. _More money for fish, wildlife and recreation plus a cutback in federal timber sales. _A new ``family savings account'' that would allow people to earn tax-free interest and dividends on money that is squirreled away for at least seven years _ with contributions of up to $5,000 per year per family. _No new general tax hikes and a renewal of Bush's call for a lower capital gains tax rate, a tax credit for adoptions and one for child care. _A $8.5 billion slash in Medicare funds. Bush has also announced that he will seek a $1.1 billion increase, to $10.6 billion, for the war on drugs. Some 24,000 of the blue-jacketed, 1,592-page budget documents are being printed, and they will go on sale on Monday at government bookshops for $38 apiece. But a new government economic report was already raising doubts about the administration's assertions that the Bush budget would lower the federal deficit to $64 billion, as required by the Gramm-Rudman budget balancing law. The Commerce Department reported Friday that economic growth in the last three months of 1989 fell to an annual rate of 0.5 percent when adjusted for inflation, considerably worse than projected by the Office of Management and Budget as it put together the economic assumptions for the new budget. The economic figures will make ``total hash'' of the administration's claims that its spending outline can significantly reduce the budget deficit, said Michael Evans, president of a Washington-based economic forecasting service.

DOC.HEAD: Worst River Flooding in Years Washes Our Bridges, Roads and Homes
DOC.TEXT: The cold, muddy water of the swollen Amite River began receding Saturday from washed-out roads, bridges and flooded homes and officials said they expected heavy damage in its wake. ``It'll be a while before we have any good estimates. We still can't get into a lot of the places because they're still flooded,'' said Red Cross Disaster Director Bob Hernandez. ``All I can tell you is that a lot of people are comparing it to 1983, which was the worst we ever had, and the Red Cross spent $1.25 million in that one,'' he said. In '83, the Amite crested at 40.5 feet near Baton Rouge, the highest crest in 100 years. The river crested at 39.5 feet Saturday, Hernandez said. No injuries or deaths had been reported in the flooding by Saturday. The floodwaters receded in Baton Rouge and nearby Denham Springs in the morning. To the south, in Ascension Parish, water didn't begin falling until later in the day. The flooding resulted from heavy rains Wednesday and Thursday over the Amite River basin, primarily north of Baton Rouge. Also, 12 to 15 inches of rain fell in 36 hours last week in the upper Comite Basin in southwestern Mississippi, which drains to the Amite and Comite rivers, said Malcolm Moreau of the National Weather Service in Baton Rouge. More than 30 roads and highways in southeastern Louisiana were closed Saturday because of flooding. In the Denham Springs area, almost 150 single-family homes and house trailers were damaged, an early survey revealed, Hernandez said. ``We know it'll be more than that,'' he said. ``We've just started looking. Most of what we're seeing is major damage. We had water up to the tops of trailers, in the second floor of split-level houses.'' About half of the approximately 50 homes in one East Baton Rouge subdivision flooded with up to 3 inches of water. Homeowners estimated thousands of dollars in damage. Most residents left the subdivision late Friday, either taking their possessions with them or mounting what they could on cinder blocks. ``People knew this flood was coming and prepared for it beforehand,'' said Hernandez. ``That's going to help keep the damage to possessions down.'' The National Weather Service predicted a 20 percent chance of rain Saturday night and Sunday, but state Department of Public Works officials did not expect new problems. About 38 people spent Friday night in shelters in Denham Springs, said Don Eisenberg, director of the Baton Rouge chapter of the Red Cross. He said the shelter would stay open until residents can make their homes habitable.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Urge Curbs on Tourism in Antarctica
DOC.TEXT: An environmental group on Saturday urged the government to protect penguins and other Antarctic wildlife by regulating companies that take tourists to that ice-bound continent. ``Repeated tourist visits will cause animals to abandon their breeding sites or increase the vulnerability of their eggs and young to predation,'' Environmental Defense Fund attorney Bruce Manheim said in a statement. The New York-based group issued a report calling on the National Science Foundation, the State Department and the Coast Guard to establish a licensing system to ensure no damage to Antarctica from tour groups. ``Although remote and generally inhospitable, Antarctica is now visited by thousands of tourists each year who wish to see the continent's pristine environment before it could be despoiled,'' the report said. It said ``most tourists are seriously concerned about protecting Antarctica'' but ``their visits are often localized repetitive and frequently occur at breeding grounds for penguins, seals and other seabirds.'' The report said ``frequent helicopter visits by the first tourists to Antarctica _ diplomats and dignitaries visiting McMurdo Station _ quickly resulted in a 50 percent reduction in the southernmost Adelie Penguin rookery at Cape Royds.'' It said Antarctic tourism is growing and one Australian company hopes to develop and a hard-surface runway and luxury hotel on the continent. Currently, however, most of the tour companies are American and thus the federal government could do much to limit environmental damage, it said. The group urged a ban on aircraft overflights within 1,500 meters of wildlife sites, guidelines on government observation of wildlife, management plans for wildlife sites, advance information requirements for expeditions, and coordination of tour visits to wildlife areas. It also called for a monitoring program to assess the impact of such visits, a ban on the disposal of oil, plastics and garbage from tour vessels and strict regulation of vessel operations in waters off Antarctica. The report was released on the first anniversary of the grounding of the Bahia Paraiso, an Argentine tour vessel that spilled more than 180,000 gallons of oil into wildlife breeding areas, the report said. ``A year after Antarctica's most significant environmental disaster, we still don't have regulations to prevent similar catastrophes,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Walton Confident of Recovery from Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire Sam Walton, who controls one of the biggest fortunes in America, says he has a better than even chance of winning his battle with bone cancer. Walton, the 71-year-old founder and chairman of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., has been diagnosed with multiple myeloma, a form of bone cancer and is receiving treatment at M.D. Anderson Hospital in Houston. He returned Friday to his home in Bentonville, where Wal-Mart keekps its corporate offices, to attend weekend meetings. He is scheduled to return to Houston on Monday to resume chemotherapy and radiation treatments on his back and on his bones, which he said have become soft and developed holes because of the cancer. Walton said the treatments have been effective and that he has about a 60 percent chance of recovery from the disease. ``I'm getting on a lot better,'' he said Friday. ``I've been on this treatment for about a week and there seems to be definite improvement in the way I feel and the way I'm walking.'' If his current therapy regime does not work, he said, he'll have to take heavier doses of chemotherapy with greater side effects. ``We're trying to do it with a less-type treatment at this point.'' Walton, known for making surprise visits to stores in his popular Wal-Mart discount chain and leading employees and customers in a ``Give me a W, Give me an A...'' cheer, he was grateful for the cards and prayers of well-wishers. ``I'm one of the real fortunate folks who have people believing in me and wanting to help and I wish it were that way with everybody,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu Associates Go on Trial; One Admits Guilt
LaserPhotos XBUC1,2
DOC.TEXT: Four men who were high-ranking officials in Nicolae Ceausescu's regime went on trial Saturday on charges they contributed to the deaths of hundreds of people during last month's revolution. One of the four, former Politburo member Ion Dinca, told the court he was an accomplice to ``criminal measures'' ordered by Ceausescu to try to crush the uprising. Dinca was the only one of the defendants called to testify during Saturday's four-hour session, but the prosecution presented declarations it said were from each of the defendants admitting their guilt. On trial are former Communist Party secretary Emil Bobu; former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu; and former Politburo members Manea Manescu and Dinca. They are charged with complicity in genocide in connection with the deaths of hundreds of people during the December revolution that ousted Ceausescu's government and face life in prison at hard labor if convicted. The military prosecutor, Col. Aurel Cosma, said each man could have prevented the killings of at least 689 people shot to death by troops by asking Ceausescu to resign. Instead, they backed his order to shoot protesters, Cosma said before presenting the declarations purported to be from the accused. Cosma did not say when the declarations were given. ``I was a beast because I agreed to the orders of Nicolae Ceausescu,'' said a statement attributed to Postelnicu, 59, who partly controlled the Securitate secret police. ``I decided to fight alongside him until the end,'' he said. Bobu, considered the No. 3 official in the government behind Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, was quoted as saying: ``I didn't take a position. My attitude was contemptible. I was the one who suggested cremation of the victims in Timisoara'' to hide evidence of the military action. The revolt began in the western city of Timisoara. Manescu, 74, was quoted as saying: ``I asked Nicolae Ceausescu not to resign. I ordered fire with war munitions. I agreed with the army's repression.'' ``Everyone with no exception proved to be cowards. We carried out Ceausescu's orders,'' said Dinca, 62. Hundreds of people crowded into a hall at the Romanian Military Academy in Bucharest to view the trial, the first of former Ceausescu associates since the dictator and his wife were tried in secret on genocide charges and executed Christmas Day. The defendants entered the dock without handcuffs, guarded by two armed policemen. Postelnicu appeared on the verge of tears. Prosecuting Ceausescu loyalists is a key test of the provisional government, which is struggling to gain the support of the people before free elections in May. The trial opened one day after the vice president of the provisional government resigned, claiming that ``Stalinist methods'' were being used by the nation's new leaders. The charges referred to Ceausescu and his wife as the ``authors'' of the genocide but said the four defendants did not act to block the Ceausescus and therefore were guilty of complicity. One of the issues raised at the session was of the events that led to security forces being ordered to open fire on demonstrators.
