Dinca, in his testimony, said he and four other Politburo members opposed the president's demand that they shoot at protesters and told Ceausescu so at a Politburo meeting Dec. 17. ``It was the first time that Ceausescu met with opposition from the Politburo,'' he said. ``He got up from the council table, very nervous, and said, `Will you please elect another general secretary if you don't agree with me.''' Dinca said some Politburo members then gave their support to Ceausescu, who went ahead with the orders to shoot protesters. ``I consider myself his accomplice in what he did,'' Dinca said. ``If any of us had tried to oppose him, others would have allied with us and we would have managed to convince him to give up such an order.'' He added: ``I didn't have the courage. I didn't do it because of cowardice.'' ``I gave my help to Ceausescu to put into practice the criminal measures to suffocate in blood the justified revolution of the people,'' he said. The revolution was justified, he said, because Romanians were deprived of basic human rights, food, medicine and energy to heat their homes. Ceausescu forced Romania's 23 million people to endure hardships, exporting food and energy supplies for heating, as he sought to pay off Romania's $10 billion foreign debt. On Dec. 22, Dinca said, Ceausescu called an emergency Politburo meeting and asked if anyone objected to the steps he was taking to crush the revolt, which by then had spread to Bucharest and other cities. ``Everybody there said they would fight to the end,'' Dinca said. By then, Defense Minister Vasile Milea, who had refused to shoot at protesters, had himself been shot to death by pro-Ceausescu forces. The Ceausescus boarded a helicopter to flee Bucharest on Dec. 22. They were caught and executed Christmas Day after being convicted of genocide and ruining the economy. The death penalty has since been outlawed. Under questioning from Cosma, Dinca said Milea told Ceausescu on Dec. 17 that he had examined all the military regulations and ``didn't find anywhere that the armed forces should shoot the people.'' Before Dinca finished testifying, his three co-defendants were asked if they had any questions for him. Manescu and Bobu said no. But Postelnicu, referring to shorthand transcripts of the Politburo meetings, said: ``I think there are many lies in these papers.'' The tribunal president, Col. Andrei Nitoui, said Postelnicu could say more about that when he testifies. Nitoui adjourned the tribunal until Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Birthplace No Longer The Lenin Shipyard
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Welders on Saturday cut down the word ``Lenin'' from the sign over the gates to the shipyard where the Solidarity movement was born and removed a statue of the Soviet Communist founder from the plant. The tributes to Vladimir I. Lenin had remained at the state-owned shipyard even after Solidarity had forced the Communists to give up power in Poland following parliamentary elections last year. Workers, laughing and applauding, removed the Lenin sign as the Polish Communists were gathering in Warsaw for a last national congress that is expected to create a new party with a new name and program. ``May this symbolic act be proof of the irreversibility of the changes in our country, a warning for those who led us to so many disasters,'' said Zbigniew Lis, head of the Solidarity commission at the yard. ``We got rid of a symbol the working class never identified with,'' he said. The Solidarity committee decided to restore the old name, the Gdansk Shipyard, as part of plans to create a joint stock company at the complex. The yard had been renamed the Lenin Shipyard 23 years ago. The then-Communist government announced in 1988 that the yard would be closed because it was unprofitable. Lech Walesa, the shipyard electrician who has led the union since 1980, denounced that decision as politically motivated. Plans for a Polish-born American heiress, Barbara Piasecka-Johnson, to invest up to $100 million in the yard fell through when workers would not agree to her offer. The Solidarity-led government now announced plans to create a stock corporation from the state-owned shipyard whose shares would eventually be sold to investors.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Protesters Clash With Police in Several Cities
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of ethnic Albanians clashed with police in the troubled Kosovo province Saturday, and opposition groups appealed for negotiations and free elections as a solution to ending ethnic tensions. Police used tear gas and truncheons to disperse stone-throwing demonstrators in protests that broke out in several Kosovo towns Saturday. According to Radio Belgrade, shots may have been fired by both sides. The state Tanjug news agency reported several injuries in the clashes. Belgrade radio reported that up to five people may have died, but the reports could not be confirmed. Protests broke out in the province Tuesday. On Wednesday, riot police used tear gas and a water cannon to disperse about 40,000 ethnic Albanians who demonstrated in Pristina, the provincial capital, to protest alleged human rights abuses in Kosovo. According to Tanjug, protests broke out Saturday in the provincial towns of Urosevac, Pec, Orahovac, Podujevo, Suva Reka, Prizren, and Brestovac. A source reached by telephone in Orahovac, about 31 miles southwest of Pristina, told The Associated Press that demonstrators threw stones at police in nearby Brestovac. Radio Belgrade reported that police fired tear gas there, and reportedly reverted to shooting after allegedly being fired at by demonstrators. In Pec, about 31 miles west of Pristina, Tanjug said about 2,000 people took part in what it described as ``very aggressive demonstrations.'' It said protesters built barricades and set a car belonging to the Communist Party headquarters on fire. It said several other cars were damaged. Belgrade television reported the Pec demonstrators were dispersed and that ``very strong security units'' were maintaining calm in the streets. According to media reports, shots were fired in Pec during protests there Friday, and Tanjug Saturday quoted Pec police chief Aslan Slamniku as saying five policemen were injured Friday. Earlier Saturday, ethnic Albanian opposition groups had demanded an end to ``police repression'' and appealed for demonstrations to stop, saying they would ``only give authorities a justification for more repression.'' In their crackdown against the protests ``Kosovo authorities have once again demonstrated ... the lack of minimal willingness to tackle social problems through dialogue,'' said a joint statement by the region's three newly-formed independent opposition groups. About 100 Kosovo Albanians were arrested in the wake of this week's unrest. Protesters were demanding the release of political prisoners and the lifting of a partial state of emergency in the province imposed last year. At least 28 people died in violence that erupted in the province last year, after constitutional changes were passed limiting the region's autonomy. The largest republic of Serbia, of which Kosovo is an administrative part, gained near-total control over the region. Albanians make up about 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million people. The opposition statement urged Kosovo residents to sign a petition detailing their demands for democratic reforms in the country's most economically underdeveloped region. The main points on the petition would establish ``the conditions for the creation of parliamentary democracy in Kosovo, prevent a new spiral of violence,'' said Veton Surroi, a spokesman for the opposition. The Serb minority in the province has claimed harrassment by the ethnic Albanian majority there, and authorities have said the partial state of emergency was necessary to protect the minority. The petition calls for the lifting of emergency measures in Kosovo, the freeing of all political prisoners, free elections and freedom of the press. Yugoslavia's federal government has promised to permit the first free multi-party elections in communist Yugoslavia next April.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Says He Is Firm Against U.S. Pressures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with captain dismissed following shooting of young boy, SUB 8th graf pvs with 3 grafs; pickup 9th graf pvs, `Shamir leads...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir promised Saturday to withstand U.S. pressures for concessions on Middle East peace issues. He also threatened _ for the second time in a week _ to resign from his job if he loses a party vote of confidence. In the West Bank, soldiers shot and killed two Palestinians on Saturday in a clash with stone-throwers in the village of Abu Dis, Arab reports said. The army confirmed a clash in the village and said it began when border guards ``came upon masked activists.'' At least one protester was wounded, an army spokesman said. Officials at Muqassed Hospital in East Jerusalem confirmed the deaths.Arab reports identified the victims as Abdullah Nabil Halabiya, 16, and his uncle, Mohammed Dahoud Halabiya, 45. Their deaths raised to 651 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis in the 25-month-old uprising against Israeli rule. Another 174 Arabs have been slain by fellow Palestinians for alleged collaboration with Israel, and 43 Israelis have died in the violence. Soldiers also clashed with protesters in the Gaza Strip, and Arab reports said five Palestinians were shot and wounded. An unidentified reservist combat captain was dismissed Saturday after an investigation found he violated regulations in the shooting of a 5-year-old Palestinian boy Jan. 23 near the West Bank town of Jenin, Israel TV said. The boy, Mohammed Kadaha, was seriously wounded by a rubber bullet that hit him in the head as soldiers dispersed stone-throwing protesters. In threatening to resign Saturday, Shamir said in an army radio interview he ``understood that if the top institution of Likud doesn't accept the policy of Likud's leader, then I can no longer fill this position.'' Shamir leads the right-wing Likud bloc. The Likud meeting has been called for Feb. 7 by Industry Minister Ariel Sharon to debate his objections to Israel's plan to hold elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip as part of an interim peace settlement. Sharon holds that the U.S.-backed plan could jeopardize Israel's claim to these lands captured in the 1967 Middle East War. Shamir said last week he would step down if Sharon and his backers undermined party support for Israel's peace plan. This time, Shamir added he would insist on a separate vote for his proposals, suggesting that rejecting Sharon's recommendations would not be enough to satisfy him. The party infighting has delayed efforts by Secretary of State James A. Baker III to convene Egyptian and Israeli foreign ministers in Washington. Baker's planned meeting is supposed to help prepare Israeli-Palestinian dialogue in Cairo on Israel's election proposal for Arabs in the occupied lands. Also delaying Baker's plans is disagreement over which Palestinians may participate in peace talks. Israel has ruled out any role for the Palestine Liberation Organization, but Palestinians consider the PLO their sole representative. Shamir said high-ranking American officials have assured him that the Bush administration never authorized recent published suggestions to reduce financial assistance to Israel. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole introduced the idea of cutting aid to Israel at a news conference Jan. 16. Dole suggested a 5 percent cut to large recipients, including Israel, which receives $3 billion a year. Dole's remarks were interpreted in Israel as new pressure on Shamir to ease his stand on peace talks.

DOC.HEAD: Crashes Becoming More Survivable, Industry Say
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 10th graf pvs, bgng: It could, with 2 grafs to UPDATE with FAA comment on safety upgrades on foreign airliners
DOC.TEXT: Air disasters such as the Avianca Airlines crash on Long Island last week are becoming more survivable, in part because design and technical advances have made jet travel safer, many air safety experts say. ``The accident rate is improving. It's not more dangerous, it's getting better,'' says S. Harry Robertson, director of the Crash Research Institute in Tempe, Ariz. ``Airplanes are getting safer as the newer generations come along. The rate of improvement is very significant.'' Capt. Ed Arbon, who flew for 22 years with TWA and is now an official of the Flight Safety Foundation, agrees. ``Some of the recent improvements do make the modern aircraft more survivable,'' Arbon says. ``Eighty to 85 percent of recent crashes are survivable,'' says Drucella Anderson, a spokeswoman for the National Transportation Safety Board. ``A lot of safeguards have been built into the planes.'' Eighty-nine of the 161 passengers _ more than half _ survived the crash of Avianca Flight 52 into a hill on the north shore of Long Island. Preliminary inquiries suggest the craft had either run out of fuel or had a very low supply when it crashed Thursday night on its way to John F. Kennedy International Airport. There was no fire when the 23-year-old Boeing 707 crashed. But many of the experts say that the battle for air safety is far from over even though air travel on the whole has become amazingly safe and millions of passengers are transported each year without incident. Under new rules issued by the Federal Aviation Administration and prompted by the investigation of air crashes, passenger seats are being strengthened and have been covered with fire blocking material. The allowable level of toxic smoke and fumes from burning aircraft materials also has been reduced, and exit doors have been made more reliable to avoid jamming. FAA spokesman Fred Farrar said Avianca, like other foreign airlines, would have been required to make some safety upgrades, such as providing fire-retardant seat covers and lavatory smoke alarms, but it would not have been required to strengthen seats. The latter requirements still are being adopted for foreign airliners, Farrar said. Arbon says that by the nature of its technology, the modern jet passenger liner is a far safer plane than the piston aircraft it replaced. ``We used to lose engines frequently,'' he said. ``The jetliner has a very reliable power plant. It also has a good guidance system, a good auto pilot; the electronics are much more reliable.'' Robertson says improvements are continuing on ``the ways in which airplanes are informed as to what is going on and how people on the ground control them.'' An example, he says, is the wind shear blamed for the August 1985 crash of a Delta airliner near the Dallas-Ft. Worth airport. ``The people in the tower had no idea of what was going on,'' he contends. ``Today they have better sensors out there. So that is improving.'' Arbon said some 70 percent of today's accidents are due to ``the human factor,'' adding that it is there that the strongest efforts for improvement are now being made. Ms. Anderson says the NTSB dates many of the improvements in air safety to the recommendations made after its investigation of the deadly fire on June 2, 1983, aboard an Air Canada jetliner en route from Texas to Toronto. Twenty-three people died aboard the plane, which made an emergency landing at the Greater Cincinnati Airport. Some suffered fatal burns. Others died of smoke inhalation. The recommendations led to the installation of fire blocking covers on passenger seats on all commercial aircraft with 30 or more seats, automatic fire extinguishers in lavatories, halon fire extinguishers in the cockpit, smoke detectors in lavatories and new rules on cabin materials to make the cabin interiors more flame resistant and less likely to emit toxic gases, Ms. Anderson said. But there are some clouds on the safety horizon. For example, Robertson said that while seats have been made stronger to resist the impact of a crash, the floor beneath them has not. ``Before the changes the seats were folding over,'' he said. ``But when the seat is stiff it makes it easier to break it off the floor.'' ``So they sometimes do pop off the floor,'' he said and added: ``Maybe this step in the right direction is going to backfire.'' Modern technology may also have reduced the protection offered by the ``protective cocoon'' or fuselage of a jetliner, Robinson says. Today's planes are made from high-strength aluminum to hold down weight. But Robertson says the resulting fuselage is brittle. ``They shatter, and sharp fragments lie all over the crash site,'' he says. ``Earlier generations of aircraft would crush, buckle and wrinkle, but the box was still there. They are losing that cocoon protection.'' Robertson, whose institute has been engaged in the study of air crashes for more than 30 years, says air disasters can be divided into three categories. These range from the airborne equivalent of fender-benders _ posing small risk to those on board _ to deadly accidents in which all or most of the passengers and crew are killed. But it is the third category _ middle-ground accidents in which some are killed but many survive _ which pose an opportunity, the safety experts say. ``The aim is to take that middle ground and expand it,'' thus reducing the number of totally deadly accidents, Robertson said. ``It is in fact being expanded.'' Robertson cites recent studies in which experts were asked what could be done to significantly improve air safety in the year 2000 and beyond. ``They said you could probably make the best contribution to safety if you can figure out a way to slow the planes enough to allow them to land at half the speed you do now,'' Robertson said, adding that might prove difficult to achieve. ``But if you can cut the speed in half you can make the greatest contribution to safety _ that's absolutely correct,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf of NEW YORK-dated last item to RESTORE dropped word. A version moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins will have his own at-bat in the campaign to keep the Yankees in the Bronx. Dinkins and Yankees owner George Steinbrenner met Friday at City Hall and agreed to renew discussion of the fate of the team that Steinbrenner has hinted at moving to New Jersey when the Yankee Stadium lease expires in 2002. ``Let's face it. The public perception is that there isn't enough parking, ingress and egress is too slow, and there is even perceptions about safety,'' Dinkins said. ``We have to do some new and unique things to get people there _ one of which is to give them a winning team,'' Dinkins said. Former Mayor Edward I. Koch had all but nailed down a 30-year extension on the Yankee lease, but Steinbrenner said they could not agree on such amenities as VIP suites and a restaurant with a view of the ballfield.

DOC.HEAD: Suspects Arrested in Killing of Salvadoran Politician
DOC.TEXT: Six Guatemalans have been arrested in the slaying of a leftist Salvadoran politician and a Guatemalan attorney, who were kidnapped in the capital and shot to death, police said Saturday. Police said the suspects were caught with a cache of weapons, including a .32-caliber pistol similar to the one used to kill the victims. Guillermo Mollinedo, a spokesman for Guatemala's national police, said the six Guatemalans also were suspected of robbing public buses, stealing weapons from the presidential guard and arms trafficking. Mollinedo said they were arrested in Puerto Barrios on the Caribbean coast, 180 miles northeast of Guatemala City. He did not say when the arrests occurred or provide any further information on the suspects. In Guatemala, suspects must appear before a judge within six hours to be charged or released. The police did not say whether they had been charged. The bodies of Hector Oqueli Colindres, 45, the deputy secretary-general of the leftist National Revolutionary Movement in El Salvador, and Guatemalan lawyer Gilda Flores Arevalo were found Jan. 13 in Jalpatagua, a city east of Guatemala City on the road to El Salvador. They had been shot in the head. Oqueli and Flores Arevalo were kidnapped a day earlier while driving to Guatemala City's airport, where Oqueli was to board a flight for Managua. He was to help monitor preparations for the Nicaraguan election Feb. 25. His political party said both were kidnapped by armed men. No one claimed responsibility for the killings. Leftist political leaders in Guatemala and El Salvador said they believed Salvadoran and Guatemalan right-wing death squads were responsible. President Vinicio Cerezo appointed a commission of top military and civilian officials to investigate, and said he would personally supervise the panel's work. The slayings came at a time of increasing political violence in El Salvador and Guatemala, where rightist factions have longstanding ties. Oqueli was a deputy foreign minister in El Salvador from October 1979 until March 1980, when a military coup overthrew the government. Like many other leftists, he fled El Salvador after the coup but returned in 1987 to participate in politics. He left again in November, as did many Salvadoran leftists, under protection of the Venezuelan Embassy after he was threatened during a major offensive by the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front guerrillas. He had reportedly planned to return home Jan. 20.

DOC.HEAD: Social Philosopher Lewis Mumford Dead at 94
DOC.TEXT: Lewis Mumford, a critic of architecture and urban planning whose writings warned of the decline of cities and the dehumanizing influence of technology, has died at age 94. Mumford, who died in his sleep Friday afternoon, ``was frail, but there was no sickness. It was simply a matter of old age,'' said his grandson James Morss. Mumford, best known for his writing on the subject of cities and culture, was the author of more than 30 books, including ``The City in History,'' for which he received the National Book Award in 1961. Morss said his grandfather spent the last few years quietly, passing the days with his wife and doing some light reading. Mumford was among 12 artists, including composer Aaron Copland and film director Frank Capra, awarded the National Medal of Arts by President Reagan in a White House ceremony in 1986. Recipients were honored for their lifetime contributions to American arts. The illegitimate son of a businessman, Mumford was born in Queens on Oct. 19, 1895, but grew up on the West Side of Manhattan. He attended City College, but ill health prevented him from completing his degree. Instead, he took graduate courses at Columbia University and at the New School for Social Research. It was then that he discovered the works of Sir Patrick Geddes, a Scottish town planner whose influence he said was the most important one in his life. After serving as a naval radio technician in World War I, Mumford became associate editor of The Dial magazine. His essays on housing and urban matters led him to become acting editor of The Sociological Review. Mumford co-founded the Regional Planning Association of America in 1923 and served on the staff of the New York Housing and Regional Planning Commission. In 1938, Mumford published ``The Culture of Cities,'' a book that traced the history of cities in the modern world and set forth proposals for their improvement. The book made his international reputation and put him on the cover of Time magazine. He was among the earliest and most prescient critics of highways in Manhattan. In 1943, he wrote that ``express highways would be admirable if they were related to anything except the desire, on the part of the more prosperous, to get out of New York as fast as possible; actually, their function is to increase the planless decentralization of the metropolis and thereby pile up such a load of decaying properties in the center as to hasten the final exodus.'' In addition to his writings on urban issues, he wrote a weekly art column for The New Yorker. At the same time he published the first of four volumes in what became known as the ``Renewal of Life'' series. A social philosopher and educator, Mumford implored people to place a higher value on human feelings and morals than on dehumanizing technology. He feared that science and technology would eventually lead to ``a uniform, all-enveloping superplanetary structure, designed for automatic operation.'' Man, he said, will then ``have not only conquered nature, but detached himself as far as possible from organic habitat.'' He is survived by his wife, Sophia; daughter Alison Mumford Morss, of Amenia; and two grandchildren, James, of New York City and Elizabeth of Troy, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Budget To Claim Big Deficit Cut, But Economic Assumptions Faulted
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts new 2nd graf to provide more budget details; picks up 3rd graf pvs ``The budget ...'' ^By MARTIN CRUTSINGER
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's $1.23 trillion budget, due to be unveiled Monday, will seek to slash the federal deficit in half in 1991, administration sources said Saturday, in a spending plan based on pared-down defense outlays and optimistic economic assumptions. Bush, sticking to his campaign pledge, will meet his deficit goal without a general tax increase, opting instead to save billions of dollars through trimming a variety of government programs, ranging from Medicare to college student loans. The budget document, Bush's first solo effort to reorder the government's spending priorities, also will contain a somewhat whimsical overview written by Budget Director Richard G. Darman, who likens the federal budget to the ``Ultimate Cookie Monster'' _ the voracious gremlin on the ``Sesame Street'' television program. With a generally rosy set of assumptions about economic growth and with a host of proposed cuts in military and domestic spending programs, the administration projects that the deficit for 1991 will be reduced to $63.1 billion, just under the $64 billion deficit target established in the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law. The administration projects a deficit for the current fiscal year of $123.8 billion, far above the Gramm-Rudman target of $100 billion, according to officials who have seen the budget projections and who spoke on condition that their names not be used. The budget forecasts the deficit will be reduced to $25.1 billion in 1992 and will actually show a surplus of $5.7 billion in 1993, the year the Gramm-Rudman law calls for a balanced budget. It projects further surpluses of $10.7 billion in 1994 and $9.4 billion in 1995. Former President Ronald Reagan also submitted budgets showing surpluses down the road, but the surpluses never materialized because the economic assumptions upon which the revenue and spending forecasts were based proved too optimistic and Congress balked at going along with many of the program cuts. Many analysts believe a similar fate will befall the 1991 Bush budget, the president's first complete spending blueprint. Last February, he released a 193-page set of amendments to Reagan's final budget. Even before its release, the Bush administration's assumptions about economic growth were being called into question. The Congressional Budget Office, projecting lower economic growth and thus lower government tax revenues, is estimating higher deficits and thus the need for sharper cuts for 1991 and following years. Bush's 1991 budget, for the fiscal year beginning next Oct. 1, proposes total spending of $1.233 trillion and expects government receipts will total $1.170 trillion, leaving a deficit of $63.1 billion. In his budget, Bush will propose using a portion of the surplus revenues in coming years to set up a ``Social Security Integrity and Debt Reduction Fund'' which would reduce the $2.8 trillion federal debt and ``thus leave a more manageable financing burden for future generations,'' according to Darman's overview. The fund is the administration's effort to derail a politically popular proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to roll back Social Security tax increases this year and in 1992. The budget does not include any proposed general tax increase, continuing to honor Bush's no-new-taxes campaign pledge. To honor another 1988 pledge, Bush will once again seek to slash taxes on capital gains _ the profits resulting from the sale of stock or other assets. That effort is certain to generate partisan wrangling on Capitol Hill. To deflect arguments that the capital gains reduction is a tax cut for the wealthy, Bush will unveil a proposed ``family savings account'' which would allow people to earn tax-free interest and dividends on money invested for at least seven years _ with contributions of up to $5,000 per year per family. Among the budget cuts, Bush will propose to trim $8.5 billion from projected spending on Medicare, the huge health plan for Social Security recipients. The money would be saved by lowering payments to hospitals and doctors, not by curbing patient benefits. Seeking to capitalize on the lowered East-West tensions, the administration is proposing a pared-down Pentagon budget with outlays totaling $292.1 billion, up slightly from this year, but representing a 2 percent cut after adjusting for inflation. The 1991 budget proposes reducing active duty military personnel by 38,000, cutting civilian Defense Department employment by 5,000 and reducing the reserves by 3,000, while protecting some of administration's pet programs, such as the Strategic Defense Initiative, the nuclear shield in space commonly called Star Wars. ``By 1995, defense spending will be at its lowest level, measured either as a share of (the total economy) or as a portion of total federal spending, since before World War II,'' Defense Secretary Richard Cheney said in a Pentagon budget document obtained by The Associated Press from congressional sources. To help meet the trimmed down spending levels, Cheney is scheduled to unveil on Monday a sweeping list of proposed military base closures and reductions over the next five years, targeting installations from Philadelphia to Long Beach, Calif. Cheney's moves have already prompted cries of protest from members of Congress who have been briefed on which installations are on the ``hit list.'' Darman complains that Congress has widely inflated expectations of how much in government resources will be freed up from the so-called peace dividend resulting from the reduced Soviet threat in Eastern Europe. ``This great historical shift has been almost trivialized in its translation into public debate about the budget. The issue has been framed as: `How big is the peace dividend?' _ and, in effect, `How can I get mine?''' Darman wrote in his essay, first reported in Saturday's New York Times. Darman's colorful essay, titled ``The Director's Introduction to the Budget,'' offers a tour of the budget ``wonderland'' with references to the budget as the ``Ultimate Cookie Monster.'' ``Its excessive tendencies toward consumption are not exactly ennobling,'' Darman writes. He also likens many huge government spending programs to the popular video game ``Pac Man,'' as they wait to ``spring forward and consume another line of resource dots in the budget maze.'' The 1,592-page Bush budget, bound with a blue cover, will go on sale Monday at government bookstores for $38.

DOC.HEAD: Nationalists Battle Troops, Truce Reached on Border Section
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with additional comment from People's Front, SUB grafs 4-5 pvs with 5 grafs; pickup 6th graf pvs, `Most of...' Kh. in 7th graf stands for first initial of Hajizade's name.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB1,2,3; LaserColor MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: Armed nationalists battled troops in southern Azerbaijan, leaving five people dead, but other nationalist fighters agreed to withdraw from a tense section of the Armenian-Azerbaijani border, Tass said Saturday. A truce along that part of the border was said to be holding, and the Interior Ministry reported exchanges of hostages between Armenians and Azerbaijanis. Troops made scores of arrests Saturday to crush what the official Soviet news agency called the ``criminal military structure of the People's Front of Azerbaijan.'' The People's Front offered to negotiate with Soviet officials, a spokesman for the movement said by telephone late Saturday from Baku, the republic's capital. It offered to maintain order, call off strikes and get workers to work double shifts to make up for lost production. It was unlikely that the Soviet government would agree to those terms, however. The Soviet defense minister, Dmitri T. Yazov, said last week that soldiers and security forces were intent on rooting out a nationalist network from factories and state-run institutions. But another leader of the People's Front, Kh. Hajizade, said in a telephone interview from Baku that the group's loose structure of small independent units was keeping the front alive. ``The People's Front continues to operate whether or not its leadership is arrested,'' he said. Hajizade said the front also stood ready to discuss the removal of Soviet soldiers, the fate of reform in the republic and other issues. Most of Baku was still reported on strike Saturday to demand the withdrawal of Soviet soldiers who entered the city Jan. 20. Tass quoted Baku's military commandant, Lt. Gen. Vladimir Dubnyak, as saying 125 people, including 27 police and soldiers, have died since troops seized control in Baku. That raised the death toll since ethnic violence began Jan. 13 in Baku to 197. Dubnyak did not provide further details on the figures. It was not clear how many of the deaths occurred in the assault on Baku on Jan. 20, or whether the figures included the five deaths in the battle in the southern region of Gaftona. One soldier was among those killed in the clash between soldiers and armed nationalists near the Caspian Sea, Tass said. Four others were wounded and 54 people were arrested, Tass said. It did not say what day the clash occurred. Tass also reported the arrests of 80 people in Lenkoran and 22 in nearby Neftechala. Another 35 people, Armenians and Azerbaijanis, were arrested outside Kirkidzhan, the main city of the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region in Azerbaijan, Tass said. The national daily newspaper Trud, quoting military reports, said more than 1,000 military uniforms and a large cache of arms were seized in headquarters of the People's Front, along with telephone lists, bank passbooks, passports and other belongings of Armenians who were victims of ethnic attacks. Those attacks evolved into a fight for secession by militants in Azerbaijan, a predominantly Shiite Moslem republic. Rakhmi Gadzhiyev, identified as a leader of the pro-independence Azerbaijani People's Front and a member of the National Defense Committee, the front's militant wing, was among those arrested, the news agency Tass said. Forty more members of nationalist groups linked to the People's Front were arrested, another newspaper, Komsomolskaya Pravda, quoted police Lt. Col. A. Sorokovikh in Baku as saying. But newspapers said Front leaders had gone underground and were preparing ``new mass disorders.'' Nearly 150 people were detained in Baku overnight, most for violating curfew, the reports said. Tass reported that negotiators meeting along the border between Armenia and the Nakhichevan region of Azerbaijan had agreed to remove all armed men by Sunday morning. The two sides may have unarmed patrols of no more than 10 men on the roads nearby, according to the agreement. Meeting in the Armenian border town of Eraskh, the two sides agreed Thursday on a cease-fire. Tass said the two sides exchanged 17 Armenian hostages for 22 Azerbaijani hostages. But Rafael Popoyan, an Armenian delegate, reported from the Armenian capital, Yerevan, that shooting from the Azerbaijani side had been reported Saturday during a continuation of the talks. The ethnic attacks in Baku on Jan. 13 started the latest flare-up in violence in the Caucasus republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan, which are disputing control of the mountainous Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan. The population of Nagorno-Karabakh is predominantly Armenian and is demanding to be united with Armenia. Officials of the People's Front organizations of the three Baltic republics announced that officials from analogous movements in Armenia and Azerbaijan had agreed to travel to Latvia for possible peace talks. But the Azerbaijanis said they would negotiate only if the Armenians did not bring up claims to Nagorno-Karabakh. Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov told Soviet journalists on Friday that the army had moved into Baku past barricades of heavily armed nationalists to stop a drive to transfer power to the People's Front. He said the soldiers and security forces were intent on rooting out a nationalist network from factories and state institutions. Yazov said the Soviet military estimates there are 40,000 well-armed nationalists still loose in the republic. Five hundred buses were back on the road in Azerbaijan, and the restoration of full service was expected soon, it said. In Baku, some stores were beginning to open, although there were shortages of supplies and long lines. Television broadcasts resumed for the first time in a week but more than 400 enterprises were at a standstill, reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Quarters Being Built for Noriega, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Construction work that goes on even at night at a federal prison southwest of Miami has sparked rumors that Manuel Noriega will be moved there from his courthouse basement quarters. Lawyers visiting clients at the suburban Metropolitan Correctional Center said they have seen work being done under floodlights and two windows have been filled with cinder blocks in an interview room. A prison official who spoke on condition of anonymity said a holding area intended for Noriega has been under construction, was being painted Saturday and could be ready for his transfer as early as Sunday. But Angel Montalvo, a prison duty officer, said the construction was routine and part of ongoing expansion at the 280-acre facility, which houses about 1,200 prisoners. Federal prisoners held for trial in Miami normally are held at the fenced center run by the U.S. Bureau of Prisons, but the deposed Panamanian leader has been confined in a courthouse apartment since he was flown from Panama Jan. 4. The U.S. Marshals Service, which holds responsibility for Noriega in the courthouse, and federal prison officials refuse as a matter of policy to publicly discuss any prisoner moves. Defense attorneys have been assured ready access to their high-profile client, but they are barred from divulging any confidential matters in the case, such as preparations for a move. Noriega, dressed in his general's uniform, appeared before U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler on Friday claiming he was a prisoner of war illegally captured in the U.S. invasion of Panama. The legal argument is given little chance of success because courts have consistently upheld the government's right to prosecute foreign defendants once they are in this country, no matter how they were brought to the jurisdiction. The doctrine, outlined in 1856, was based on a capture by a bounty hunter in Peru. In another development, two co-defendants named with Noriega in a February 1988 drug indictment planned Monday to renew their bids for release on bond before Hoeveler. The government is appealing a $1 million bond set for accused drug-money pilot Daniel Miranda, who had a bondsman on hand to obtain his release at a hearing Jan. 12. Miranda remained in custody when the prosecution appealed. In the other case, an attorney representing Luis del Cid, a former Noriega aide accused of money laundering, will argue that the government has confused him with a different man named Mario del Cid. Luis del Cid appears in a photograph with Noriega and Cuban President Fidel Castro in Havana. But his attorney, Samuel Burstyn, argues the government knows del Cid never took part in any conferences in which Castro purportedly acted as a mediator in talks between Noriega and Colombian cocaine cartel leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Pacific Northwest; Snow Across Upper Great Lakes
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in parts of the Pacific Northwest on Saturday, with rain changing to snow in the mountains, and blowing and drifting snow reached across the Upper Great Lakes. A winter storm warning was posted Saturday across the Washington Cascades and Olympics mountains and the northern Cascades in Oregon. Warnings for gale force winds on the Washington and Oregon coast continued. In Southern California, there were advisories for strong and gusty Santa Ana winds for the mountains, valleys, canyons and passes. Blowing and drifting snow was expected in northeast Iowa and northwest Wisconsin. An inch of snow fell Saturday morning at Alma, Wis. Winds were gusty Saturday morning across Nebraska, Iowa, Illinois and Kentucky. Winds gusted to about 55 mph at Carbondale, Ill., Rochester, Minn., and Sandberg, Calif.; to 50 mph at Cody, Wyo., and Grand Rapids, Mich., and to about 45 mph in the Nebraska cities of Beatrice, Kearney and Lincoln and Springfield, Ill., and Blythe, Calif. Snow reached across eastern Minnesota, northwest Wisconsin, parts of Iowa and western upper Michigan. Snowfall during the six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included 1 inch at Eau Claire, Wis., Mason City, Iowa., Minneapolis and Rochester, Minn. Heavier rainfall during the same six hours included half an inch at Seattle, Astoria, Ore., and Olympia, Wash. The nation's low Saturday in the Lower 48 states was minus 10 degrees at Lake Yellowstone, Wyo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 6 degrees at Warroad, Minn., to 82 degrees at McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Welcomes Foreign Observers to May Elections
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Communists said Saturday they would welcome international supervision to ensure fairness in the country's first free elections. A front-page editorial in the party daily Neues Deutschland said having a team of foreign observers monitor the campaign and the May 6 elections would be ``good and practical.'' It urged opposition groups to accept the proposal, which has been introduced in Parliament by interim President Manfred Gerlach, a member of one of the non-Communist parties in Premier Hans Modrow's coalition government. ``Even if all precautions are taken for free and fair elections, an additional safeguard cannot hurt,'' Neues Deutschland said. Joachim Herrmann, 61, a former Politburo member who controlled the state media in the ousted hard-line leadership of Erich Honecker, meanwhile became the latest disgraced top official to be arrested, a week after his expulsion from the Communist Party. The official news agency ADN said prosecutors were investigating whether he could be tried for high treason. It quoted a statement by the chief prosecutor's office as saying the probe was based on his alleged ``responsibility for the unconstitutional media policy of past years.'' Herrmann was the top propaganda official in the now-dissolved Communist Party Central Committee, a post through which the Communists controlled national media, including television and radio. The prosecutor's office also issued an arrest warrant for Gerhard Schuerer, former head of the State Planning Commission, on corruption charges, ADN said. Schuerer was expelled from the party last week. New Forum, the largest opposition movement and one of the most diffuse, on Saturday began a two-day congress in East Berlin to chart its course in preparation for the May elections. Opposition groups on Friday accepted Modrow's offer to join the government, but only if all Cabinet members renounce their politcal affiliations. A new group, the German Forum Party, began preparing for the elections by opening its founding congress in Karl-Marx-Stad Saturday. A delegate, Frank-Thomas Heinze, said the party will advocate free market concepts and German unity, according to ADN.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Would Use Social Security Surpluses to Reduce Debt
With AM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, hoping to derail support for a Social Security tax cut, will offer as an alternative a proposal to use the growing Social Security surpluses to reduce the national debt, administration officials said Saturday. The officials said the administration would spell out the workings of the proposal as part of Bush's 1991 budget, which will be released Monday. According to the officials, who spoke on condition that their names not be used, the debt reduction would work in the following way: The budget will call for creation of a ``Social Security Integrity and Debt Reduction Fund'' to be administered by the Treasury Department. The money for the fund would come from revenues collected by the government beginning in 1993, the year the administration projects the budget will finally enjoy a small surplus of $5.7 billion. The Bush proposal would call for the fund to receive an amount equal to 15 percent of the surplus that year in the Social Security trust fund. The contribution would rise to 50 percent of the Social Security trust fund surplus in 1994, to 85 percent in 1995 and finally 100 percent from 1996 through the year 2000. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the Social Security surplus, the amount collected in payroll taxes above what is paid out in benefits, will total $98 billion in 1993, rising to $112 billion in 1994 and $128 billion in 1995. The portion of the surplus funds flowing into the debt reduction account would be used to reduce the federal debt, which now stands at $2.8 trillion. By reducing the debt, Budget Director Richard G. Darman writes in a budget overview to be released Monday, policymakers would be leaving ``a more manageable financing burden for future generations.'' The federal debt is the sum of all of the annual deficits. Since the government has not had a surplus for 30 years, the Treasury must add to the national debt by borrowing more each year. The administration's plan assumes that the deficit reduction targets spelled out in the Gramm-Rudman law will be met and the government will start running surpluses in 1993. However, former President Reagan also forecast surpluses in future years only to see those assumptions fail to occur because of slower economic growth and the unwillingness of Congress to go along with his recommended cuts in domestic programs. The administration's proposal for dealing with the Social Security surpluses is a recognition of the growing support for a proposal by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., to reduce the Social Security tax paid by workers and their employers by $62 billion over the next two years. Moynihan wants to cut this year's 7.65 percent Social Security payroll tax back to last year's 7.51 percent rate and also cancel a further increase scheduled for next year. Bush has called the Moynihan proposal a ``charade'' that could lead to an eventual reduction in Social Security benefits or force a general tax increase, something the president has vowed to oppose. Moynihan has argued that the Social Security payroll tax should be reduced since the growing surpluses in the Social Security tax were not being saved to pay for the retirement of the Baby Boom generation but were instead being used to mask the government's real budget deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Leaders Press Flesh on New Year's Day
DOC.TEXT: While most Beijing residents rested Saturday from late-night celebrations of the start of the Year of the Horse, top leaders were out hugging babies in a campaign to show Communist Party unity with the masses. Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin and Vice Premier Tian Jiyun visited homes in a rural village outside Beijing. Premier Li Peng went to a coking plant, a thermal electricity plant and Tiananmen Square, the base for the pro-democracy movement government troops crushed in June. President Yang Shangkun visited an exhibition hall in Shanghai, and vice premiers Yao Yilin and Wu Xueqian went to a food market in central Beijing. The national television news Saturday evening showed each of them shaking hands, making jokes and hugging babies in a campaign-stumping style that has become common here only in the past few years. The official term for such visits to homes and factories is ``going to the grass roots,'' and it is an axiom of Maoist Communism that ``uniting with the masses'' is the only way to stay in power. The leaders' schedules were planned to include visits with peasants, workers and soldiers, the three ``red'' _ or revolutionary _ classes. In Tiananmen Square, Li saluted men of the People's Armed Police, a paramilitary force, and praised them for serving the country. Senior leader Deng Xiaoping was shown on television attending a New Year's Eve party in Shanghai, but there was no report of further activities Saturday. The 85-year-old Deng, who holds no official post but still holds decisive power, walked with a slightly unsteady gait, as he has in recent years, and shook hands with Shanghai officials with a fixed smile on his face. Deng customarily spends the Lunar New Year in Shanghai. Officials in Beijing gathered at the Great Hall of the People for a party, at which Li gave a speech reaffirming the government's determination to continue its drastic austerity policy. Sharp reductions in credit and construction have slowed inflation, but also have forced the closure of millions of rural factories. Urban factories remain open, but in many the workers sit around playing cards and drinking tea because they lack electricity or raw materials. Li pledged the government's ``unremitting efforts'' to educate Chinese in ``patriotism, collectivism, socialism, self-reliance and hard struggle.'' ``The year 1989 was an unusual year,'' he said. ``The Chinese people ... withstood a severe test and achieved a great victory in quelling the anti-government rebellion in Beijing last June.'' He was referring to the massive pro-democracy demonstrations that were crushed by the army, leaving hundreds and possible thousands dead. ``We believe that ... the progressive cause of socialism has a bright future in spite of twists and turns along its advance,'' he said. Li condemned what he called a trend in Taiwan toward seeking independence from the mainland. The island province has been isolated from the mainland since 1949 under rule of the rival Nationalists, but both sides have always regarded it as part of China. ``We will not sit idly by and will not keep silent if Taiwan works for independence,'' Li warned.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 13-17, ``A senior official to update with comments after Perez meeting and include Arias comments
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle said Saturday after meeting with Latin heads of state that the U.S. invasion of Panama has created no ``sour note'' in U.S.-Latin relations despite their earlier comments deploring the military action. Quayle said, however, that the heads of state with whom he met did voice concerns and made it clear they want to see U.S. invasion troops withdrawn from Panama. ``Yes, it will help when we're able to reduce our troops,'' Quayle told reporters after a lunch with the presidents of Costa Rica, Venezuela, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador and the prime minister of Belize. ``That will be a positive contribution toward the building of democracy in Panama.'' ``Did they express concern? Certainly concern was expressed,'' Quayle acknowledged. But he and his aides reported an upbeat atmosphere nonetheless. Quayle had said earlier in the day that the additional troops would be withdrawn in ``a matter of weeks, not months.'' A senior administration official traveling with Quayle said that the sense was many Latin countries would not recognize the U.S.-installed government of President Guillermo Endara in Panama until the troop levels are down from the current 17,000 to the pre-invasion force of some 13,000. At the invasion, there were a total of 27,000 U.S. troops. However, the official insisted, there was ``no resentment'' expressed at the luncheon at the home of newly inaugurated Honduran President Rafael Callejas. ``Panama was the dog that didn't bark,'' the official claimed, speaking on condition of anonymity. Quayle was sent by President Bush to explain the invasion rationale to the regional leaders, most of whom expressed dismay at the invasion of Panama's sovereignty in the Dec. 20 military action. ``I am convinced that this decision by the president ... will not be any type of sour note and we will be able to continue with the good relations we have had,'' Quayle told reporters. ``There is no strain in the relationship.'' Quayle talked at some length privately with Callejas about economic issues, aides said, and also for about 25 minutes with Costa Rican President Oscar Arias about the upcoming presidential election in neighboring Nicaragua. He later held a lengthy session with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez, whose government was among the most offended by the invasion of Panama. A senior official traveling with Quayle subsequently characterized Perez' position as: ``He regretted the U.S. had to take this action, however it was done.'' Venezuela was among the countries that signaled to Quayle that resentment against the invasion was so intense that it would not be opportune for him to visit there now. The official in the Quayle party said Perez explained that a Quayle visit ``would be an excuse for the left to stage anti-American demonstrations.'' However, the official said Perez said he would welcome a visit by Quayle soon and that ``it would be a very positive situation'' when the additional U.S. troops are out of Panama. ``It is necessary for the United States to withdraw its troops from Panama as soon as possible,'' Arias said at a news conference. ``It is also necessary for the U.S. and Latin America to undertake a joint effort as soon as possible to help in the total reconstruction of Panama.'' The leaders were in Honduras for the inauguration of Callejas. Quayle, speaking briefly to reporters after the breakfast at the home of Ambassador Chris Arcos, acknowledged the Panama invasion was ``not without controversy. ``We have certainly read the public pronouncements. Today and tomorrow and Monday my mission will be private consultations, not in the nature of apologizing, but in the nature of where do we go from here. How can we work together to build democracy.'' As to the 17,000 troops remaining in Panama, down from about 27,000 at the height of the invasion, Quayle said he would tell the Latin leaders Bush is committed to reducing the level to the 13,000 pre-invasion strength. He would not give a timetable but said it was ``a time period of weeks rather than months. We are moving in a downward direction.'' Before the inauguration, Quayle met with El Salvador's President Alfredo Cristiani in a session that focused mostly on human rights and the need to move expeditiously to prosecute military officers charged in the Nov. 16 slaying of six Salvadoran Jesuit priests. Quayle was applauded and cheered where he entered the outdoor stadium where the inaugural ceremony was held. He later commented ``I was impressed by the enthusiastic response President Callejas got'' during his lengthy inaugural speech. Following the ceremony, Quayle met with the presidents of Venezuela, Costa Rica, Guatemala and Belize, in addition to Callejas. They attended a luncheon hosted by Callejas that included a minister of Nicaragua, Miguel d'Escoto. Nicaragua's president, Daniel Ortega, did not attend the inauguration of his neighbor. As Quayle arrived at Callejas' home he told a handful of onlookers that it was ``a great day for democracy.'' At lunch Quayle planned to discuss Bush's rationale for the Panama invasion, his aides said. Quayle and his party, which included Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., and Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, D-Miss., strongly urged Cristiani to keep pressing on that case, said one official in the Quayle party. They impressed on him the high level of interest in Congress, where the Jesuits case revived rumblings about cutting the $1.5 million-per-day U.S. aid to El Salvador. Talking briefly with reporters, Quayle said Cristiani had assured him of his ``steadfast conviction'' to seeing justice in the case. He praised Cristiani for ``doing the right thing'' in arresting four officers and four soldiers in the killings. Cristiani assured Quayle and his party ``that he will pursue this investigation to its conclusion,'' the vice president said. Cristiani said ``we are very well on our way'' in the investigation. Testimony by the soldiers has pointed to Col. Guillermo Alfredo Benavides, who is charged in killings, as the one who gave the orders. If they come to trial it will be the first trial of officers in connection with a human rights case in El Salvador. Quayle aides said the vice president also was prepared to discuss concerns by the small countries of the region who stand to see their U.S. aid packages cut, even as Bush puts forward a $1 billion plan to help Panama recover from the invasion. In Honduras, the United States withheld some $70 million in 1989 aid because outgoing President Jose Azcona did not implement promised economic reforms. Callejas, leader of the National Party, succeeds Azcona after winning the election last November. It was the second time Callejas was the top vote getter in a presidential contest. The other was in 1985 when he was prevented from victory by election rules that allowed Azcona to take office. Callejas has promised to implement economic reforms that the United States has been pushing. Also of concern to the Bush administration is how the new government will deal with the Nicaraguan Contra rebels encamped along the Honduran border. Azcona periodically has demanded the U.S.-backed rebels be removed from Honduran territory. But U.S. officials have urged Honduras not to boot them out. Traveling with Quayle for all or part of his three-day trip to Panama Saturday night and Jamaica on Monday are Lugar, Montgomery, Republican political consultant Mitch Daniels, Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson, as well as Quayle's staff.

DOC.HEAD: Publication Keeps Pulse on the Man Who's A Heartbeat Away
DOC.TEXT: For six months, Jeff Yoder and Deborah Werksman have been hunting Quayle in the newspapers and are displaying their catch in a new publication devoted exclusively to the vice president. The Quayle Quarterly went out in the mail last week to its first 500 subscribers, offering a generous mix of satirical and serious news about the man who's a heartbeat away from the presidency. Articles include ``The Quayle Trail,'' a sampling of Quayle's verbal gaffes, ``Travel Tips for Number Twos,'' and ``Here, But Still Forgotten,'' along with a quiz, cartoons and letters. There's an advertisement for a Dan Quayle doormat and a list of Quayle statistics, like the number of House Small Business Committee meetings he missed in one session (10 of 14). Subscriptions have been sold so far to citizens, political consultants and the Democratic National Committee. No senators and congressmen have signed on, ``but I think a lot of their aides did,'' said Werksman, 31. She runs the desk-top operation with her husband from his Bridgeport home. They have a commuter marriage and Werksman lives in New York City. Both are registered Democrats and did not vote for Quayle and his running mate. That Quayle is vice president ``means he's grooming for the presidency. He's being groomed and the American public is being groomed to accept him,'' Werksman said. ``Americans have a short memory and we would just like to keep the focus. We don't want it to just happen and everybody turn around and say, `How did this happen?''' she said. Yoder, 35, got the idea for the Quayle Quarterly while driving to his job at a Stamford computer software firm. ``He heard on the radio _ this was back in September _ that William Bennett was being named drug czar, and it registered in his mind that that was a job Bush mentioned as Quayle's job all through the election,'' Werksman said. ``He wondered, well, what is Quayle's job? And he thought others were probably wondering as well,'' she said. Werksman and Yoder figure they'll have to sell 2,000 subscriptions to break even. Four issues cost $12. Is Quayle a subscriber? ``We sent him a complimentary copy of the first issue. We only sent it yesterday _ bulk mail,'' Werksman said with a laugh on Tuesday. ``In fact, we debated whether we should make him buy it.'' Quayle's spokesman, Dave Beckwith, said he has yet to see a copy, but knew it was coming because his office answered questions from the publishers. ``I'm not exactly sure who they are, but we tried to answer their questions as well as we could,'' he said. ``It seems to be a mixture of fun _ which I have no objection to, as long as they're fair about it _ and serious, scholarly work.''

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Invites More Controversy with Remarks on Alcohol Abuse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to ADD that Silber has taken leave from university post and comments from spokeswoman. Michal is cq. Picks up 8th graf, `Silber's remarks...'.
DOC.TEXT: The same day gubernatorial candidate John Silber found himself defending remarks viewed as racist, he caused further controversy with his comments on alcohol abuse. ``You can live with alcohol abuse and still achieve at a high level,'' said Silber, speaking to a group of Milton High School teachers Friday. Silber, who is on leave as president of Boston University, described a former boss who drank a ``pint of whiskey or enough until he put himself to sleep'' every night but awoke to function fully. Several teachers criticized his remarks, which came in response to a question about what the faculty should do about increased drinking by students. Silber said alcoholics do not burden society in the same way as drug addicts and should not be lumped together with them. ``He is downplaying the ramifications of alcoholism,'' said Mary Cobb, president of the teacher's union. ``The horror and destruction alcoholism causes may not be as flashy, but they can be just as devastating as drug abuse.'' Michal Regunberg, a Silber spokeswoman, said Saturday the Democratic candidate's remarks were not controversial and stressed that he did not discount the dangers posed by those who drive after drinking alcohol. ``I think what he was saying is that in comparison with the scourge of drugs ... you can't compare the two. Alcohol, whether we like it or not, has been a part of society for a long time,'' she said. Silber's remarks Friday came during a day when he had to defend himself in the face of charges that he had made racist remarks about welfare in Massachusetts. In a published interview he had questioned whether the state has become a ``welfare magnet.'' ``I think anyone who raised the suggestion that I was either hostile to immigrants or in any sense a racist definitely owes me an apology,'' Silber said Friday, adding that his father was a German immigrant. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who is not seeking re-election, called Silber's comments about immigrants to the state offensive and pressed him to apologize.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0587 to fix file number. SUBS 1st item in AM-Digest Briefs to UPDATE.
DOC.TEXT: Communist leaders wrote off their fading party on Saturday and began issuing cards for a new party, one they hope stands a better chance of winning power in an increasingly democratic Poland. They met for the final congress of the Polish United Workers Party _ the communist party's formal name _ as riot police clashed outside with hundreds of demonstrators still outraged by the Communists' long hold on Poland. No arrests or serious injuries were reported. At least one major reformer, Tadeusz Fiszbach, did not sign up to join the new party, which had yet to be named. A party spokesman said there were no figures on how many delegates did. The three-day congress was convened to officially dissolve the Polish United Workers Party, as the Communist Party is formally known. Delegates also planned to condemn Communist ideology, endorse parliamentary democracy and start a new left-wing party with a different name.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Fall to Their Deaths at Apartment Building
DOC.TEXT: Two construction workers plunged to their deaths Saturday when a ladder they were using on a 14th floor terrace toppled over, police said. Police Sgt. Norris Hollomon identified the victims as Benjamin Perez, 22, and Manuel Suberdo, 31, both of New York. According to police and witnesses, the workers were doing brick and stone restoration work on the 14-story midtown apartment building when the ladder Perez was standing on twisted and fell. Suberdo tried to right the ladder but lost his footing and fell with his co-worker to the sidewalk, said Sgt. Ed Burns, a police spokesman. The contractor, Key Restoration, was issued a summons by the city Department of Buildings for working on Saturday without permits, said Hollomon.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Field Biologist Sees `Total Destruction' of Amazon Rain Forest
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. field biologist and conservation activist said Saturday he foresees total destruction of the Amazon jungle, home to thousands of species of plants and animals and a major source of Earth's oxygen. Archie Carr blamed the Brazilian government, saying it complained about efforts to protect its rain forest instead of cooperating to save the jungle, the world's largest wilderness. He spoke to The Associated Press at a congress on conservation at this field research station 70 miles west of Caracas, the capital. U.S. and Latin American field biologists and educators have gathered in the rain forest to discuss ways to instill a conservation ethic in young people. Most U.S. participants said they were surprised at how much conservation was taught in a school they visited in the Catia slums of west Caracas and how much grass-roots support for conservation exists in the region. ``Many of us were not even aware of our own prejudices,'' said Ann Berkovits, director of teaching programs at the Bronx Zoo in New York City. The First Pan-American Congress on Conservation of Wildlife through Education is sponsored by the New York Zoological Society through its field research wing, Wildlife Conservation International. Carr is regional coordinator of the society's field programs in Mexico and the Caribbean. Brazilians say their struggling economy benefits from development work in the Amazon. President Fernando Collor de Mello told a news conference Friday in Washington, where he was visiting President Bush, that his government is aware of environmental concerns. But, he said, any actions Brazil decides to take will be because the government believes it is in the best interests of Brazil, not because of outside pressure. Carr said in the interview, ``At the present time, I see no reason not to foresee an Amazon Basin that is totally deforested, populated from end to end, and the scene of a whole host of environmental problems that would constitute a planetary disaster of historical dimensions.'' He said Brazil's recent efforts to overturn legislation giving tax breaks to settlers clearing the land were not enough to save the immense region, almost as large as the continental U.S. ``The only thing that's saving the Amazon at present is its magnitude,'' he said. Carr said Brazil in the mid-1970s instituted a tax program to encourage slum dwellers in major cities to emigrate to the scarcely populated northern and western Amazonian states, but that the soil there is not able to support agriculture and settlers were left worse off than before. ``That's what galls conservationists. If we're going to help poor people, let's help poor people, not try to solve a momentary crisis by invading nature,'' he said. ``I just won't accept that saving the Amazon Basin is an imperialistic solution. The urge to conserve the environment is a universal need and it is growing,'' Carr said. He was answering criticism that industrialized nations are hypocritical in urging the Amazon nations of Brazil, Venezuela, Ecuador, Colombia and Peru to conserve the jungle instead of cleaning up their own backyards. The five countries recently formed an Amazonian nation pact to study the little-known region and come up with solutions to save its resources. But Carr warned that because of a delicate environmental balance in the Amazon, tampering with the region could lead to severe flooding and droughts that would change the entire planet's weather patterns. He said creating a national park would not solve the problems facing the Amazon Basin, because of the sheer vastness of the region. Scientists say destruction of the rain forest adds to the greenhouse effect, which traps the sun's rays and causes global warming. The Brazilian government says only 5 percent of its rain forest has been destroyed. The World Bank, however, says 12 percent has been cut and burned.

DOC.HEAD: Quaker Uses Full-Page Newspaper Ads to Launch Volley in Oat Bran Wars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to DELETE extraneous word.
DOC.TEXT: Quaker Oats Co. is using full-page newspaper ads to sprinkle some salt on the credibility of a recent medical study that found oat bran supplies no special cholesterol-lowering effect. The cereal manufacturer has bought full-page ads in seven major newspapers nationwide to cite 10 previous studies supporting its claim that eating oat bran helps reduce blood-cholesterol levels and the risk of heart attack. The plain black-and-white ads, published Friday in some papers, list the studies individually by author, title, publication and date. ``Quaker Oat Bran can help reduce cholesterol. Look at 27 years of research,'' say the ads, which ask consumers who want details on the research to write to the Chicago-based company. The ads were bought in USA Today, The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Boston Globe, the Chicago Tribune and the Los Angeles Times. Quaker holds about 70 percent of the oat bran cereal market. Its sales of Oat Bran Original Hot Cereal went from 1 million pounds in all of 1987 to 2 million pounds per month in 1989. In all, 218 new oat bran products were introduced last year alone, according to Gorman's New Product News, an industry newsletter. But some analysts predict the oat-bran boom will go bust, or at least be deflated, because of a Harvard study published last week saying oat bran has no special cholesterol-lowering properties. The study, which appeared in the New England Journal of Medicine, said the apparent cholesterol-reducing benefits of eating oat bran resulted from its replacement of fatty foods in people's diets, not from a special property of the grain itself. Other cereals work just as well to reduce artery-clogging excess cholesterol in the bloodstream, said the authors. Kellogg Co., another major cereal manufacturer that makes oat products such as Common Sense Oat Bran cereal, has ``no plans to change our marketing strategy and no plans to change our advertising,'' spokeswoman Nancy Roach said from the company's headquarters in Battle Creek, Mich. Quaker spokesman Ron Bottrell said his company has no plans to run additional ads or to change its marketing or advertising for Quaker Oat Bran hot cereal, Oat Bran cold cereal or oatmeal products. The company has research findings indicating the Harvard study hasn't swayed people away from using oat bran, ``but we wanted to reinforce with those customers (the fact that) a large body of research existed,'' Bottrell said. Bonnie Liebman, director of nutrition for the Washington-based consumer group Center for Science in the Public Interest, agreed. ``Scientists are used to having studies with opposite results and they know that, over time, the truth emerges,'' Ms. Liebman said. ``Consumers have only recently accepted science and health as news, and they aren't used to that.''

DOC.HEAD: $770,000 Paid for Antique Weather Vane
DOC.TEXT: A 19th-century weather vane was sold for $770,000 at an auction Saturday, a record for an American folk sculpture, Sotheby's announced. The copper and zinc weather vane, which portrays a well-dressed rider on a horse, was purchased by Stephen Score, an Essex, Mass., dealer, said Matthew Weigman, a spokesman for the auction house. It was the top lot in the sale of the collection of Bernard M. Barenholtz, who co-founded the toy manufacturer Creative Playthings and was a widely repected collector and author. Barenholtz died last August. The collection brought a total of $2.6 million at the auction, a record for an American folk art collection, Sotheby's said. Barenholtz acquired the weather vane, made about 1860, in 1966. The 42-inch high piece, created by J. Howard & Co. of West Bridgewater, Mass., has a bullet hole through the top hat of its rider. Other unusual items sold at the auction included a late 19th-century squeak toy, a dog, which brought $1,210; an early 19th-century pine spinning toy carved into a sailor, which brought $38,500; a 19th-century rocking horse that sold for $17,600; and an 1824 New England tavern sign that sold for $71,500, Weigman said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Journalist Blair Bolles Dies
DOC.TEXT: Blair Bolles, a former journalist who worked for The Washington Star and The Blade of Toledo and wrote a book about the reconstruction of Europe after World War II, has died at age 78. A cause of death was not immediately available. He died Friday. Bolles attended Yale University and in 1935 began covering the White House and State Department for the now-defunct Washington Star. He also wrote for a number of publications, including The Nation, Business Week, The New Republic, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Click magazine, and the King Features Syndicate. His book, ``The Big Change,'' was based on his reporting for the Blade from 1953 to 1956 and argued that Europe's old class structure would give way to a more consumer-oriented, Americanized society. Bolles wrote three other books: ``Tyrant from Illinois,'' ``How to Get Rich in Washington,'' and ``Men of Good Intentions.'' In addition, he co-authored ``America's Chance of Peace'' and a number of foreign-policy booklets. He began working for The Blade in 1948 on a free-lance basis, providing foreign affairs analysis. In 1953, Bolles opened the newspaper's Paris bureau. He returned to Toledo in 1956 and worked as an associate editor at the Blade until 1959, when he left Toledo and began a business career with Fairbanks Whitney, later known as Colt Industries. He worked in the company's government affairs office in Washington and retired in 1976. Bolles is survived by his sons, Harry, DeVallon, and Blair, Jr.; a daughter, Zoe, six grandchildren, and a foster grandchild.

DOC.HEAD: Split Threatens Polish Communist Plans for New Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with grafs 1-25, UPDATING with split within communist party threatening plans for single new party, quotes. Picks up 15th graf pvs, `As delegates.' EDITS thereafter to conform, tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WAR51
DOC.TEXT: The communist party's plan to dissolve itself and form a single new party with broader appeal was threatened Saturday when a group of renegade members accused the leadership of making only cosmetic changes. The communist party opened its final congress Saturday to form a new party that it hopes will stand a better chance of winning power in an increasingly democratic Poland. After heated debate most delegates voted to suspend the congress of the Polish United Workers Party _ the party's formal name _ and immediately open the founding congress of the new, still-unnamed party. But a leading progressive, Tadeusz Fiszbach, and about 100 others refused to join, saying no authentic reform had emerged and that the new party must shed part of its old conservative membership to draw support. ``It's not our goal to break up the party, but we all are not going the same way,'' Fiszbach told about 200 delegates at a meeting early Sunday after the congress recessed for the night. Fiszbach, a communist parliamentary leader with backing from Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, was enlisting supporters for another new party _ to be called the Social Democratic Union of the Republic of Poland. Communist leaders sought to negotiate with Fiszbach in hopes of avoiding a split. First Secretary Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski opened the three-day communist party congress with a surprise announcement that he would not try to lead a new party. During the afternoon, riot police clashed with hundreds of anti-communist demonstrators Saturday outside Congress Hall. No arrests or serious injuries were reported. The agenda of the communist party congress called for dissolving the 41-year-old party with a resounding condemnation of its ideology and endorsement of parliamentary democracy, the starting work on the new party. But the more than 1,600 delegates voted overwhelmingly to change the order by proceeding with forming the new party before dissolving the old one. Fear about what would happen to the party's assets was a focal point of much of the debate over issues involved in the dissolution. The legal status of buildings, companies, car fleets and other property amassed by the communist party during its long control is under review by a commission established last week. The Solidarity-led government is trying to defuse public clamor to nationalize the communists' holdings. After the vote suspending the communist party congress, delegates began signing cards making them founding members of the new, still unnamed party, which is likely to follow the Social Democratic model. The delegates then quickly approved a 44-member presidium for the new party and bylaws that had been prepared in advance. But Fiszbach's absence became public when his seat on a committee had to be reassigned. He wanted immediate dissolution of the communist party and his backers said unless there was evidence of deep reform, people would not believe a truly new party had been formed. ``I haven't seen manipulation of such a kind for a very, very long time,'' said communist parliament Deputy Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz. ``Mr. Rakowski should get a prize as the best magician of the year. In one speech he turned ... communists into Social Democrats. Everything going on in that room is too good to be true.'' Rakowski and other leaders hope the new party will become the main left-wing party in Poland's widening democratic political spectrum. The communist party ceded governing power to the Solidarity movement after disastrous defeat last year in the freest elections here since World War II. Poland since has plunged into economic reforms aimed at swiftly converting the system to free enterprise. The nation's communist party would become the second in the East bloc to reconstitute itself. The Hungarian Socialist Workers Party transformed itself into the Hungarian Socialist Party in October. As delegates met, more than 500 demonstrators from anti-Communist groups gathered outside chanting, ``Communists must go!'' They burned a red flag. Riot police moved in to push them away, with a few police using truncheons. One demonstrator was seen with a bloodied face. The police moved the protesters a block away, where demonstrators continued to hurl stones, bottles, firecrackers and a few gasoline bombs. The delegates gathered in Warsaw's imposing Stalinist-era Palace of Culture and Science, where Rakowski opened the meeting with a speech reviewing the party's past and discussing the future. In announcing he would not seek a leadership role in a new party, Rakowski, 65, said: ``I consider it appropriate to pass over the helm to a new generation.''
